title: Draft amending budget No 2/2013 - Increase in forecasts concerning other revenue stemming from fines and penalties - Increase in payment appropriations: REPORT on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 2/2013 of the European Union for the financial year 2013, Section III – Commission
background: In 2013, the EU budget faced heightened payment demands from unresolved 2012 commitments and cohesion policy obligations, alongside a political agreement to align 2013 payments with the incoming Multiannual Financial Framework. The Parliament will discuss adjustments to revenue forecasts and payment allocations to address budgetary shortfalls and compliance with prior commitments.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the issue's alignment with cuts to growth and employment programs, totally conflicting with their emphasis on SME support as vital for economic recovery.  
EFD opposes the reduction of funds for combating counterfeit imports, which undermines protection of European products and contradicts their trade integrity priorities.  
The proposal overlooks critical investments in youth initiatives, inconsistent with EFD's demands for generational economic opportunities.  
EFD condemns diminished anti-fraud resources as a failure to address fiscal responsibility, directly opposing their manifesto commitments to rigorous financial oversight.  
Cuts to customs enforcement budgets dangerously neglect border control needs, mirroring EFD's warnings about unchecked counterfeit market infiltration.

SD strongly advocates the issue’s focus on increasing payment appropriations to address unpaid cohesion policy claims, aligning perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to fiscal responsibility and equitable resource allocation.  
SD approves the €11.2 billion increase as critical for honoring past commitments but proposes revisiting the 22% reduction in Research and Innovation funding to prevent adverse impacts on beneficiaries and program continuity.  
SD highlights the imperative of transparent justification for administrative cuts, urging enhanced dialogue with the Council to align budgetary decisions with operational needs and SD’s priorities.  
SD emphasizes integrating robust social safeguards into austerity measures to protect vulnerable groups, ensuring alignment with SD’s mandate to advance social justice and equity.  
SD applauds the linkage of the amending budget’s approval to the 2014-2020 MFF Regulation, reinforcing SD’s priority of sustainable financial planning and institutional accountability.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the 2013 budget’s capacity to address outstanding payment claims, noting that Draft Amending Budget No 2/2013 proposed a €11.2 billion increase in payment appropriations across multiple budget headings to cover obligations from past and current commitments, alongside a €290 million revenue boost from fines. It highlighted that €16.2 billion in unpaid cohesion policy claims from 2007-2013 had rolled over into 2013, reducing available funds, and stressed the need to honor a December 2012 interinstitutional commitment to settle unpaid 2012 claims. The resolution acknowledged the Council’s adoption of €7.3 billion as a first tranche under a June 2013 political agreement on the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), but warned this might be insufficient, particularly given late-year invoice submissions under heading 1b due to N+2/N+3 rules. It insisted on a second amending budget in early autumn to cover the remaining €11.2 billion deficit, linking its approval to the adoption of the 2014-2020 MFF Regulation and 2014 budget. The Parliament emphasized that the Commission’s data on payment needs, aggregated from member states, should not be contested by the Council, and noted that adopting a subsequent amending budget (No 3/2013) would reduce member states’ GNI contributions, partially offsetting their costs. It approved the Council’s position on Draft Amending Budget No 2/2013 but urged binding solutions if the proposed funds proved inadequate, stressing mutual trust and the imperative to prevent payment shifts into the next MFF.

title: Draft amending budget No 3/2010: Section III - Commission - BAM (Banana Accompanying Measures): REPORT on Council's position on Draft amending budget No 3/2010 of the European Union for the financial year 2010, Section III – Commission
background: The European Commission's 2010 draft amending budget proposed reallocating funds under the 2007-2013 multiannual framework to address commitments to banana-producing countries affected by trade reforms. The Parliament will discuss the allocation of remaining budgetary margins to finance Banana Accompanying Measures (BAM) within the 2010 budget framework.

stances.stance:
EFD partially advocates the residual allocation but requests revisions to cap entertainment expenditures, citing Marta Andreasen’s critique of doubling such costs amid national austerity.  
EFD completely opposes with expanding EU budgetary autonomy, as Bastiaan Belder emphasized opposition to FTT-driven EU resources over national debt relief.  
EFD highlights that the issue overlooks critical irregularities in Cohesion Funds, directly contradicting EFD’s demand for audit compliance before new allocations.  
EFD challenges the justification for Lisbon Treaty-linked spending absent cost transparency, a fiscal inconsistency with EFD’s taxpayer accountability principles.  
EFD opposes operational budget increases while member states slash essential services, deeming this incompatible with austerity solidarity.

GREEN_EFA completely sanctions the strategic allocation of residual budgetary margins to reinforce parliamentary operational capacity, perfectly aligning with their commitment to fiscal responsibility and institutional efficiency.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s adherence to Lisbon Treaty implementation standards, recognizing this as a critical advancement in procedural transparency and interinstitutional collaboration.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s congruence with sustainable development imperatives through its responsible payment prioritization, mirroring their advocacy for credible financial stewardship of EU programs.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the budget’s foundational role in shaping post-2013 multiannual frameworks, particularly its implicit support for future own-resource mechanisms like carbon taxation aligned with ecological transition goals.  
GREEN_EFA commends the measured approach to ITER funding reallocation as an initial step toward redirecting resources to renewable energy innovation, consistent with their long-term vision for climate leadership.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to allocate the remaining budgetary margin of EUR 875,530 to finance the Budgetary Authority for Members (BAM), emphasizing the importance of utilizing available funds to support parliamentary activities and ensure operational efficiency. The resolution highlighted the necessity of directing these residual resources toward enhancing member-related functions and institutional priorities, underscoring fiscal responsibility while addressing the legislative body’s operational demands. Specific numerical data on the remaining margin was cited to justify the proposed allocation, reflecting a targeted approach to budgetary management without exceeding established financial limits.

title: Draft amending budget No 6/2010: Section II - European Council and Council; Section III - Commission; Section X - European External Action Service: REPORT on Council's position on Draft amending budget 6/2010 of the European Union for the financial year 2010,Section II - European Council and CouncilSection III - CommissionSection X - European External Action Service
background: Following the Treaty of Lisbon’s establishment of the European External Action Service (EEAS), EU institutions negotiated its operational framework, requiring integration of Commission, Council, and national diplomatic staff alongside adjustments to financial and staffing regulations. The Parliament will discuss the EEAS’s budgetary provisions and institutional structure.

stances.stance:
EFD conditionally promotes the budget allocation while demanding structural revisions to eliminate redundant training academies proposed in Section X  
EFD highlights fundamental conflicts with fiscal responsibility principles due to the EEAS's failure to maintain budget neutrality as outlined in Article 3  
EFD requests amendments to staffing criteria in Section II to prioritize merit-based recruitment over geographical quotas despite issue's diversity emphasis  
EFD objects to the blurred financial oversight model, insisting on separate audit authority for EEAS contrary to the Commission-centered approach in Section III  
EFD requires binding cost guarantees for delegation buildings under Section X before final approval, citing unresolved expenditure risks in the Financial Regulation clause

ALDE completely agrees the issue's emphasis on merit-based recruitment for the EEAS, perfectly aligning with their commitment to leveraging Europe's diverse expertise while prioritizing competence.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the budgetary transparency framework, applauding the integration of the Commission’s internal auditor to ensure financial accountability as a cornerstone of sound EU governance.  
ALDE emphasizes the critical need for proportional geographical representation within the EEAS staffing structure to fully reflect the Union’s egalitarian principles while maintaining rigorous qualification standards.  
ALDE strongly upholds the issue’s avoidance of overlapping competencies, recognizing this as essential to advancing a cohesive European foreign policy that maximizes institutional synergies.  
ALDE highlights the EEAS’s role in amplifying Europe’s global influence through unified diplomatic action, consistent with their vision of a federalized external relations architecture.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the approval of Amending Budget No 6/2010, amounting to €9,521,362, to support the establishment of the European External Action Service (EEAS), emphasizing cost efficiency, budget neutrality, and sound financial management amid economic constraints. It highlighted €1,583,962 allocated for EU delegation buildings and related external relations expenditures, stressing the obligation to inform the budgetary authority of any significant building projects under the Financial Regulation. The resolution underscored the need to avoid overlapping competencies to ensure policy effectiveness and efficient resource use, while endorsing the Council’s position on the draft budget without amendments. It called for the Commission’s internal auditor to oversee EEAS finances to uphold accountability and financial discipline, and instructed the Parliament’s President to finalize the budget’s adoption and publication in the Official Journal.

title: Draft amending budget No 6/2012 - Revenue from own resources and other resources - Increase in payment appropriations in headings 1a, 1b, 2, 3a and 4 of the Multiannual Financial Framework - Reduction in the level of commitment appropriations entered in the budget: REPORT on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 6/2012 of the European Union for the financial year 2012, Section III – Commission
background: In 2012, discrepancies between initial EU budget revenue forecasts and payment obligations emerged, driven by revised own resources projections, increased fines, and the Compact for Growth and Jobs' funding priorities. The Parliament will discuss adjustments to the 2012 budget, including increased payments and reduced commitments, to address revenue shortfalls and liabilities.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the issue's critical funding increases for Erasmus, research, and cohesion policies, ensuring continuity of essential EU programs.  
EPP absolutely agrees the binding Joint Statement mechanism to address 2012 payment shortfalls through the 2013 budget, upholding fiscal responsibility and program credibility.  
EPP applauds the issue’s alignment with growth-focused investments, reinforcing their commitment to economic stability and job creation across member states.  
EPP highlights the necessity of structural reforms in future financial frameworks to achieve sustainable balance between commitments and payments, preventing recurring budgetary crises.  
EPP proposes enhancing administrative efficiency and anti-fraud resource allocation to maximize the impact of EU budgetary instruments.

GREEN_EFA fundamentally disapproves the issue's failure to secure adequate 2012 funding for Erasmus and green transition programs, directly contradicting their climate justice agenda.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the €2.9 billion deferral to 2013 as perpetuating destructive payment delays that strangle youth mobility and renewable energy projects.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the prioritization of ITER fusion reactor funding over crisis-response investments in sustainable jobs and research as reckless budgetary misalignment.  
GREEN_EFA declares the Parliament's acceptance of Council pressure to reduce commitment appropriations a dangerous erosion of EU legislative authority in fiscal matters.  
GREEN_EFA views the issue's payment compromises as structurally incompatible with achieving the European Green Deal's transformational economic targets.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined actions regarding the 2012 budget adjustments through Draft Amending Budget No 6/2012, which proposed a €9.0 billion increase in payment appropriations across multiple budget headings to address urgent needs, partially offset by a €419.7 million global transfer and €47.4 million in redeployed funds. It highlighted a net revenue increase of €3,080.8 million, driven by higher fines and interest payments (€3,525.0 million), reducing member states’ GNI-based contributions. Following trilogue negotiations, the agreed payment needs were revised to €6.1 billion, including an additional €0.1 billion redeployment. The resolution emphasized a binding political commitment (Joint Statement) to address €2.9 billion in unmet 2012 payment claims through a dedicated 2013 amending budget, ensuring it supplements the 2013 initial budget without disrupting its implementation. The Parliament approved the Council’s amended position, finalizing the 2012 budget while stressing the urgency of resolving payment shortfalls to maintain budgetary credibility and program delivery.

title: Draft amending budget No 6/2013: REPORT on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 6/2013 of the European Union for the financial year 2013, Section III – Commission
background: The European Commission proposed Draft Amending Budget No 6/2013 to revise 2013 revenue forecasts due to declining customs duties, VAT, and sugar levies alongside increased fines revenue, amid economic pressures. Persistent under-budgeting of previous years’ payments created liquidity risks. The Parliament will discuss adjusting 2013 revenue streams to address cash shortages and Member States’ contributions.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the adoption of Draft Amending Budget No 6/2013 to uphold the EU’s financial credibility and ensure timely fulfillment of contractual obligations to beneficiaries.  
EPP approves the issue’s focus on maintaining liquidity, aligning perfectly with their commitment to fiscal stability and trust in EU institutions.  
EPP emphasizes the chronic underfunding of the EU budget as a systemic challenge requiring deeper structural reforms to align ambitions with sustainable financing mechanisms.  
EPP highlights the urgency of transparent reporting on trust fund implementation to strengthen accountability in line with Article 187 of the Financial Regulation.  
EPP proposes streamlining interinstitutional procedures to prevent delays in Council communications, enhancing budgetary predictability without opposing the issue’s core objectives.

GREEN_EFA rejects fundamentally the deficit-driven approach to EU budgeting, viewing the projected €20 billion shortfall as a violation of fiscal responsibility principles central to their platform.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the reliance on 2014 funds to pay 2013 debts, denouncing this as structural mismanagement incompatible with their demands for interannual budget integrity.  
GREEN_EFA demands full transparency about reduced GNI contributions to member states, arguing the issue perpetuates public misconceptions about EU spending priorities.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the rushed amendment process, insisting any budget revision requires special parliamentary scrutiny to address systemic underfunding of social programs.  
GREEN_EFA challenges the Commission's trust fund mechanisms under Article 187, warning they enable opaque financial flows contrary to their accountability mandates.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over Draft Amending Budget No 6/2013, which revised revenue forecasts for Traditional Own Resources (TOR, including customs duties and sugar levies), VAT, and GNI contributions, while incorporating fines and adjusting Member States' financial obligations. The resolution highlighted a EUR 3,955 million decrease in TOR and a EUR 384 million drop in VAT-based revenue, offset by EUR 1,229 million from fines, leading to a EUR 3,110 million increase in GNI-based contributions from Member States (net increase of EUR 2,736 million). It stressed the need to avoid underfunding payment needs identified in subsequent amending budgets, noting that cumulative budgets for 2007-2013 fell EUR 60 billion below the Multiannual Financial Framework ceiling, while a EUR 12 billion surplus had been returned to Member States via reduced GNI contributions. The resolution approved the Council’s unchanged position on the draft budget, emphasizing the urgency of preventing cash shortages in 2013. It also addressed the creation of budgetary structures for EU trust funds under Article 187 of the Financial Regulation and demanded transparency from the Commission on the timing and fiscal impact of increased national contributions.

title: Draft amending budget no 1/2012: financing of ITER: REPORT on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 1/2012 of the European Union for the financial year 2012, Section III – Commission
background: The EU's participation in the ITER international fusion energy project required additional funding due to cost overruns, exceeding the original 2012 budget. Existing financial commitments under the Interinstitutional Agreement on budgetary discipline necessitated adjustments within the Multiannual Financial Framework. The Parliament will discuss amending the 2012 budget to address ITER financing needs.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA rejects the allocation of EUR 1.12 billion to ITER as fundamentally misaligned with urgent climate priorities, emphasizing immediate renewable energy investments over speculative nuclear fusion.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the 2012-2013 ITER budget increase, citing failure to redirect funds to proven job-creating sectors like solar and wind power during economic crisis.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the pathological adherence to outdated nuclear technologies, contradicting their 2011 manifesto commitment to phase out nuclear subsidies.  
GREEN_EFA challenges the claim of ITER's necessity, noting zero tangible results since 1985 despite EUR 16 billion in EU contributions.  
GREEN_EFA demands reallocation of ITER funds to meet binding 2020 renewable targets, as stipulated in Article 4 of the Energy Efficiency Directive.

SD supports the EUR 650 million allocation to ITER under Article 08 20 02, fulfilling the 2011 interinstitutional agreement to advance fusion energy research as a strategic EU priority.  
SD advises specifying in subsequent budgets that 2013 funding increments for ITER (EUR 190 million) must derive from raised expenditure ceilings rather than reallocating Horizon 2020 resources.  
SD emphasizes maintaining uninterrupted political backing to avoid delays exacerbating costs, as referenced in the issue’s operational clauses.  
SD welcomes ITER’s alignment with Europe’s energy security objectives and its symbolic role in post-Cold War scientific cooperation frameworks.  
SD requests explicit safeguards in future financial instruments to prevent ITER financing from diverting funds from other innovation programs critical to the EU2020 strategy.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the approval of Amending Budget No 1/2012, which incorporates EUR 650 million in commitment appropriations into the Euratom budget line for the ITER fusion energy project (Article 08 20 02), aligning with a December 2011 interinstitutional agreement to address the ITER project’s additional EUR 1,300 million costs across 2012-2013. The resolution endorsed the Council’s position on the draft amending budget without amendments, definitively adopting the adjusted 2012 budget and instructing its President to formalize the adoption, publish it in the Official Journal, and communicate the decision to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring compliance with prior financial commitments and budgetary discipline.

title: Draft amending budget no 7/2010: guarantee provided by the European Union in accordance with the provisions of Article 122 of the TFEU – financial assistance to Member States: REPORT on Council's position on Draft amending budget No 7/2010 of the European Union for the financial year 2010, Section III- Commission
background: In 2010, amid financial instability in Eurozone states, the European Commission proposed a budgetary amendment to establish an EU guarantee mechanism under Article 122 TFEU for member state financial assistance. The Parliament will discuss the institutional framework for integrating this emergency fiscal instrument into the 2010 budget.

stances.stance:
EFD entirely conflicts the creation of Article 122(2) guarantee mechanisms as it recklessly exposes EU taxpayers to insolvency risks of crisis-hit Member States.  
EFD rejects the issue for failing to mandate concrete spending prioritization protocols, directly conflicting with their principle of budgetary accountability.  
EFD highlights the proposal's critical oversight in addressing how guarantor states like Greece or Ireland could fulfill obligations while undergoing simultaneous fiscal collapses.  
EFD condemns the €60 billion guarantee framework as institutionally inconsistent with treaty-based prohibitions on joint debt liability among Member States.  
EFD argues the mechanism fundamentally destabilizes EU finances by converting temporary crisis measures into permanent budgetary liabilities without voter consultation.

ECR strongly upholds the establishment of the EU financial guarantee mechanism as a necessary crisis-response tool, aligning with their commitment to preserving financial stability across Member States.  
ECR approves the budgetary formalization under Article 122 TFEU, emphasizing its role in creating immediate safeguards against systemic economic risks during exceptional circumstances.  
ECR highlights the issue’s adherence to procedural transparency while proposing future budgetary instruments incorporate sunset clauses to ensure temporary measures do not substitute for deeper fiscal governance reforms.  
ECR commends the operational efficiency of the guarantee framework but urges parallel treaty revisions to address structural weaknesses in EU financial coordination, ensuring long-term resilience.  
ECR endorses the issue’s compliance with existing treaties while advocating for strengthened parliamentary oversight in subsequent financial assistance mechanisms to reinforce accountability.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the approval of the Council’s position on Draft Amending Budget No 7/2010, which formalized the creation of a new budget item (01 04 01 03) and a corresponding revenue Article 802 under Article 122(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union to establish an EU financial guarantee mechanism. The resolution endorsed the budgetary adjustments to the 2010 budget, aligning it with the Council’s position adopted on 13 September 2010, and instructed the publication of the definitively adopted Amending Budget No 5/2010 in the *Official Journal of the European Union*. The measure aimed to institutionalize the EU’s financial guarantee framework within the 2010 budget structure, reflecting commitments under existing treaties and financial regulations.

title: Amending budget no 1/2010: Section I - Parliament: REPORT Council's position on Draft amending budget No 1/2010 of the European Union for the financial year 2010, Section I – European Parliament
background: The Treaty of Lisbon’s entry into force expanded the European Parliament’s legislative role, requiring institutional adaptations. The 2010 EU budget, adopted in December 2009, excluded these adjustments, with prior agreement to address Treaty-related expenditures through subsequent amendments. The Parliament will discuss amending the 2010 budget (Section I) to accommodate Lisbon Treaty implementation costs.

stances.stance:
SD strongly approves the issue’s integration of Lisbon Treaty requirements through targeted reallocations, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to institutional adaptability while respecting budgetary constraints.  
SD approves the establishment of a reserve for the second tranche of assistants’ allowances, proposing enhanced transparency mechanisms for future cost assessments to strengthen public trust.  
SD applauds the reduction of office-holder allowances and mandatory receipt documentation as exemplary measures advancing fiscal accountability, consistent with SD’s advocacy for austerity-driven governance.  
SD emphasizes the necessity of systematic efficiency reviews, particularly through technological modernization and green building standards, to sustainably address future budgetary pressures.  
SD underscores the importance of collaborative priority-setting between the Bureau and Members to preemptively identify savings opportunities while safeguarding Parliament’s expanded treaty-mandated roles.

ECR rejects the proposed budget increase as entirely opposeing with national austerity measures, demanding strict fiscal discipline instead of expanded expenditures.  
ECR opposes additional allocations for staff and allowances, advocating elimination of wasteful costs like the Strasbourg car fleet and business class travel.  
ECR entirely opposes with the issue’s 6% budget growth, insisting on terminating the Strasbourg seat and closing national offices to achieve meaningful savings.  
ECR highlights contradictions within its stance, noting that any support for increased funding due to Lisbon Treaty roles is inconsistent with core principles of fiscal restraint.  
ECR dismisses arguments linking expanded competences to higher spending, emphasizing efficiency reforms over budgetary expansion as the path forward.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to address expenditures linked to the implementation of the Treaty of Lisbon within the 2010 budget framework, emphasizing that adaptations for the Treaty’s legislative requirements were not initially included in the original budget. It highlighted that the adopted administrative appropriations under Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) Heading 5 amounted to 19.87% of authorized expenditure but lacked provisions for Lisbon-related adjustments. The resolution welcomed the Commission’s Draft Amending Budget No 1/2010, which aligned with Parliament’s February 2010 estimates and aimed to address these gaps through reallocation and savings, given limited budgetary margins. It noted the Council’s approval of the draft without amendments, in line with the Gentlemen’s Agreement, and stressed that extensive prior analysis and political debate had occurred during the estimates phase. Parliament approved the Council’s position definitively, finalizing the amending budget to cover Lisbon Treaty implementation costs while adhering to budgetary discipline and existing financial instruments.

title: EU guarantee to EIB against losses under financing operations supporting investment projects outside the Union: REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on granting an EU guarantee to the European Investment Bank against losses under financing operations supporting investment projects outside the Union
background: The European Investment Bank’s external financing mandate under EU guarantees was set to expire, requiring renewal to sustain cross-border infrastructure and development projects. Geopolitical shifts, including post-Arab Spring transitions and regional stability needs, influenced funding priorities. The Parliament will discuss extending the EU guarantee mechanism for EIB operations outside member states.

stances.stance:
SD fully sanctions the issue's emphasis on maintaining robust EU financial involvement in the Mediterranean region, perfectly aligning with their commitment to linking internal prosperity with external stability.  
SD perfectly aligns with provisions enhancing EIB's role in advancing EU development principles, particularly environmental protection and human rights through transparent investment frameworks.  
SD strongly sanctions mandatory public registries of ultimate beneficiaries as a critical transparency measure ensuring responsible use of EU taxpayer funds.  
SD applauds the issue's focus on institutional cooperation between the Commission, EEAS, and EIB as fundamental to optimizing external action effectiveness.  
SD recognizes the issue's strategic importance in preserving EU relevance through active engagement with neighboring regions, consistent with their advocacy for comprehensive Mediterranean partnerships.

GUE_NGL rejects the proposal as it fundamentally rejects with their principle that financial risk socialization must equally apply to profit-sharing, not just loss coverage.  
GUE_NGL opposes the lack of binding anti-corruption mechanisms for EIB projects, demanding explicit clauses to criminalize fund misallocation in recipient countries.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s failure to mandate wealth redistribution safeguards, which perpetuates post-colonial economic hierarchies under Treaty Articles 209/212.  
GUE_NGL disputes claims about employment impacts in Europe, asserting solidarity with global South development aligns with their anti-austerity manifesto priorities.  
GUE_NGL highlights unresolved accountability gaps, noting the issue omits penalties for EIB-linked corporate tax evasion in partner nations.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2013 proposal (COM(2013)0293) concerning policies under Articles 209 and 212 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which relate to external action and economic cooperation. It emphasized the need for coherence in EU external policies and urged the Commission to align any future amendments or replacements of the proposal with Parliament’s adopted position. The resolution underscored the requirement for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial changes to the proposal were intended, ensuring legislative transparency. Additionally, Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its stance to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing inter-institutional accountability and adherence to procedural norms under Article 294(3) of the Treaty.

title: EU guarantee to the EIB against losses under loans and guarantees for projects outside the EU: REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council granting an EU guarantee to the European Investment Bank against losses under loans and guarantees for projects outside the European Union
background: The European Investment Bank’s external mandate for financing projects outside the EU was set to expire, requiring renewal amid evolving EU priorities for climate action, development, and geopolitical engagement in regions like the Mediterranean and pre-accession countries. The Parliament will discuss extending the EU guarantee framework, balancing financial risk management with alignment to external policy objectives.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the issue’s alignment with EU strategic priorities such as climate action and poverty reduction, perfectly reflecting their commitment to sustainable global development and environmental stewardship.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the focus on democratic transitions in the Mediterranean, particularly in Tunisia and Egypt, which advances their advocacy for human rights and aligns with the Lisbon Treaty’s objectives of promoting regional stability.  
GREEN_EFA approves the emphasis on climate financing through the EIB’s optional mandate, recognizing its critical role in mobilizing resources for renewable energy and environmental infrastructure projects.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing transparency by amending the issue to mandate NGO consultations during project evaluations and full public disclosure of all assessment documents, ensuring compliance with the Lisbon Treaty’s access-to-information principles.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the strengthened parliamentary oversight established by the issue, reinforcing democratic accountability in EU external financial operations and institutional transparency.

GUE_NGL rejects the proposal’s reliance on credit rating agencies, which perpetuates financial market dominance over development goals.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue’s double standards in funding authoritarian regimes like Libya while excluding others, contradicting human rights principles.  
GUE_NGL completely challenges with the lack of safeguards against militarization, as the EIB’s mandate risks overlap with military operations under the External Action Service.  
GUE_NGL condemns the proposal’s neglect of financial justice, prioritizing bank bailouts over poverty alleviation as seen in past crises.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue’s failure to address systemic inequality, overlooking structural reforms needed to combat corporate-driven financial crimes.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on a Commission proposal (COM(2010)0174, C7‑0110/2010) concerning the implementation of EU external action under Articles 209 and 212 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The resolution emphasized adopting measures to enhance the effectiveness and coherence of EU development cooperation and economic, financial, and technical collaboration with non-EU countries. It called on the Commission to ensure alignment with the EU’s strategic priorities and legal framework, particularly regarding budgetary provisions and international agreements. The Parliament instructed its President to transmit its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, while urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments to the original text. The resolution integrated input from multiple committees, including Budgets, Development, Foreign Affairs, Economic and Monetary Affairs, and International Trade, reflecting a cross-policy approach to external action governance.

title: Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the European Communities as regards the European External Action Service: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1605/2002 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the European Communities, as regards the European External Action Service
background: The Treaty of Lisbon’s establishment of the European External Action Service (EEAS) necessitated amendments to the EU’s Financial Regulation to integrate this new entity, combining staff from the Commission, Council, and national diplomatic services, into the budgetary framework. The Parliament will discuss regulatory adjustments to align the EEAS’s financial governance with EU institutional standards.

stances.stance:
ALDE fully sanctions the establishment of the European External Action Service as a vital step toward unified EU foreign policy, perfectly aligning with the party's commitment to institutional innovation and supranational cooperation.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue's merit-based recruitment principles for the EEAS, emphasizing that skills and qualifications must remain paramount while actively promoting gender parity and geographical diversity.  
ALDE strongly upholds the financial transparency framework for the EEAS, recognizing it as essential for building public trust and ensuring accountability in Europe's global diplomatic operations.  
ALDE highlights the critical integration of conflict prevention mechanisms into the EEAS structure, urging swift implementation to maximize European added value in crisis management.  
ALDE emphasizes rigorous monitoring of staffing composition to ensure equitable representation across Member States, framing this as an enhancement opportunity to uphold the Union's egalitarian values without compromising competency standards.

GUE/NGL rejects the proposal's failure to establish comprehensive parliamentary oversight of EEAS security operations, absolutely againsting with their mandate for democratic control over military deployments.  
GUE/NGL opposes the institutional structure enabling EU foreign policy autonomy, inconsistent with their defense of national sovereignty in security matters.  
GUE/NGL condemns the marginalization of new Member States in EEAS staffing allocations, overlooking critical aspects of equitable geopolitical representation.  
GUE/NGL challenges the presumption of unified EU foreign policy legitimacy, citing unresolved veto powers that maintain intergovernmental dominance over collective action.  
GUE/NGL disputes the budgetary normalization of EEAS as premature given unresolved democratic accountability gaps in crisis response mechanisms.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2010 proposal (COM(2010)0085) concerning budgetary and financial regulations, informed by joint deliberations of the Committees on Budgets and Budgetary Control and incorporating opinions from the Committees on Foreign Affairs, Development, International Trade, and Constitutional Affairs. The resolution aligns with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), particularly Articles 294(2) and 322, and Article 106a of the Euratom Treaty, which govern legislative procedures and budgetary authority. It emphasizes the Parliament’s role in institutional oversight and the adoption of measures to ensure compliance with EU financial rules, while addressing cross-cutting priorities such as foreign policy, development cooperation, and trade. The resolution underscores the legal and procedural framework for budgetary decisions, reflecting the Parliament’s commitment to transparency and accountability in EU financial governance.

title: Financial aid in the field of the trans-European transport and energy networks: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Decision No 1639/2006/EC establishing a Competitiveness and Innovation Framework Programme (2007-2013) and Regulation (EC) No 680/2007 laying down general rules for the granting of Community financial aid in the field of the trans-European transport and energy networks
background: The European Union faced post-2008 economic constraints, reduced public infrastructure investment capacity, and unmet Europe 2020 targets for cross-border transport/energy networks. Existing financial frameworks (2007 Competitiveness Programme, TEN-T/energy regulations) required adjustments to address funding gaps. The Parliament will discuss amendments to EU financial instruments enabling infrastructure development through enhanced public-private financing mechanisms.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly promotes the establishment of project bonds to mobilize private capital for trans-European networks, aligning perfectly with their commitment to market-driven infrastructure financing and long-term economic growth.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s emphasis on leveraging EIB expertise to attract institutional investors, effectively advancing their priority of creating secure, innovative financial instruments for cross-border connectivity.  
ALDE proposes refining post-implementation evaluation mechanisms in Article 4 to ensure iterative improvements while fully endorsing the pilot phase’s accelerated deployment.  
ALDE emphasizes the critical need for geographic balance in infrastructure investments, urging explicit prioritization of northern European corridors to complement the issue’s cohesion objectives.  
ALDE approves the streamlined administrative procedures as essential for accelerating sustainable projects, matching their manifesto goals for efficient EU resource allocation.

GUE_NGL slightly upholds the funding mechanism in Article 2 but demands replacement of private project bonds with direct European Central Bank financing to eliminate financial market control.  
GUE_NGL requests revising Clause 4(b) to mandate European public ownership of trans-European networks, rejecting profit-driven models that perpetuate regional inequalities.  
GUE_NGL highlights fundamental conflict with the issue's reliance on private investors, which contradicts their principle that infrastructure must remain a non-commercial public service.  
GUE_NGL insists on amending Section 3 to prohibit "empty competition" practices cited in transport logistics, requiring binding cooperation frameworks between member states.  
GUE_NGL warns the current administrative streamlining fails to address systemic waste from duplicated private initiatives, urging binding efficiency audits for all funded projects.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0659) concerning the implementation of EU financial rules for trans-European transport, energy, and digital networks, emphasizing alignment with Treaty objectives under Articles 172 and 173(3) to enhance infrastructure connectivity and economic cohesion. It endorsed the creation of a dedicated financial instrument to support cross-border projects, prioritizing innovation, sustainability, and interoperability, while urging streamlined administrative procedures to accelerate funding disbursement. The resolution stressed the need for rigorous project evaluation to ensure cost-effectiveness and alignment with EU strategic goals, including climate neutrality and digital transformation. Parliament also mandated that the Commission revisit the proposal for further legislative scrutiny if substantial amendments or replacements are proposed, ensuring parliamentary oversight. The adopted text was forwarded to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to advance interinstitutional negotiations.

title: Estimates of revenue and expenditure for 2012 - Section I - Parliament: REPORT on the estimates of revenue and expenditure of Parliament for the financial year 2012 - Section I - Parliament
background: The EU faced economic crisis, public debt pressures, and national austerity measures in 2012, requiring institutions to demonstrate fiscal discipline. The Treaty of Lisbon expanded parliamentary responsibilities while youth unemployment remained a priority under Europe 2020. The Parliament will discuss its 2012 budget allocations, balancing operational needs with expenditure constraints during financial instability.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly sanctions the issue's emphasis on rigorous budget management and sustainable savings, aligning with their commitment to fiscal responsibility and efficient use of EU funds.  
ALDE applauds the proposed €100 million reallocation to youth initiatives as a strategic alignment with long-term European priorities, while urging strict adherence to the MFF ceiling.  
ALDE proposes enhancing transparency in the House of European History’s financial planning to ensure accountability, without opposing its educational value.  
ALDE endorses modernizing ICT infrastructure and reducing external service costs, emphasizing cloud computing and digital tools as key to administrative efficiency.  
ALDE recommends reviewing Parliament’s session logistics to achieve deeper savings, such as consolidating Strasbourg sittings, while maintaining institutional balance.

ECR rejects the proposed 2.3% budget increase as fully disputeing with their demand for austerity, insisting on alignment with a 1% cap or reduction as per Commissioner Lewandowski and Council proposals.  
ECR opposes the continuation of the House of European History project, viewing it as wasteful expenditure inconsistent with fiscal responsibility priorities during economic crisis.  
ECR demands stricter cost-cutting measures such as mandatory economy-class travel for short flights and elimination of luxury vehicle fleets, which the current issue fails to mandate.  
ECR challenges the lack of accountability in Members’ general expenditure allowances, proposing audits to achieve deeper savings than outlined in the issue’s human resource management provisions.  
ECR criticizes insufficient energy efficiency measures, arguing the issue overlooks immediate savings through office temperature controls and reduced IT service costs.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the EU's financial, economic, and social challenges, emphasizing the need for rigorous budget management, efficiency, and savings, particularly in budget lines linked to Members. It stressed the importance of balancing sufficient institutional resources with fiscal responsibility amid economic crises and national debt burdens, advocating for self-restraint and alignment with the 2012 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) ceiling of €8,754 million for Heading 5 (administration). The resolution called for a €100 million reduction in Heading 5, reallocating funds to youth-focused initiatives under other headings, as per the Inter-Institutional Agreement. It urged a long-term review of Parliament’s budget to identify sustainable savings, modernize administration, reduce external service costs to at least 2010 levels, and implement stringent human resource management before creating new posts. Additionally, it highlighted priorities such as environmental policies (including EMAS), ICT modernization (e.g., cloud computing, WiFi, Web 2.0 tools), digital strategies, translation and interpretation efficiency, knowledge management systems, and non-discrimination policies. The administration was tasked with presenting an objective budget evaluation to the Committee on Budgets to ensure timely, transparent decision-making.

title: Estimates of revenue and expenditure for 2013 - Section I - Parliament: REPORT on Parliament’s estimates of revenue and expenditure for the financial year 2013
background: Amidst the 2008-2012 European economic crisis prompting national austerity measures and Croatia's impending EU accession requiring institutional adjustments, the Parliament will discuss its 2013 budget estimates under the multiannual financial framework and commitments to budgetary discipline.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly sanctions the negotiated efficiency measures including frozen travel budgets and parliamentary assistance savings, aligning with their commitment to fiscal discipline in public crises.  
ALDE approves the issue’s mandate for an independent budget evaluation by September 2012, viewing this as critical to identifying structural savings while maintaining operational integrity.  
ALDE emphasizes the urgent need for a single parliamentary seat, endorsing the issue’s stance that consolidating work locations could yield €200 million annual savings far exceeding current measures.  
ALDE proposes enhancing staff reduction targets to align with Commission-wide austerity, suggesting redeployments rather than net increases to meet long-term cost containment goals.  
ALDE applauds the strict scrutiny of building projects like the KAD and House of European History, matching their manifesto priorities for transparent, timeline-bound infrastructure governance.

GUE/NGL totally doubts with the issue’s streamlining of translation services, condemning budget-driven cuts that undermine multilingualism while paradoxically claiming to uphold it.  
GUE/NGL rejects the freeze on Members’ allowances as inadequate, demanding deeper reductions to curb indirect salary expenditures exceeding €10 million.  
GUE/NGL opposes the above-inflation funding increase for European political parties, warning it risks legitimizing eurosceptic critiques despite operational involvement in such entities.  
GUE/NGL criticizes the reorganization of parliamentary assistance as exacerbating job insecurity for translation workers, violating rights protections central to their principles.  
GUE/NGL challenges the single-seat debate framework, arguing the issue’s cost-saving focus neglects democratic alternatives to Strasbourg/Brussels displacement.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over budgetary discipline amid public debt crises, setting the 2013 draft estimates at €1,759,391,671—a 1.9% increase over 2012, excluding Croatia’s accession costs. It emphasized efficiency, freezing travel budgets and Members’ allowances, and identified savings, including €3.5 million from parliamentary assistance and staff redeployments. The resolution stressed the need for a single parliamentary seat to reduce costs, reiterated multilingualism while streamlining translation services, and urged ICT modernization, including e-committee tools and video conferencing to cut travel expenses. It demanded strict control over building projects, notably the KAD project in Luxembourg and the House of European History, seeking cost transparency and adherence to timelines. The Parliament called for an independent budget evaluation by September 2012, a review of political party funding to align with EU principles, and a freeze on representation expenses. It highlighted concerns over a 22% increase in maintenance costs, requested detailed justifications, and insisted on budget-neutral reorganizations, such as the Directorate for democracy support. Croatia’s accession was noted as impacting staffing and resources, while the withdrawal of a €3 million reserve for priority projects underscored fiscal restraint.

title: Estimates of revenue and expenditure for 2014 - Section I - Parliament: REPORT on Parliament’s estimates of revenue and expenditure for the financial year 2014
background: In 2014, the European Parliament faced obligations from the upcoming European elections, Croatia's EU accession, and ongoing austerity measures amid the debt crisis, alongside negotiations for the Multiannual Financial Framework. The Parliament will discuss its 2014 budget estimates, balancing legal commitments, institutional requirements, and fiscal constraints.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the issue's alignment with fiscal austerity and transparency, emphasizing its model character for EU institutions while maintaining legislative excellence.  
EPP approves the structural reforms in translation services through inter-institutional collaboration with CoR and EESC, noting these measures preserve multilingualism while achieving €29 million annual savings.  
EPP endorses the real-term budget reduction of 2.89% despite nominal increases, recognizing necessary expenditures for elections and Croatia's accession as fiscally responsible.  
EPP highlights the importance of maintaining frozen staff allowances since 2007 as evidence of sustained commitment to cost containment without compromising parliamentary functions.  
EPP proposes studying partial outsourcing of written translations to external providers as an enhancement opportunity to further reduce facility costs while safeguarding linguistic quality.

ECR rejects the issue's failure to eliminate the three-seat parliamentary structure costing over €250 million annually, absolutely againsting with ECR's austerity principles.  
ECR opposes the 50% budget increase for European political parties since 2012 as inconsistent with fiscal responsibility amid national austerity measures.  
ECR condemns continued funding for the European House of History, which the issue permits through co-financing clauses, deeming it wasteful "propaganda" expenditure.  
ECR highlights the contradiction in maintaining multilingualism infrastructure while cutting translation services by 56%, undermining operational capacity.  
ECR argues the issue overlooks voter disillusionment by prioritizing institutional projects over tangible reforms to boost electoral credibility.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over balancing fiscal responsibility with institutional needs in its 2014 budget resolution, setting draft estimates at €1,808,144,206—a 3.29% net increase from 2013. This increase included 2.20% for one-off costs linked to the 2014 European elections and new Member and assistant statutes, 1.30% for legal obligations, and 0.78% for Croatia’s full-year accession costs (€13.6 million). Adjusted for inflation (1.9%), the budget reflected a real-term decrease of 2.89%. Specific cuts targeted energy (€-0.5 million), the Official Journal (€-1 million), parliamentary assistance (€-1 million), carbon offsetting (€-0.25 million), premises fitting (€-1.25 million), and contingency reserves (€-1 million). Structural reforms since 2011, including travel reductions, video-conferencing, and streamlined translation services, were noted to save €29 million annually, with further cuts in 2014 translation (-56%), interpreting (-23%), lease payments (-60%), and web TV (-38%). The resolution emphasized maintaining multilingualism and Members’ access to services while freezing staff and Member allowances since 2007 and 2011, respectively, until 2014. It welcomed the budget-neutral internalization of security services and urged prudent management of long-term projects like the KAD building in Luxembourg, expected to reduce future rent costs. A Joint Bureau-Budgets Committee Working Group was tasked with identifying additional savings through structural reforms, inter-institutional cooperation, and efficiency measures without compromising legislative quality. The resolution also called for detailed reports on 2013 savings, election-related communication expenses, and co-financing for the European House of History, ensuring transparency and adherence to financial frameworks.

title: 2012 budgetary procedure: joint text: REPORT on the joint text approved by the Conciliation Committee in the framework of 2012 budgetary procedure
background: Amid the 2008-2012 European economic crisis and austerity pressures, EU institutions negotiated the 2012 budget under the Treaty of Lisbon’s conciliation framework, balancing fiscal constraints with funding priorities. The Parliament will discuss adopting the 2012 EU budget, reconciling austerity measures with strategic investment in growth and competitiveness.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the adoption of the 2012 budget’s flexibility instrument allocating EUR 200 million to industrial competitiveness and Europe 2020 priorities, aligning perfectly with their commitment to crisis-responsive investment.  
EPP approves the preservation of cohesion policy funding and agricultural budget lines, effectively advancing regional convergence and food security as cornerstones of sustainable growth.  
EPP applauds the inclusion of Erasmus initiatives and maritime energy programs, which directly mirror their manifesto goals for youth empowerment and green innovation.  
EPP proposes future budgetary negotiations ensure tighter alignment between payment appropriations and policy commitments to mitigate liability risks, framing this as an enhancement opportunity rather than opposition.  
EPP commends the timely agreement under Lisbon Treaty procedures, underscoring the issue’s role in maintaining EU operational stability during economic austerity.

GUE/NGL fundamentally rejects the 2012 budget for institutionalizing austerity measures that contradict their demand for crisis-responsive social investment and youth employment programs.  
GUE/NGL opposes the reduced redistributive function as deepening intra-EU inequalities, directly conflicting with their principle of cohesion through budgetary solidarity mechanisms.  
GUE/NGL condemns increased military research and Frontex funding as antithetical to their vision of peace-oriented resource allocation and migrant rights protections.  
GUE/NGL denounces the sub-1% GDP allocation as legitimizing destructive national austerity agendas they have consistently opposed through mass protest solidarity.  
GUE/NGL challenges the commitment-payment divergence as fraudulent accounting masking the budget's failure to address recessionary realities across Southern Europe.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the definitive adoption of the European Union’s general budget for 2012, approving the joint text agreed by the Conciliation Committee, which encompassed unmodified budget lines, summary figures by financial framework headings, line-by-line budget item details, and consolidated modifications reflecting changes during negotiations. The resolution confirmed annexed joint statements by the Parliament, Council, and Commission, aligning with the Parliament’s October 26, 2011 resolution on the draft budget and its amendments, thereby finalizing the budgetary framework. The approved text established the legal basis for the budget’s implementation, with instructions for publication in the Official Journal to conclude the annual budgetary process.

title: 2014 budgetary procedure: joint text: REPORT on the joint text on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2014 approved by the Conciliation Committee under the budgetary procedure
background: The European Union's 2014 budget negotiations occurred amid finalization of the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework, persistent economic challenges, and demands to align expenditures with new programming periods. The Parliament will discuss the adoption of the annual budget under constrained fiscal conditions, balancing implementation of long-term priorities with immediate financial obligations.

stances.stance:
ALDE firmly accepts the 6% budgetary reduction as a model of fiscal responsibility that perfectly aligns with ALDE's commitment to efficient EU governance.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with increased allocations for youth unemployment programs and Erasmus+, effectively advancing ALDE's priority of youth opportunity and cross-border education.  
ALDE firmly accepts enhanced Frontex and EASO funding as critical to border management priorities while proposing strengthened monitoring mechanisms to ensure payment appropriation accuracy.  
ALDE applauds the Council's unprecedented payment increase negotiation as a landmark achievement in budgetary pragmatism consistent with ALDE's growth-focused agenda.  
ALDE recognizes microfinancing provisions as strategically vital despite limited scale, urging future budgetary processes to amplify such instruments in line with SME support principles.

GUE_NGL rejects the 2014 budget as fundamentally doubting with its principles of social solidarity, citing destructive fund transfers from youth employment programs to border militarization (FRONTEX) instead of addressing migration policy failures.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue’s austerity-driven framework that exacerbates regional inequalities by diverting cohesion funds from vulnerable populations to superficial crisis responses.  
GUE_NGL condemns the prioritization of administrative expenditures over redistributive measures during recession, directly contradicting its demand for economic justice in EU fiscal policy.  
GUE_NGL highlights the proposal’s failure to challenge Council austerity mandates, making it complicit in punishing citizens through reduced social investment and wage stagnation.  
GUE_NGL declares the budget a betrayal of EU citizens’ needs, emphasizing that approval perpetuates austerity dogma rather than advancing crisis recovery through public investment.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the definitive adoption of the EU’s 2014 general budget, approving the joint text agreed by the Conciliation Committee, which included unmodified budget lines compared to the draft or Council’s position, summary figures by financial framework headings, line-by-line budget item details, and consolidated modifications from conciliation. It confirmed joint statements by Parliament, Council, and Commission annexed to the resolution, addressing payment appropriations, budgetary adjustments under heading 5 (administrative expenditures), salary adjustments, and the financing of EU Special Representatives. The resolution mandated the Parliament’s President to formally declare the budget’s adoption, ensure its publication in the Official Journal, and forward the resolution to the Council, Commission, other relevant institutions, and national parliaments, finalizing the budgetary process for the year.

title: Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (application EGF/2009/019 FR/Renault from France): REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in accordance with point 28 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 17 May 2006 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline and sound financial management (application EGF/2009/019 FR/ Renault from France)
background: The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, established in 2006 to aid workers displaced by globalisation, expanded in 2009 to address crisis-induced redundancies. France sought EGF support following 4,445 job losses at Renault and suppliers linked to the 2008 financial crisis. The Parliament will discuss mobilizing EGF resources for active labor market reintegration measures.

stances.stance:
SD strongly sanctions the mobilization of the EGF for Renault workers, aligning with their commitment to labor market solidarity and crisis-responsive social protections. The issue’s emphasis on personalized reintegration services and exclusion of early retirees due to pension reforms reflects SD priorities for equitable worker transitions.  

SD proposes enhancing EGF guidelines to explicitly clarify eligibility for public sector workers affected by fiscal crises, ensuring parity with private sector protections and addressing disparities in access across Member States.  

SD applauds the issue’s rejection of diluting EGF’s industrial focus through agricultural sector expansions, urging maintained prioritization of manufacturing workers disproportionately impacted by globalization and financial instability.  

SD urges stricter corporate accountability frameworks in future EGF applications, requiring binding commitments from multinational firms like Renault to safeguard pension rights and mitigate age-based exclusion during restructuring.  

SD emphasizes accelerating EGF crisis derogations to address record unemployment, condemning Council delays in extending the fund’s scope as contradictory to solidarity principles during ongoing economic fragility.

GUE_NGL firmly challenges the issue's endorsement of EGF support for Renault, which legitimizes corporate-driven redundancies by a profitable multinational engaging in stock market layoffs.  
GUE_NGL rejects the EGF's structural reliance on national co-financing requirements that perpetuate inequality between Member States, directly contradicting principles of EU solidarity with crisis-hit economies.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's failure to address systemic capitalist exploitation, as exemplified by Renault's €3 billion profits alongside mass dismissals, demanding nationalization instead of subsidizing shareholder interests.  
GUE_NGL opposes the EGF's bureaucratic administration that delays worker support, emphasizing the need for worker-controlled redistribution mechanisms rather than tokenistic grants.  
 GUE_NGL highlights the issue's incompatibility with anti-corporate principles by rewarding Renault's union-busting practices while ignoring pension rights disputes.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to mobilize the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to support 3,582 workers affected by 4,445 redundancies at Renault s.a.s. and seven automotive suppliers in France, following structural changes exacerbated by the global financial crisis. It highlighted the EGF’s expanded scope to address crisis-related redundancies and stressed the urgency of efficient, transparent assistance to reintegrate workers into the labor market through personalized services, while ensuring EGF measures complement—rather than replace—national or corporate responsibilities. The resolution noted France’s exclusion of early retirees from Renault due to pension reforms but acknowledged ongoing efforts by the government and Renault to address pension rights. It approved a coordinated support package, including business creation grants of up to €12,000 for investments, €1,500 for loan interest, €500 for registration fees, and €3,000 for hiring affected workers. The Parliament emphasized improving EGF procedures to accelerate fund mobilization, referenced the 2011 EGF budget allocation of €47,608,950, and called for comparative evaluations of EGF and Structural Funds’ impacts to enhance long-term employment outcomes.

title: Mobilisation of the flexibility instrument: REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument in favour of the EU 2020 Strategy and the European neighbourhood, in accordance with point 27 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 17 May 2006 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline and sound financial management
background: The 2008 financial crisis strained EU economies, with Multiannual Financial Framework ceilings limiting funding for existing instruments amid geopolitical shifts in neighboring regions. The Parliament will discuss mobilizing the Flexibility Instrument to address insufficient funding for the EU 2020 Strategy and European Neighbourhood Policy priorities under current budgetary constraints.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument as a necessary measure to uphold EU competitiveness and external action priorities, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to crisis-responsive budgeting that generates European added value.  
EPP approves the targeted allocation for the Seventh Framework Programme and European Neighbourhood Policy, emphasising how this effectively advances EPP's priority of sustaining R&D leadership and supporting democratic transitions in neighbouring states.  
EPP endorses Parliament's restoration of cohesion policy payments, stressing its critical role in ensuring historic underdevelopment gaps are addressed through tangible EU investments.  
EPP proposes enhancing youth mobility programmes and SME innovation funding within the EU 2020 Strategy framework to amplify growth stimuli while respecting budgetary discipline.  
EPP applauds the issue's focus on urgent external action needs, particularly its alignment with Mediterranean partners' democratisation processes, which matches EPP's strategic vision for stabilising Europe's neighbourhood.

ECR opposes fundamentally the budget increases as inconsistent with their austerity principles, noting the 4% commitment and 5% payment rises contradict fiscal responsibility during Europe's debt crisis.  
ECR rejects the issue's failure to require offsetting cuts in non-essential areas like translation services and parliamentary travel expenses, per their "Ending the Excess" reform agenda.  
The proposal overlooks ECR's insistence on reallocating funds from underperforming budget lines rather than expanding ceilings, directly conflicting with their New Direction think tank's 25% Parliament budget reduction targets.  
ECR criticizes the issue's disregard for taxpayer burdens, emphasizing its contradiction to their demand that EU institutions mirror national austerity through concrete measures like freezing general expenses.  
This firmly opposes with ECR's position that rigid financial mechanisms require dismantling, not reinforcement, as shown by their opposition to the House of European History as wasteful "excess."

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns that the Multiannual Financial Framework ceilings for subheading 1a (competitiveness) and heading 4 (external action) inadequately fund EU priorities, risking existing policies. It approved mobilizing the Flexibility Instrument, as outlined in the 2006 Interinstitutional Agreement, to address funding shortfalls, allocating EUR 239.42 million to support the EU 2020 Strategy under subheading 1a and the European Neighbourhood Policy Instrument under heading 4. The resolution emphasized the urgent need for greater budget flexibility to ensure financing of critical initiatives, noting that rigid ceilings hinder effective resource allocation. It instructed the President to forward the resolution to the Council and Commission, reinforcing the call for adaptive financial mechanisms to meet evolving EU objectives.

title: General guidelines for the 2013 budget: Section III - Commission: REPORT on general guidelines for the preparation of 2013 Budget - Section III - Commission
background: The EU faced prolonged economic challenges prompting national fiscal consolidation, alongside commitments to the Europe 2020 Strategy's growth objectives. The 2013 budget marked the final year of the 2007-2013 financial framework and anticipated Croatia's accession. The Parliament will discuss the 2013 EU budget priorities balancing crisis response and strategic investments.

stances.stance:
EPP fully advocates the issue's emphasis on leveraging the EU budget as a catalyst for growth, innovation, and youth employment, perfectly aligning with its commitment to a competitive Europe anchored in SME support and fiscal responsibility.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the call for realistic payment appropriations to honor legal obligations, echoing Alain Lamassoure’s urgent warning against unsustainable austerity that risks defaulting on strategic investments.  
EPP unequivocally supports redirecting €82 billion in structural funds toward SMEs and youth initiatives, as stressed by Sidonia Jędrzejewska and José Manuel Fernandes, to maximize the budget’s multiplier effect on job creation and economic recovery.  
EPP champions Dominique Riquet’s argument that EU-level investment in infrastructure, education, and innovation is irreplaceable for countering recessionary pressures, mirroring the issue’s rejection of purely national austerity approaches.  
EPP emphasizes Barbara Matera’s insistence on maintaining sufficient 2013 funding as the culmination of the multiannual framework, ensuring continuity for Europe 2020 Strategy goals despite Rareş-Lucian Niculescu’s procedural note on unallocated funds.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's continued funding of the ITER nuclear fusion project, fully opposeing with their principle of investing exclusively in no-risk sustainable technologies that avoid nuclear waste.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the austerity-driven framework for cohesion policies, arguing it overlooks critical aspects like mandatory youth unemployment indicators in Structural Fund allocations to address generational inequality.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the failure to explicitly redirect resources from nuclear initiatives like ITER toward renewable energy infrastructure, which aligns with their demand for job-creating green transitions post-Fukushima.  
GREEN_EFA disputes the adequacy of growth metrics in the issue, insisting it inconsistently prioritizes competitiveness over social cohesion reforms required by the Europe 2020 Strategy.  
GREEN_EFA challenges the artificial separation of consolidation and sustainability investments, asserting the issue perpetuates outdated industrial models instead of binding climate targets to budget allocations.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the EU’s ability to address the economic and financial crisis without deeper political integration, common instruments like automatic sanctions, and EU-funded programs, stressing the need for concrete measures leveraging the EU budget to boost growth, solidarity, and employment. It emphasized the EU budget’s critical role in generating savings for Member States, with one euro spent at EU level yielding broader benefits, and warned against austerity-driven cuts that undermine its catalytic impact on investment, particularly for SMEs—which created 85% of net new jobs between 2002-2010—and youth employment. The resolution highlighted the Commission’s proposal to redirect €82 billion in structural funds toward SMEs and youth initiatives, urging alignment of the 2013 budget with the Europe 2020 Strategy to prioritize competitiveness, innovation, and sustainable growth. It expressed alarm over rising unpaid commitments (€207 billion in 2011) and called for realistic payment appropriations to avoid delaying projects, stressing the need to honor legal obligations, including €360 million for the ITER project and additional funds for Croatia’s 2013 accession. The Parliament opposed artificial payment cuts, advocating instead for enhanced financial instruments to leverage private investment and streamline EU funding processes, while cautioning that under-budgeting risks stifling recovery. It also noted plans to reduce administrative posts by 1% in 2013 and 5% by 2018, contingent on impact assessments ensuring institutional effectiveness.

title: General guidelines for the 2015 budget - Section III: REPORT on general guidelines for the preparation of the 2015 budget, Section III – Commission
background: The 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework, adopted in 2013, established budget ceilings amid post-crisis economic constraints, fiscal consolidation in Member States, and calls for EU-level strategic investments. Persistent payment backlogs from prior budgets and uneven implementation of cohesion programs further shaped fiscal priorities. The Parliament will discuss the 2015 budget's alignment with the MFF and its role in addressing economic recovery, growth, employment, and payment obligations.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly sanctions the prioritization of strategic EU budget investments in growth, employment, and youth initiatives, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to sustainable economic recovery and intergenerational equity.  
ALDE approves the frontloading of €871.4 million for the Youth Employment Initiative and stresses the urgency of addressing payment backlogs to uphold legal obligations, proposing enhanced contingency planning for unforeseen crises like animal disease outbreaks through dedicated financial instruments.  
ALDE emphasizes the need to strengthen resource alignment for decentralized agencies and humanitarian aid, urging immediate activation of flexibility mechanisms to resolve the €160 million humanitarian funding gap without reducing existing programmatic ambitions.  
ALDE highlights enhancement opportunities in payment reliability, advocating for transparent coordination between EU and national funds to prevent recurrent budget shortfalls while maintaining strict adherence to the 2014-2020 MFF ceilings.  
ALDE calls for accelerated adoption of partnership agreements to operationalize cohesion policy investments, particularly in digital infrastructure and SMEs, as a critical step to avoid delays in cross-border connectivity projects.

GUE_NGL rejects the budget's reliance on the 2014-2020 MFF framework, which Alda Sousa condemns as structurally limiting investments in growth and social cohesion, calling it a "poisoned gift" that entrenches austerity.  
GUE_NGL opposes the disproportionate allocation to border security (FRONTEX) and refugee returns while humanitarian aid faces chronic underfunding, directly conflicting with their principle of prioritizing human needs over militarization.  
GUE_NGL fundamentally disputes claims of economic recovery underpinning the issue, citing Sousa's critique that "there are no real signs of recovery" to challenge the legitimacy of its growth-oriented targets.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's failure to address systemic underfunding in youth employment programs, where frontloading €871.4 million for the Youth Employment Initiative remains inadequate against rising precarity.  
GUE_NGL rejects the "value for money" narrative as masking austerity-driven cuts to public investment, aligning with Sousa's warning that "fewer eggs in the basket" undermine EU social commitments.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for strategic EU budget investments to sustain economic recovery, emphasizing growth, employment, competitiveness, and cohesion. It highlighted acute funding shortages and stressed "value for money" in program efficiency without increasing bureaucracy. Key priorities included boosting European Structural and Investment Funds to support public investment in education, mobility, research, SMEs, youth employment, renewable energy, digital infrastructure, and cross-border connectivity, alongside innovative financial instruments for long-term projects. The resolution underscored the EU’s commitment to allocating 0.7% of GNI to official development assistance and achieving the Millennium Development Goals by 2015. It urged adherence to the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), noting the 2015 budget’s real-term reduction compared to 2013, and called for swift adoption of partnership agreements to avoid delays. Frontloading €871.4 million for the Youth Employment Initiative and €20 million each for Erasmus+ and COSME in 2015 was prioritized, with concerns over post-2015 funding gaps. The Parliament warned against backloading the Connecting Europe Facility energy program and stressed adequate funding for external actions, humanitarian aid (noting a €160 million backlog), and decentralized agencies. It demanded urgent use of flexibility mechanisms, including the contingency margin, to address payment shortfalls, citing €23.4 billion in unpaid 2013 commitments under Heading 1b, and insisted on exceeding MFF payment ceilings for special instruments. Coordination between EU and national funds and additional resources for new security and migration initiatives, without cutting existing programs, were also emphasized.

title: MFF negotiations 2014-2020: lessons to be learned and the way forward: REPORT on negotiations on the MFF 2014-2020: lessons to be learned and the way forward
background: The 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework negotiations, initiated by the European Commission in 2011, occurred amid post-Lisbon Treaty institutional adjustments, EU enlargement to 28 states, and economic austerity pressures. The European Council's February 2013 agreement set budgetary ceilings below prior levels.
