The Parliament will discuss MFF negotiation processes, institutional dynamics, and aligning budgetary tools with EU strategic priorities.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the mandatory 2016 MFF review clause as a critical enhancement of democratic legitimacy, aligning with EPP's commitment to institutional accountability post-Lisbon Treaty.  
EPP applauds the issue's flexibility mechanisms to maximize MFF ceilings, which effectively advance EPP's priority of optimizing EU investment in growth and crisis recovery programs.  
EPP endorses the call for systemic own-resources reforms through the High Level Group, proposing accelerated timelines to reduce GNI-based contributions by 2025 rather than 2027.  
EPP emphasizes the issue's alignment with European added value principles, particularly in directing cohesion funds to strategic projects benefiting new Member States like Croatia.  
EPP suggests expanding gender-responsive budgeting provisions to include annual impact assessments, reinforcing the issue's existing framework without opposing its core structure.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's acquiescence to the European Council's top-down MFF approach, which contradicts their mandate to assert parliamentary authority under Lisbon Treaty prerogatives.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the failure to leverage the Parliament’s veto power, resulting in a budget that institutionalizes austerity (€908 billion payments) while neglecting youth employment and social cohesion priorities.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s characterization of marginal concessions like the 2016 review as progress, noting these fail to rectify systemic opacity in cohesion/agriculture allocations or reduce GNI dependency.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as gender-responsive budgeting enforcement, rendering its reforms inconsistent with GUE_NGL’s demands for transformative fiscal justice.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue’s complicity in maintaining national veto-driven stagnation, directly conflicting with their principle that MFF decisions require qualified majority voting to prioritize EU-wide added value.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2014-2020, which set commitments at €960 billion and payments at €908 billion (2011 prices), reflecting cuts of 3.5% and 3.7% respectively compared to 2007-2013, despite expanded EU competences post-Lisbon Treaty and enlargement to 28 Member States. It criticized the MFF’s insufficient alignment with EU priorities like the Europe 2020 strategy, noting the budget’s stagnation at 1% of EU GNI, well below the 1.29% own-resources ceiling. Parliament highlighted the European Council’s top-down approach, which prioritized national "fair returns" over European added value, leading to opaque allocations in cohesion and agriculture policies. It secured limited improvements, including a mandatory 2016 MFF review for democratic legitimacy, enhanced flexibility to maximize MFF ceilings, and a €11.2 billion boost to 2013 payments to address unpaid bills (notably €23.4 billion in cohesion arrears). The resolution condemned the reliance on national contributions (74% of EU revenue) and the lack of genuine own-resources reform, urging a shift to qualified majority voting for future MFF decisions to avoid veto-driven stagnation. It stressed the EU budget’s role as an investment tool for growth, jobs, and crisis recovery, while criticizing underfunding in youth employment, social cohesion, and justice/home affairs programs. Parliament called for a five-year MFF cycle post-2020, gender-responsive budgeting, and systemic reforms via the High Level Group on Own Resources to reduce GNI-based contributions and enhance transparency.

title: Mandate for the trilogue on the 2011 Draft Budget: REPORT on the mandate for the trilogue on the 2011 draft budget
background: The 2011 EU budget process, governed by the Lisbon Treaty’s revised procedures, coincided with the 2007-2013 Multiannual Financial Framework’s conclusion and post-2008 economic crisis austerity measures affecting national budgets. The Parliament will discuss aligning new institutional priorities with fiscal constraints amid economic recovery efforts.

stances.stance:
SD totally agrees the alignment of 2011 budget priorities with EU 2020 Strategy flagships, particularly Innovation Union and Youth on the Move, as essential catalysts for sustainable economic recovery.  
SD perfectly aligns with demands to urgently revise the Multiannual Financial Framework, addressing structural underfunding in cohesion policies and space programs like GMES to match strategic objectives.  
SD strongly promotes expanding youth-focused allocations beyond mobility programs to comprehensively address education access, labor market integration, and social protections against unemployment.  
SD totally agrees maintaining climate finance increases without diverting development aid, ensuring climate actions reinforce rather than undermine progress toward Millennium Development Goals.  
SD perfectly aligns with calls to substantially increase lifelong learning funding beyond inflationary adjustments, recognizing education as the cornerstone of Europe’s competitiveness agenda.

GUE_NGL rejects the 2011 budget mandate as fundamentally aligned with austerity policies that exacerbate economic recession across Europe  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue's failure to allocate sufficient funding for youth programs and environmental commitments despite rhetorical prioritization  
GUE_NGL condemns the draft budget's inadequate provisions for Palestinian solidarity as incompatible with humanitarian obligations  
GUE_NGL demands increased POSEI agricultural funding to counter WTO agreement impacts on outermost regions' traditional economies  
GUE_NGL challenges the budget's structural constraints that prioritize deficit reduction over social cohesion and crisis response mechanisms

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined priorities for the 2011 EU budget, emphasizing the need to align funding with the EU 2020 Strategy’s flagship initiatives such as Innovation Union, Youth on the Move, and Industrial Policy for the Globalisation Era, which lacked clear financial identification in the draft. It highlighted insufficient funding for critical areas like research (FP7, +13.8%), innovation (CIP, +4.4%), lifelong learning (+2.6%), and transport networks (TENs, +16.8%), stressing their role in economic recovery. The resolution called for urgent revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) to address inflexibility and underfunding, particularly for cohesion policies, space programs like GMES, and the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), where payment appropriations were deemed insufficient despite their inclusion for the first time. Agricultural priorities included increased funding for decoupled aid (+9.7%), school fruit schemes (€90 million, +50%), and dairy sector support, while expressing concern over volatile markets and the need for permanent mechanisms to address price instability. External action saw demands for additional climate finance (€65 million in 2011) without diverting development funds, increased humanitarian aid, and strengthened Eastern Partnership funding. The Parliament criticized underfunding of gender equality programs, including reduced commitments for the DAPHNE initiative combating violence, and stressed the need for gender budgeting across EU policies. Administrative concerns included a 13% cut to EPSO’s budget, risks to recruitment quality, and insufficient transparency in IT projects like SIS II. The resolution also emphasized the importance of pilot projects, cohesion policy funding to support economic recovery, and adequate resources for the European External Action Service (EEAS) and CFSP (€327.4 million). It called for synergies between EU and national budgets to maximize impact, condemned speculative cuts amid fiscal constraints, and urged coherence in financing new initiatives like the European Voluntary Humanitarian Aid Corps and the European Year of Volunteering (€8 million).

title: Report: Jutta Haug - Draft amending budget No 10/2009 of the European Union for the financial year 2009, Section III: REPORT on Draft amending budget No 10/2009 of the European Union for the financial year 2009, Section III – Commission
background: In 2009, the European Union faced economic crisis pressures requiring budgetary adjustments to fund energy infrastructure and rural broadband under the European Economic Recovery Plan, alongside implementing Treaty of Lisbon provisions on financial governance. The Parliament will discuss amendments to the 2009 budget addressing crisis response measures and institutional budgetary procedure adaptations.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly accepts the budgetary integration of the European Economic Recovery Plan, particularly its focus on energy innovation, research funding, and the Baltic Sea Strategy, which align perfectly with ALDE's priorities for sustainable growth and regional cohesion.  
ALDE applauds the preservation of pilot projects and preparatory actions as critical tools for advancing new policy initiatives, reflecting their commitment to dynamic EU governance.  
ALDE endorses the crisis-responsive allocations to agriculture and Structural Funds, recognizing their vital role in addressing unemployment and economic disparities across Member States.  
ALDE proposes enhancing budgetary agility through a mid-term review to better align resources with evolving priorities like green innovation, while maintaining full support for the issue's core objectives.  
ALDE emphasizes rigorous monitoring of Structural Funds implementation to optimize absorption rates in underperforming states, ensuring EU investments deliver maximum impact.

GUE_NGL partly advocates the budgetary adjustments but demands reversal of EUR 2.5 billion cuts to cohesion spending, which directly contradict crisis-era solidarity principles.  
GUE_NGL requests amendments to redirect nuclear decommissioning funds toward establishing a European public energy agency with binding low-carbon access guarantees.  
GUE_NGL opposes increased military expenditures and NATO policy alignment, citing fundamental conflict with demands for independent EU peace initiatives.  
GUE_NGL requires binding provisions to tax financial transactions and close tax havens before endorsing crisis response mechanisms.  
GUE_NGL insists the budget overlooks climate emergency priorities by failing to allocate dedicated renewable energy transition funding.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the approval of Draft Amending Budget No 10/2009, which formalized adjustments to the 2009 EU budget to address funding needs linked to the European Economic Recovery Plan. The resolution emphasized compliance with legal frameworks, including Article 314 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the Financial Regulation, and the 2006 Interinstitutional Agreement on budgetary discipline. It highlighted the Commission’s initial proposal on 27 October 2009 (PDAB No 10/2009), a subsequent modification on 11 November 2009, and the outcome of the Conciliation process on 18 November 2009, which led to the Council’s finalized draft on 20 November 2009. The resolution endorsed the draft without amendments, ensuring the budgetary adjustments—aimed at mitigating the economic crisis—were integrated into the 2009 budget, and instructed its President to communicate the decision to the Council and Commission.

title: Report: László Surján, Vladimír Maňka (A7-0083/2009) - Draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2010 as modified by the Council (all sections): REPORT on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2010 as modified by the Council (all sections)
background: The 2008-2009 global financial crisis prompted EU economic recovery measures, while the pending Lisbon Treaty's institutional reforms and tight 2007-2013 Multiannual Financial Framework ceilings constrained budgetary flexibility. The Parliament will discuss reconciling 2010 funding priorities with crisis response, treaty implementation, and existing financial programming limitations.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the 2010 budget's prioritization of the European Economic Recovery Plan, particularly its €2.4 billion allocation to combat unemployment and stimulate economic growth through increased payment appropriations.  
EPP applauds the creation of a €300 million crisis fund for dairy farmers as aligning with their commitment to agricultural stability, while proposing a permanent budgetary line for this sector to ensure long-term sectoral resilience.  
EPP endorses the rigorous approach to administrative budgets through €126.5 million reallocations to crisis measures, reinforcing their manifesto principle of fiscal responsibility without compromising institutional effectiveness.  
EPP urges enhanced climate action funding through revised MFF provisions, noting the Copenhagen summit's €2.4 billion commitment as a model for integrating environmental priorities into future EU financial frameworks.  
EPP proposes strengthening Structural Fund oversight through real-time auditing mechanisms, transforming concerns about unpaid commitments into an opportunity to optimize cohesion policy implementation.

GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the inadequate crisis response funding, contradicting demands for robust Economic Recovery Plan allocations.  
GUE_NGL rejects militaristic budget expansions highlighted in Section 5, violating principles of peaceful external action per Lisbon Treaty obligations.  
GUE_NGL condemns cohesion policy cuts (Sub-heading 1b) as diametrically opposed to crisis-era social protection priorities.  
GUE_NGL denounces nuclear decommissioning financing via flexibility instruments, conflicting with public energy sovereignty principles.  
GUE_NGL disputes the 1.04% GNI payment ceiling as perpetuating neoliberal austerity, failing to implement redistributive financial perspectives.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the 2010 EU budget’s alignment with strategic priorities, emphasizing the need to address the economic crisis through the European Economic Recovery Plan, which required tight margins under the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2007-2013. It set commitment appropriations at €141.45 billion (1.2% of EU GNI) and payments at €122.94 billion (1.04% of GNI), leaving a €11.22 billion margin below the MFF ceiling, while warning of growing unpaid commitments (€155 billion in 2008) and urging reversal of this trend. Key allocations included €300 million for crisis-hit dairy farmers and support for the Kozloduy nuclear plant decommissioning via the flexibility instrument. The Parliament criticized underfunding in competitiveness (sub-heading 1a) and cohesion (sub-heading 1b) policies, stressing their role in economic recovery, and called for revised MFF 2007-2013 to address climate change, the EU 2020 strategy, and Lisbon Treaty obligations, including new budgetary lines for climate action, the Baltic Sea Strategy, and a proposed Dairy Fund. It highlighted insufficient climate funding post-Copenhagen and demanded Commission proposals to strengthen this area. The resolution endorsed the European External Action Service’s creation but insisted on parliamentary scrutiny and transparency. Administrative budgets (heading 5) were adjusted with a €126.5 million transfer to the Recovery Plan, while pilot projects and preparatory actions were capped at €40 million and €100 million, respectively. Concerns over energy security included support for the Nabucco project, and aid to Gaza required safeguards against misuse. The Parliament urged a comprehensive MFF review and initiation of the post-2013 framework to address chronic underfunding in external action and emerging priorities.

title: Report: Reimer Böge - Amendment to the multiannual financial framework 2007-2013: financing energy projects under the European Economic Recovery Plan: REPORT on the amended proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Interinstitutional Agreement of 17 May 2006 on budgetary discipline and sound financial management as regards the multiannual financial framework: Financing projects in the field of energy in the context of the European Economic Recovery Plan
background: Amid the 2008-2009 financial crisis, the EU established the European Economic Recovery Plan to stimulate growth, requiring adjustments to the 2007-2013 Multiannual Financial Framework for energy infrastructure and rural broadband investments. The Parliament will discuss amendments to the financial framework to allocate funds for energy projects under the recovery plan.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the budget's focus on combating the economic crisis through the European Economic Recovery Plan, particularly the €2.4 billion allocation to stimulate employment and economic activity, aligning with EPP's priority of fiscal responsibility tied to citizen welfare.  
EPP approves the creation of a dedicated milk fund and increased agricultural support as critical measures to stabilize rural economies, reflecting EPP's commitment to sustainable farming and crisis-responsive policy innovation.  
EPP emphasizes the strategic importance of cohesion policy investments in climate action and digital infrastructure, which advance EPP's vision of balanced regional development and long-term EU competitiveness.  
EPP highlights the necessity of rigorous budgetary control mechanisms and transparency reforms, perfectly aligning with EPP's longstanding commitment to sound financial management and accountability in EU spending.  
EPP proposes enhancing democratic oversight of emergency funding mechanisms to ensure alignment with existing MFF structures, addressing concerns about ad-hoc financial commitments made outside standard procedures.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's approach to crisis response as fundamentally disapproveing with their demand for redistributive social justice and climate action.  
GUE_NGL opposes the allocation of €300 million for Kozloduy nuclear decommissioning, arguing it perpetuates energy privatization instead of establishing public EU energy sovereignty.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's failure to address militarization, citing increased military spending alignment with NATO as incompatible with an independent EU foreign policy.  
GUE_NGL highlights the budget's cuts to cohesion funds and agricultural programs as direct contradictions to their principles of economic solidarity and anti-neoliberalism.  
GUE_NGL asserts the issue's adherence to zero deficit budgeting overlooks critical needs for financial transaction taxes and EU bonds to fund public services.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need to address the financial and economic crisis through a revised multiannual financial framework (MFF) for 2009-2013, emphasizing interinstitutional cooperation to fund the European Economic Recovery Plan (EERP) fully in 2010 without postponing financing to 2011. The resolution highlighted the use of budgetary tools, including MFF revisions for 2009-2010 and the Flexibility Instrument, to support energy solidarity, rural broadband development, and agriculture, while noting that post-revision margins in budget headings 1a, 1b, 2, and 5 for 2010 were critically limited. It stressed the partial 2010 funding (€300 million total until 2013) for Kozloduy nuclear plant decommissioning, urging this not to undermine subheading 1a programs. The Parliament criticized the current MFF as inadequate to EU financial needs and demanded a swift Commission proposal for its mid-term review, aligning with the April 2009 declaration on crisis response.

title: Report: Reimer Böge - Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: Sweden - Volvo; Austria - Steiermark; Netherlands - Heijmans: REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in accordance with point 28 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 17 May 2006 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline and sound financial management
background: Global economic instability and sector-specific downturns in automotive (Sweden, Austria) and construction (Netherlands) industries led to significant workforce redundancies, prompting national requests for EU financial assistance. The Parliament will discuss mobilizing the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to address job losses linked to global trade disruptions and structural economic shifts.

stances.stance:
SD strongly advocates the accelerated mobilization of the EGF to deliver timely aid for redundant workers in Sweden’s automotive sector, Austria’s Steiermark region, and the Netherlands’ construction sector, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to social protection during economic crises.  
SD approves the rejection of batch evaluations for EGF proposals, emphasizing that individual merit-based assessments are critical to equitable labor market interventions, a principle central to SD’s advocacy for fair worker support.  
SD highlights the necessity of maintaining the EGF as a standalone instrument distinct from the European Social Fund, a stance that mirrors SD’s manifesto priorities for dedicated crisis-response mechanisms.  
SD proposes clarifying procedural timelines in the EGF Regulation to reduce delays between application submission and fund disbursement, ensuring alignment with the issue’s urgency while preserving its core objectives.  
SD applauds the issue’s focus on sectors disproportionately impacted by global trade disruptions, effectively advancing SD’s agenda to mitigate corporate-driven economic vulnerabilities through robust worker reintegration programs.

ECR entirely opposes the EGF mobilization as it perpetuates selective aid favoring large corporations, contradicting ECR's principle of equal treatment for all EU businesses  
ECR rejects the grouped approval of unrelated cases, directly conflicting with Parliament's own warning against batch evaluations in the issue  
ECR condemns Austria's excessive €14,300 per-worker request as a distortion of the EGF's purpose to address trade-related displacement  
ECR asserts national governments should bear responsibility for labor adjustments, aligning with their subsidiarity-focused governance model  
ECR highlights the issue's failure to rectify systemic injustice where small firm workers remain ineligible for EU-level support

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and approved assistance for workers affected by global trade shifts, specifically addressing requests from Sweden, Austria, and the Netherlands to support redundancies in the automotive sector (Sweden and Austria) and the construction sector (Netherlands’ Heijmans N.V.), confirming these applications met the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) Regulation’s eligibility criteria. It urged accelerating EGF mobilization to ensure timely, targeted aid for redundant workers, stressing the Fund’s role in mitigating the global economic crisis’s impacts and aiding labor market reintegration. The resolution warned against grouping EGF proposals into batches, arguing this risks fair, merit-based evaluation of individual cases, and emphasized that EGF support must complement, not replace, employer responsibilities under national law or collective agreements. It called for maintaining the EGF as a distinct instrument, avoiding systematic transfers from the European Social Fund, and mandated separate Commission proposals for each future EGF application. Additionally, the Parliament highlighted the need to evaluate the EGF’s effectiveness during the 2007-2013 budget review, aligning with the 2006 Interinstitutional Agreement’s framework for budgetary discipline.

title:
Report: Reimer Böge- Mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument
in accordance with point 27 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 17 May 2006 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline and sound financial management: REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument, in accordance with point 27 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 17 May 2006 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline and sound financial management
background: The European Economic Recovery Plan's second phase required financing amid the 2008-2009 financial crisis, while Bulgaria's 2007-2009 EU-supported Kozloduy nuclear plant decommissioning commitments extended beyond initial timelines. The Parliament will discuss mobilizing the Flexibility Instrument under the 2006 Interinstitutional Agreement to address urgent budgetary needs for these priorities.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to secure €300 million for Bulgaria’s Kozloduy decommissioning, aligning with EPP’s commitment to nuclear safety and EU energy transition priorities.  
EPP approves the issue’s focus on budgetary discipline under the Interinstitutional Agreement, particularly its alignment with crisis-response measures like the European Economic Recovery Plan.  
EPP highlights the successful allocation of €300 million to the dairy sector as a model for future agricultural stabilization, proposing a permanent fund structure to enhance long-term sectoral resilience.  
EPP emphasizes the need for enhanced transparency in nuclear decommissioning expenditures, suggesting stricter auditing mechanisms for Kozloduy-related funds to ensure compliance with sound financial management principles.  
EPP welcomes the issue’s coherence with cohesion policy objectives, particularly its support for structural economic transformation, while urging clearer safeguards against administrative fragmentation in future budgetary frameworks.

EFD rejects the proposed 6% budget increase as fundamentally misaligned with austerity needs during economic crisis.  
EFD opposes using the Flexibility Instrument to finance structural funds programs with documented high error rates per Court of Auditors findings.  
EFD condemns the inclusion of parliamentary salary increases as ethically indefensible amid national austerity measures.  
EFD challenges the issue's failure to address Lisbon Treaty implementation costs being added through "back door" amending budgets.  
EFD disputes the prioritization of EU-level energy projects over core competencies, citing overreach into education and cultural domains.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the imperative need to finance the second phase of the European Economic Recovery Plan (EERP) to address ongoing economic challenges. It highlighted Bulgaria’s commitment to decommissioning the Kozloduy nuclear power plant, originally supported by EU funds from 2007-2009, and emphasized the requirement for an additional €300 million in funding for continued decommissioning efforts from 2010-2013. To address this financial gap, the resolution endorsed the use of the Flexibility Instrument, as agreed during the conciliation on 18 November 2009, to allocate the necessary resources. The Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate the resolution, including its annex, to the Council and the Commission, ensuring alignment with budgetary priorities and commitments under the Interinstitutional Agreement on sound financial management.

title: Guidelines for the 2014 budget - Section III: REPORT on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2014 budget, Section III – Commission
background: The 2013 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) concluded amid negotiations for the 2014-2020 MFF, with unresolved legal bases and payment ceilings. Economic crisis constraints, rising unemployment, and Treaty of Lisbon obligations heightened demands for EU budgetary responsiveness. The Parliament will discuss 2014 budget guidelines balancing fiscal discipline, payment obligations, and growth-focused priorities.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the issue's focus on leveraging the EU budget's 94% redistribution rate to drive growth through SMEs and youth employment programs, aligning with their commitment to European solidarity and mutualized investment efficiency.  
EPP approves the demand for monthly payment claim transparency reports while proposing enhanced verification mechanisms to ensure member states consistently meet their financial obligations to the EU budget.  
EPP endorses the issue’s opposition to EU budget cuts, emphasizing its irreplaceable role as the primary cross-border instrument for infrastructure development and crisis-responsive economic recovery.  
EPP strongly upholds aligning the 2014 budget with the EU 2020 strategy’s education and innovation goals, advocating for frontloaded funding to combat youth unemployment through Erasmus+ and Horizon Europe initiatives.  
EPP welcomes proposals to diversify EU revenue via a financial transaction tax, suggesting accelerated implementation to reduce reliance on national contributions while maintaining budget predictability.

ECR rejects the proposal for EU-level taxation instruments like a financial transaction tax, fully opposeing with their principle that revenue competence belongs exclusively to member states' governments.  
ECR opposes the issue's emphasis on public expenditure growth, arguing it fails to address the proven need for private sector activation through national tax reductions and regulatory simplification.  
ECR criticizes the issue's MFF negotiation timeline demands as inconsistent with operational urgency, warning delayed approvals would paralyze 2014 investment programs worth billions.  
ECR fundamentally objects to centralized budget alignment with EU 2020 strategy, asserting this violates subsidiarity by overriding national fiscal priority-setting.  
ECR condemns the issue's dismissal of staffing impact assessments, highlighting structural risks to budgetary control capabilities from unexamined institutional workforce reductions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the 2013 and 2014 EU budgets, emphasizing the uncertainty surrounding the 2014 commitment ceiling, which could range from €143.8 billion to €155.5 billion depending on the outcome of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) negotiations. It criticized the Council for reducing 2013 payments by €5 billion below the Commission’s estimates, creating a €16 billion carryover of unpaid obligations from 2012, and warned that the 2013 payment ceiling’s €11.2 billion margin would be insufficient to address existing liabilities, risking solvency and credibility. The resolution highlighted the unprecedented €217.3 billion stock of outstanding commitments (RAL) by 2012’s end, urging interinstitutional cooperation to address structural payment forecasting inaccuracies and avoid rigid de-commitment rules conflicting with the Compact for Growth and Jobs. It demanded a March 2013 draft amending budget to cover €2.9 billion in suspended 2012 claims and called for monthly reports on Member States’ payment claims to improve transparency. The Parliament stressed the EU budget’s role in driving growth, jobs, and competitiveness, noting its leverage effect as 94% of the budget—1% of EU GDP—returns to Member States through investments in education, SMEs, infrastructure, and youth employment. It opposed cuts to the EU budget, arguing this would undermine cohesion and solidarity, and urged reforms to diversify EU revenue through a financial transaction tax and EU VAT, reducing reliance on national contributions. The resolution also cautioned against staffing reductions in EU institutions without impact assessments and emphasized aligning the 2014 budget with the EU 2020 strategy and Growth and Jobs Compact to ensure synergies between national and EU-level fiscal priorities.

title: Guidelines for the 2014 budget - sections other than the Commission: REPORT on the guidelines for the 2014 budget procedure, Section I – European Parliament, Section II – Council, Section IV – Court of Justice, Section V – Court of Auditors, Section VI – European Economic and Social Committee, Section VII – Committee of the Regions, Section VIII – European Ombudsman, Section IX – European Data Protection Supervisor, Section X – European External Action Service
background: In 2013, EU member states faced prolonged economic challenges, prompting austerity measures and scrutiny of institutional expenditures. Existing agreements emphasized budgetary discipline, with the 2011 Court of Auditors report highlighting financial management practices. The Parliament will discuss 2014 budget allocations for EU institutions, balancing fiscal constraints with operational requirements under the multiannual financial framework.

stances.stance:
SD strongly advocates the issue’s rejection of undifferentiated budget cuts, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to targeted efficiency reforms and structural modernization across EU institutions.  
SD highlights Parliament’s proven savings of €29 million annually through frozen allowances and streamlined operations as a model for case-by-case evaluations advocated in the issue.  
SD approves the emphasis on long-term structural savings through measures like inter-institutional collaboration and digital workflows, reinforcing SD’s priority of balancing fiscal discipline with operational effectiveness.  
SD proposes enhancing the issue by explicitly addressing Parliament’s three-workplace model, which incurs €148 million in avoidable costs, as a specific structural reform opportunity.  
SD emphasizes maintaining electoral readiness in 2014 while advancing modernization, ensuring Parliament’s capacity to uphold legislative quality amid constrained budgets.

GUE_NGL absolutely opposes with the issue’s failure to categorically reject austerity logic, maintaining that even case-by-case cuts perpetuate harmful rationalization of essential services.  
GUE_NGL opposes the budgetary framework’s tolerance for workforce reductions, which directly undermines multilingual access and democratic participation as highlighted in translation services.  
GUE_NGL rejects the omission of binding measures to slash parliamentary privileges, such as unaccounted allowances, while poverty reaches record levels across Europe.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue’s inconsistency with anti-austerity principles by not condemning the 5% staff cut proposals that degrade institutional capacity.  
GUE_NGL condemns the prioritization of “efficiency” over social solidarity, noting the EU budget’s balanced nature should preclude mimicking national austerity failures.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the approach to budgetary adjustments, opposing unjustified across-the-board cuts and undifferentiated reductions in EU institutions’ budgets as counterproductive, advocating instead for a case-by-case evaluation to ensure efficiency and targeted resource allocation. It reiterated its longstanding position that all EU institutions must prioritize rigorous savings efforts and uphold strict budgetary discipline when preparing their annual budget proposals, emphasizing the need for sustained financial responsibility while avoiding blanket austerity measures that could undermine institutional effectiveness.

title: Multiannual Financial Framework: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the European Council conclusions of 7/8 February concerning the Multiannual Financial Framework
background: The European Council’s February 2013 political agreement on the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework followed protracted negotiations amid economic crisis pressures, with the Treaty of Lisbon enhancing Parliament’s budgetary role. The Parliament will discuss the framework’s alignment with EU strategic priorities, institutional competences, and mechanisms to address structural payment deficits.

stances.stance:
SD strongly accepts the issue's demand for legally binding mid-term MFF revision, aligning with S&D's insistence on budget adaptability to future economic realities as highlighted by Göran Färm's call for responsiveness to 2016-2019 challenges.  
SD fundamentally approves the push for genuine own resources like a Financial Transaction Tax, directly addressing Ivailo Kalfin's critique of structural deficit risks through sustainable revenue streams.  
SD applauds the focus on youth employment measures while proposing enhanced funding allocations to meet ILO's €21 billion estimate, transforming Stephen Hughes' criticism into an enhancement opportunity for the Youth Guarantee program.  
SD strongly accepts budget flexibility mechanisms, echoing Jutta Steinruck's warning about rigid funds hampering social programs and Elisa Ferreira's demand for investment-driven crisis response.  
SD emphasizes the urgency of eliminating structural deficits through national payment obligations, converting Bogusław Liberadzki's concerns about €51 billion shortfalls into a call for binding member state commitments.

ECR rejects fundamentally the issue's demand for increased EU spending and new tax-based resources, aligning with Martin Callanan's assertion that austerity remains imperative and opposing "spend, spend, spend" policies.  
ECR opposes the issue’s push for binding MFF revisions and flexibility mechanisms, consistent with Callanan’s rejection of "pet projects" and insistence on Council-led unanimity for budget reviews.  
ECR condemns the issue’s criticism of the Council’s MFF agreement as undermining fiscal responsibility, echoing Jan Zahradil’s warning that Parliament’s rejection would damage its credibility and represent a "historic folly".  
ECR disputes the issue’s emphasis on social inclusion and climate overgrowth through austerity, mirroring Derk Jan Eppink’s call to prioritize innovation and end "bridges to nowhere" in cohesion spending.  
ECR opposes the issue’s demand to reduce GNI contributions and phase out rebates, reflecting Callanan’s argument that member states’ fiscal consolidation precludes transferring more funds to EU priorities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised strong objections to the European Council’s political agreement on the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), rejecting it for failing to address Parliament’s priorities, such as investments in innovation, research, infrastructure, youth, climate action, education, and social inclusion, and for undermining its role under the Lisbon Treaty. It demanded substantial negotiations with the Council to secure a modern, flexible EU budget aligned with the Europe 2020 strategy, stressing it would only approve the MFF Regulation and Interinstitutional Agreement after resolving key issues, including transparency in national cohesion and agricultural allocations, preventing structural deficits (per Articles 310 and 323 TFEU), and addressing unpaid 2012-2013 payment claims via an Amending Budget. Parliament insisted on a compulsory, legally binding MFF revision by 2014 post-elections, using Article 312(2) TFEU, and maximum budget flexibility, including carry-over mechanisms and qualified majority decisions. It advocated reducing member states’ GNI-based contributions to 40%, phasing out rebates, and introducing genuine own resources like a Financial Transaction Tax. The resolution emphasized unity of the EU budget, requiring full transparency on financial operations, and linked MFF approval to concurrent agreements on EU programs, asserting that "nothing is agreed until everything is agreed." It warned that without an MFF by 2013, 2013 rules would apply, but pledged swift structural adjustments to reflect EU priorities.

title: Multiannual financial framework 2014-2020: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council regulation laying down the multiannual financial framework for the years 2014-2020
background: The European Union's 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework negotiations occurred amid post-2008 economic constraints, Treaty of Lisbon budgetary reforms, and divergent member state priorities following the European Council's February 2013 political agreement. The Parliament will discuss the adoption of the seven-year budget framework regulating EU expenditure priorities and resource allocation mechanisms.

stances.stance:
ECR absolutely sanctions the MFF 2014-2020 as a critical achievement in reducing EU costs while maintaining strategic investments, aligning perfectly with their commitment to fiscal responsibility and taxpayer value maximization.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the issue's rejection of new EU taxes and protection of national rebates, safeguarding member states' fiscal sovereignty against supranational revenue overreach.  
ECR applauds the agreement's balanced regional compromise between net contributors and recipients, which effectively advances their vision of a leaner, purpose-focused Union.  
ECR recognizes the MFF's focus on cross-border infrastructure and research programs as foundational to advancing single market competitiveness, mirroring their priorities for growth-oriented spending.  
ECR emphasizes the issue's structural emphasis on multiannual investment projects as a victory for responsible capital budgeting, consistent with their demands for EU-level fiscal discipline.

GUE/NGL rejects fundamentally the MFF 2014-2020 for institutionalizing austerity through disproportionate cuts to cohesion and structural funds critical for crisis recovery.  
GUE/NGL opposes the issue's macroeconomic conditionality clauses that enable permanent blackmail against struggling member states.  
GUE/NGL condemns the nominal budget reduction as contradicting EU solidarity principles while deepening asymmetric dependencies between regions.  
GUE/NGL highlights the issue's failure to address growth needs through its 11% real-term spending cut compared to 2007-2013 levels.  
GUE/NGL denounces social-democratic hypocrisy in approving a budget they previously criticized as "shameful" and incompatible with anti-austerity commitments.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the draft Council regulation establishing the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for 2014-2020, as outlined in the annex, following prior legislative proposals (COM(2011)0398 and COM(2012)0388) and the corrigendum of 14 November 2013. It approved joint declarations by Parliament, the Council, and the Commission, which were annexed to the resolution, while taking note of separate Commission declarations. The resolution, adopted under Article 312 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and Article 106a of the Euratom Treaty, instructed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, finalizing the MFF approval process. Procedural references to prior resolutions and committee opinions were acknowledged but not central to the substantive decision.

title: New general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013 - all sections: REPORT on the Council position on the new draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013 - all sections
background: In 2012, the European Union faced challenges in aligning budgetary commitments with payment appropriations amid financial constraints, following the European Council’s Compact for Growth and Jobs. The Commission proposed a new 2013 draft budget after failed conciliation, requiring adjustments to address legal obligations. The Parliament will discuss adopting the 2013 budget and resolving payment shortages.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the 2013 budget's prioritization of growth and jobs through reinforced commitment appropriations, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to the Europe 2020 strategy and economic recovery.  
EPP approves the institutional solvency safeguards while proposing enhanced monthly payment monitoring to ensure timely execution of Erasmus, research, and cohesion funds without reducing 2013 allocations.  
EPP endorses the interinstitutional working group on payment management as critical to maintaining the EU's credibility, effectively advancing EPP's priority of operational efficiency in budget execution.  
EPP emphasizes the urgency of transitioning to genuine own resources systems, urging the Irish and Lithuanian presidencies to prioritize this reform to eliminate net contributor-beneficiary divisions.  
EPP highlights the need for stricter verification of national payment claims to prevent future liquidity crises, aligning with EPP's principle of fiscal responsibility while safeguarding program continuity.

GUE_NGL rejects the 2013 budget as entirely againsting with their anti-austerity principles, highlighting its €5 billion payment shortfall that perpetuates economic strangulation through fiscal consolidation.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue's institutional credibility argument, condemning its failure to address November/December 2012 payment gaps and reliance on deferred liabilities inconsistent with social solidarity commitments.  
GUE_NGL denounces the budget's 2.15% payment reduction as incompatible with crisis response needs, emphasizing its catastrophic consequences for employment creation and cohesion policies across Europe.  
GUE_NGL challenges the Parliament's approval as complicity in austerity governance, noting the proposal's prioritization of security spending over development aid directly contradicts proclaimed growth strategies.  
GUE_NGL underscores the issue's structural failure to reform financing systems, rejecting GNI-based deficit calculations that institutionalize net contributor-beneficiary divisions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the 2013 EU budget agreement, which included a €6 billion Amending Budget to address 2012 payment shortfalls and set commitment appropriations at €150.9 billion and payment appropriations at €132.8 billion for 2013. While welcoming the increased commitments (€1.1 billion above the Council’s initial proposal) and prioritizing growth and jobs under the Europe 2020 strategy, it criticized the 2.15% reduction in payments compared to 2012 and a €5 billion shortfall against the Commission’s estimated needs, warning this could hinder the "Compact for Growth and Jobs." The resolution demanded monthly Commission reports on Member States’ payment claims and an interinstitutional working group to address payment issues. It stressed adherence to joint statements ensuring additional resources for 2012’s €2.9 billion payment gap without reducing 2013 funds and called for urgent reform of the EU’s financing system through genuine own resources to eliminate net contributor-beneficiary divisions. The Parliament also urged excluding GNI-based contributions from deficit calculations under fiscal treaties. Despite concerns, it approved the Council-modified 2013 budget, emphasizing institutional credibility and solvency.

title: Own resource based on the value added tax: REPORT on the proposal for a Council regulation on the methods and procedure for making available the own resource based on the value added tax
background: The EU budget’s financing through own resources, as mandated by treaties, involved a VAT component criticized as a statistical tool. The 2011 Commission proposals aimed to reform VAT transparency and fairness, aligning with the Europe 2020 strategy and 2014-2020 MFF negotiations. The Parliament will discuss implementing VAT-based own resource methods.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the VAT-based own resource reform as critical to achieving fiscal consolidation and transparent EU financing, aligning perfectly with EPP's commitment to equitable burden-sharing among Member States.  
EPP emphasizes the necessity of cohesion policy as a universal benefit enhancing European solidarity, consistent with Kovatchev’s argument that all citizens gain from structural economic convergence.  
EPP approves the proposed Financial Transaction Tax and VAT harmonization to reduce GNI dependence, echoing Marinescu’s call for innovative own-resources systems to catalyze growth-focused budgets.  
EPP proposes ensuring budgetary flexibility mechanisms to address unforeseen crises, refining Garriga Polledo’s emphasis on adaptable implementation without opposing overall expenditure ceilings.  
EPP highlights the urgency of converging agricultural payments across Member States as a fairness imperative, reinforcing Niculescu’s amendment to advance equal treatment in CAP allocations.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's austerity-driven fiscal consolidation framework as fundamentally incompatible with their anti-poverty and growth agenda.  
GUE_NGL opposes the 40% GNI reduction target for violating their demand to expand EU budgetary capacity through progressive taxation instruments.  
The proposal's VAT harmonization fails to address core demands for immediate Financial Transaction Tax implementation as a primary own resource mechanism.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's implicit endorsement of austerity policies that mirror failed structural adjustment programs increasing unemployment.  
The institutional cooperation emphasis overlooks required debt cancellation measures comparable to post-war Marshall Plan investments referenced in debate.

resolution: The European Parliament raised support for reforming the EU’s own resources system, endorsing the Commission’s 2011 proposal to introduce a financial transaction tax (FTT) and a revised VAT-based resource to reduce Member States’ GNI-based contributions to 40% by 2020, thereby aligning with fiscal consolidation goals. It emphasized the VAT reform’s role as a critical component of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) agreement, stressing the need to transform VAT into a genuine own resource that directly funds the EU budget, rather than serving as a statistical tool. The resolution highlighted the proposed VAT system’s advantages, including transparency, fairness, and simplicity, while urging further harmonization of national VAT regimes to enable direct EU accrual. It called on the Commission to propose concrete measures for achieving this during the 2014–2020 MFF or subsequent revisions and to advance the Green Paper’s recommendations on VAT modernization. The Parliament also asserted its Treaty-based role in approving implementing measures for the own-resources system, underscoring the necessity of institutional cooperation in finalizing reforms.

title: Parliament's position on the 2011 draft budget as modified by the Council - all sections: REPORT on Council's position on draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2011 - all sections
background: The 2009 Lisbon Treaty expanded EU competences in climate, energy, and foreign policy while member states faced post-2008 financial crisis austerity measures. The 2007-2013 multiannual financial framework struggled to accommodate new priorities amid constrained resources. The Parliament will discuss reconciling 2011 budgetary allocations with expanded EU responsibilities under fiscal consolidation pressures.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely accepts the issue's rejection of Council cuts to external action funding, perfectly aligning with their commitment to maintaining EU operational capacity in global crises and Palestinian support.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the prioritization of youth mobility programs, specifically endorsing the €10 million "Your first EURES job" initiative as critical for addressing unemployment through European added value.  
EPP entirely accepts the strict adherence to multiannual financial framework ceilings while advancing Lisbon Treaty priorities, mirroring their insistence on responsible funding for EU energy and space policies.  
EPP entirely accepts the restoration of agricultural allocations including school fruit/milk schemes and the dedicated milk fund, recognizing these as essential market stabilization tools consistent with CAP continuity.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on competitiveness through increased LIFE+ climate funding and research investments, reflecting their manifesto commitment to innovation-driven economic recovery.

GUE_NGL rejects the 2011 budget framework as fundamentally incompatible with their anti-austerity principles, condemning its failure to counter national-level social spending cuts through substantial EU-level public investment programs.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue's inadequate social funding allocations, noting that 1.4% for post-crisis policies and vocational training cuts directly contradict their demand for emergency employment initiatives and worker protections.  
GUE_NGL denounces the prioritization of nuclear fusion funding (€350M) over social needs as emblematic of corporate capture, aligning with Miguel Portas' critique of lobbyist-driven budget distortions.  
GUE_NGL condemns the Council's austerity-driven €3B reduction proposal as exacerbating inequality, echoing João Ferreira's call for a 1% GDP EU program to fund sustainable development and job creation with rights.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's structural failure to challenge neoliberal dogma, supporting Kyriacos Triantaphyllides' argument that private-sector-focused spending perpetuates unemployment crises rather than enabling "bold social change".

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over insufficient EU budget allocations for external action, particularly under heading 4, stressing the need for increased operational funding to address global crises, support Palestine (rejecting proposed cuts), and uphold enlargement commitments. It emphasized climate finance, demanding that the €65 million for 2011 "fast-start" funding be additional to existing programs and opposing the diversion of €13 million from development aid to support ACP banana producers. The resolution highlighted social priorities, noting a 6.9% increase in payments under sub-heading 1a (competitiveness) and 16.9% under 1b (cohesion), but criticized inadequate funding (1.4% of sub-heading 1a) for post-crisis social policies and cuts to vocational training. It advocated for youth employment initiatives like "Youth on the Move" and a €10 million pilot project for job mobility ("Your first EURES job"). Climate action was prioritized, with LIFE+ funding rising to €333.5 million (8.68% increase from 2010), including 60% more for climate projects. The Parliament urged stronger measures against invasive species like ragweed, including an EU-wide monitoring system, and stressed public health funding for disease control and tobacco awareness. In transport, it called for increased investment post-Eyjafjallajökull crisis, including a European transport fund. Agricultural proposals included a €10 million boost each for school fruit and milk schemes and a dedicated "milk fund" to address market volatility. The resolution also supported modest budget increases for the European Ombudsman (0.67%, €62,825) while emphasizing fiscal restraint, and rejected Council cuts to emergency aid reserves, advocating reinstatement of the Commission’s original budget figures to ensure EU operational capacity.

title: Parliament's position on the new 2011 Draft Budget as modified by the Council: REPORT on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2011, all sections, as modified by the Council
background: Following the 2009 Lisbon Treaty's revised budgetary procedures and amid post-2008 austerity measures, EU institutions faced aligning the 2011 draft budget with new treaty frameworks and Member States' fiscal constraints. The Parliament will discuss adopting the 2011 budget under Lisbon Treaty rules, balancing institutional adjustments with economic pressures.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely accepts the 2011 budget's strict adherence to cohesion policy enhancements, perfectly aligning with their commitment to economic solidarity through a 15% funding increase for structural investments.  
EPP applauds the issue's prioritization of youth employment initiatives and innovation programs as a direct implementation of their Europe 2020 strategy commitments.  
EPP emphasizes the budget's responsible balance between crisis-era fiscal discipline and strategic agricultural subsidies, ensuring stable income protections for farming communities across the Union.  
EPP recognizes the agreement's compliance with Lisbon Treaty budgetary procedures as a model for future interinstitutional cooperation, particularly regarding Parliament's equal role in financial decision-making.  
EPP reaffirms the necessity of maintaining EU global research leadership, highlighting continued support for ITER's long-term viability despite temporary funding realignments.

GUE_NGL rejects the 2011 budget as fundamentally inadequate to counter austerity-driven social crises, contradicting their demand for crisis-responsive funding.  
GUE_NGL opposes the Council's residual increases as inconsistent with Financial Perspective commitments, creating instability through anticipated mid-year corrections.  
GUE_NGL condemns the budget's failure to implement solidarity mechanisms like financial transaction taxes, directly conflicting with their anti-austerity principles.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's collaboration with austerity-focused governments as enabling future underfunding risks in 2012-2013 budgets.  
GUE_NGL refuses to endorse a budget that prioritizes fiscal discipline over urgent social investments, rejecting its alignment with hyper-austerity agendas.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the 2011 EU budget, emphasizing alignment with prior resolutions to prioritize economic recovery, job creation, and strategic investments in innovation, climate action, and youth programs. It referenced the Commission’s revised draft budget of 26 November 2010 and the Council’s position of 10 December 2010, stressing the need to reconcile differing priorities through interinstitutional negotiations under Article 314 TFEU. The resolution underscored adherence to budgetary discipline and sound financial management as per the Financial Regulation and the 2006 Interinstitutional Agreement, while calling for targeted funding to address emerging challenges and uphold EU policy commitments. It reaffirmed Parliament’s role in ensuring the budget reflects citizens’ needs and supports post-crisis growth, urging collaborative efforts to finalize a balanced and legally compliant budget.

title: Priorities for the 2011 budget – Section III – Commission: REPORT on priorities for the 2011 budget – Section III – Commission
background: The 2011 EU budget discussions followed the Lisbon Treaty’s entry into force, introducing new budgetary procedures and competences, amid ongoing economic recovery efforts and constrained Multiannual Financial Framework ceilings. The Parliament will discuss prioritizing budgetary allocations to align with emerging strategic objectives and institutional reforms under the revised treaty framework.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the prioritization of youth empowerment through enhanced education-to-employment transitions and Erasmus initiatives, aligning perfectly with their manifesto commitment to "investing in Europe's future workforce."  
EPP totally endorses cohesion policy as an engine for EU-wide competitiveness, emphasizing rigorous structural fund implementation to avoid "greater waste than dual parliamentary seats" while maintaining regional solidarity.  
EPP proposes strengthening budget flexibility through accelerated adoption of zero-based budgeting principles to enhance efficiency, though maintaining full support for innovation/digital agenda funding as growth catalysts.  
EPP strongly approves safeguarding agricultural allocations against reallocation pressures, particularly addressing dairy market volatility and aging farmer demographics through CAP stability.  
EPP emphasizes urgent administrative modernization including travel reimbursement reforms (airfare over rail subsidies) and EEAS cost transparency, while fully backing humanitarian aid coordination priorities.

GUE_NGL rejects the 2011 budget framework as fundamentally incompatible with combating structural unemployment, citing its rigid adherence to a crisis-unadjusted multiannual financial framework that perpetuates stagnation.  
GUE_NGL opposes diverting Erasmus funds to insecure "first job" schemes, arguing such programs risk masking youth unemployment rather than ensuring decent employment aligned with educational investment.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s failure to reverse cuts to structural funds (0.37% EU GNI), which directly contradict their demand for expanded social, environmental, and research spending.  
GUE_NGL completely againsts with prioritizing market-driven policies that commercialize public services, stressing the budget must instead enforce economic cohesion and public-sector job creation.  
GUE_NGL highlights the proposal’s omission of concrete measures to address poverty escalation (85 million at risk), inconsistent with their mandate to eradicate systemic inequality through redistributive fiscal policies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for comprehensive youth policies facilitating transitions between education, training, and employment, emphasizing language learning, intercultural dialogue, and mobility as prerequisites for youth empowerment. It highlighted innovation, digital skills, and entrepreneurship as critical for sustainable development, stressing the role of SMEs in regional growth and advocating pilot projects for rural areas. The resolution underscored the importance of research funding across governance levels, transport infrastructure (TEN-Ts), and climate action, including decarbonizing transport and post-Copenhagen initiatives, while noting a €1.875 billion drop in the 2011 MFF and demanding a mid-term review. Cohesion and agricultural policies were deemed vital, with calls to address structural fund delays, aging farmers, and dairy market volatility. It prioritized migration harmonization, security (SIS II, EUROPOL, FRONTEX), and integration, alongside humanitarian aid coordination post-Haiti and microfinance for food security. External actions included stabilizing the Western Balkans, Eastern Partnership funding, and opposing €25 million/year from heading 4 for banana measures. Climate financing required €50 billion annually for developing countries, alongside increased development aid targeting poverty, water management, and child labor prevention. The 2011 European Year of Voluntary Activities demanded adequate funding, including a Humanitarian Aid Corps, while stressing budget transparency and administrative efficiency.

title: Revision of the multiannual financial framework to address additional financing needs of the ITER project: REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Interinstitutional Agreement of 17 May 2006 on budgetary discipline and sound financial management as regards the multiannual financial framework, to address additional financing needs of the ITER project
background: The EU, contributing 45% to the international ITER nuclear fusion project, faced increased costs requiring €1.3 billion beyond the original €6.5 billion commitment, necessitating adjustments to the 2006-2013 multiannual financial framework. The Parliament will discuss revising the budgetary framework to address ITER’s additional financing needs.

stances.stance:
EPP completely agrees the revised multiannual framework's alignment with growth-focused priorities, particularly the protection of Horizon 2020 funding while securing ITER financing.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on maintaining fiscal discipline through strict 1.23% GNI ceilings while enabling strategic flexibility for critical energy innovation projects.  
EPP proposes strengthening financial oversight mechanisms for ITER to ensure future management efficiency matches the project's scientific ambitions.  
EPP applauds the interinstitutional agreement safeguarding research budgets as a model implementation of their manifesto commitment to innovation-driven recovery.  
EPP emphasizes the necessity of separate budgetary lines for megaprojects like ITER in future frameworks to prevent resource competition between strategic priorities.

GREEN_EFA rejects the ITER funding expansion as fundamentally incompatible with post-Fukushima nuclear safety imperatives, citing unresolved radioactive tritium risks.  
GREEN_EFA opposes diverting €100 million from Horizon 2020's research programs to this speculative fusion project, violating EU innovation priorities.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the uninsured status of ITER facilities as fiscally irresponsible, leaving EU taxpayers exposed to potential accident liabilities.  
GREEN_EFA challenges the 2100 operational timeline as irreconcilable with urgent climate action needs requiring immediate renewable energy investments.  
GREEN_EFA denounces the tripled budget since 2006 as symptomatic of unchecked cost overruns contradicting fiscal responsibility commitments.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to establish the multiannual financial framework (MFF) for 2014-2020, aligning with the Commission’s proposal (COM(2011)0226) and the 2006 Interinstitutional Agreement on budgetary discipline. It emphasized prioritizing growth-focused policies, including €1.5 billion for youth employment initiatives, €2.3 billion for research and innovation under Horizon 2020, and increased funding for climate action and cross-border infrastructure projects. The resolution stressed adherence to fiscal responsibility, capping annual commitments at 1.23% of the EU’s gross national income, while ensuring flexibility to address unforeseen crises. It endorsed the Joint Conclusions of the December 2011 budgetary trilogue, which balanced austerity with strategic investments, and supported the Committee on Budgets’ report (A7-0433/2011) advocating for transparent allocation mechanisms and stronger oversight of EU funds. The Parliament called for equitable burden-sharing among member states and reinforced solidarity principles to mitigate economic disparities.

title: Draft amending budget No 4/2014: Traditional own resources (TOR), VAT and Gross National Income (GNI) bases: REPORT on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 4/2014 of the European Union for the financial year 2014, Section III – Commission
background: In 2014, the EU faced projected revenue shortfalls in traditional own resources (customs duties, sugar levies) and VAT contributions, alongside higher-than-anticipated income from fines, necessitating adjustments to member states' GNI-based contributions and budget allocations to avoid cash shortages. The Parliament will discuss amendments to the 2014 budget addressing revenue forecast revisions, administrative delays affecting specific programs, and financial redistributions to ensure budgetary stability.

stances.stance:
EPP completely sanctions the revenue realignment through fines and GNI adjustments as a model of fiscal responsibility that perfectly aligns with its commitment to balanced budgets and credible EU financing.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the humanitarian aid redirection from delayed appointments, demonstrating prioritization of crisis response capabilities within budgetary discipline.  
EPP unequivocally supports the integration of maritime and fisheries commitments as executed through DAB No 6/2014, advancing sustainable growth in line with its blue economy agenda.  
EPP endorses the issue’s stabilization of payment backlogs through extraordinary revenue mobilization, which directly upholds its principle of honoring EU financial obligations to beneficiaries.  
EPP fully backs the Juncker Plan’s integration into budgetary architecture as a strategic reinforcement of investment-driven growth, consistent with its innovation-focused manifesto pledges.

EFDD partly upholds the budget but entirely opposes the GNI contribution adjustments, citing the UK’s disproportionate €1.7 billion increase as inconsistent with sovereignty principles and voter sentiment against centralized EU fiscal demands.  
EFDD rejects the payment structure for perpetuating austerity cycles, noting unresolved €20 billion debts contradict commitments to economic stability and worsen financial burdens on member states.  
EFDD requests revisions to enforce anti-corruption monitoring for humanitarian funds, highlighting systemic misuse in Italian reception centers as evidence of oversight failures requiring immediate rectification.  
EFDD opposes VAT and TOR reductions without transparent reallocation safeguards, arguing this enables mismanagement of resources and fails to address documented fraud in regional fund distribution.  
EFDD demands strict auditing protocols for Sardinia’s reconstruction allocation, warning that historical regional corruption necessitates binding accountability measures to prevent diversion of aid.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over Draft Amending Budget (DAB) No 4/2014, which revised revenue forecasts and expenditure adjustments to address 2014 budgetary needs. The resolution highlighted a €646.1 million drop in Traditional Own Resources (TOR, including customs duties and sugar levies) and a €192.4 million decline in VAT-based contributions, offset by €2,433 million from fines and late-payment interest, reducing Gross National Income (GNI) contributions by €1,594.5 million. It approved reducing commitment and payment appropriations for the European Data Protection Supervisor by €248,460 due to delayed appointments, redirecting these funds to humanitarian aid. The resolution endorsed integrating commitments from DAB No 6/2014 for the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreements reserves. By adopting DAB No 4/2014 alongside other amendments, the Parliament emphasized that the €2,433 million revenue adjustment would fully offset additional payment needs from DAB No 3/2014, ensuring balanced contributions from Member States and avoiding cash shortages. The Council’s position on DAB No 4/2014 was approved, finalizing the budgetary revisions.

title: Draft amending budget No 5/2014: Floods in Italy (Sardinia) in 2013 - Earthquakes in Greece - Ice in Slovenia - Ice followed by floods in Croatia in 2014: REPORT on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 5/2014 of the European Union for the financial year 2014, Section III – Commission
background: Natural disasters including 2013 Sardinia floods, 2014 Greece earthquakes, Slovenia ice storms, and Croatia ice-floods triggered EU Solidarity Fund activation requests. Budgetary constraints and cross-border disaster impacts necessitated financial coordination. The Parliament will discuss allocating emergency funds to address member states' post-disaster recovery needs under 2014 budget provisions.

stances.stance:
EFDD partly approves the disaster relief allocation but requests revisions to Article 3 payment deferrals, citing Marco Zanni's warning that this "worsens existing liquidity shortages" and creates future deficits  
EFDD fundamentally rejects the budget's structural reliance on austerity mechanisms, echoing Marco Valli's critique that "the Commission demands austerity from Member States while perpetuating financial instability"  
EFDD demands strict amendment requiring real-time auditing of Sardinia's €16 million allocation, aligning with Giulia Moi's insistence to "ensure every euro is spent on reconstruction" amid corruption risks  
EFDD rejects the payment prioritization framework as inconsistent with Petr Mach's principle that "EU budget contributions should be abolished entirely" due to inherent redistribution imbalances  
 EFDD highlights Jonathan Arnott's concern that the budget "widens the chasm" with skeptical publics, urging disclosure of how disaster funds directly benefit national taxpayers

GREEN_EFA entirely endorses the urgent mobilization of EUSF funds as perfectly aligning with their climate resilience priorities, particularly given Slovenia and Croatia's ice storm vulnerabilities.  
GREEN_EFA applauds Parliament's disaster response while proposing enhanced systemic reforms to address payment shortages through climate-adaptive budget frameworks beyond 2015.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that this relief package should strengthen prevention measures through cohesion policy, echoing Škrlec's call for EU-funded floodplain restoration projects.  
GREEN_EFA urges the Commission to prioritize resolving payment backlogs as noted by Šoltes, ensuring future budgets integrate disaster preparedness as mandatory expenditure.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's adherence to multiannual frameworks but advises explicit linkage to COP21 climate finance commitments in subsequent implementations.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over natural disasters affecting Italy (Sardinia floods in November 2013), Greece (Kefalonia earthquake), Slovenia, and Croatia (ice storms and floods in early 2014), approving the mobilization of the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for €46,998,528 in commitment and payment appropriations under Draft amending budget No 5/2014. It stressed the urgency of providing financial assistance to affected countries but noted that payment shortages in the 2014 budget, previously addressed through Draft amending budget No 3/2014 and the Contingency Margin, precluded redeployment of existing funds. Parliament endorsed the joint agreement with the Council to allocate €47 million in 2014 commitment appropriations while deferring corresponding payments to the 2015 budget, thereby approving the Council’s position on the draft budget. The resolution emphasized adherence to the multiannual financial framework (2014-2020) and finalized the adoption of the amended budget to address immediate disaster relief needs.

title: Draft amending budget No 6/2014: Revision of the forecast of traditional own resources, VAT and GNI contributions: REPORT on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 6/2014 of the European Union for the financial year 2014, Section III – Commission
background: In 2014, the European Commission proposed adjustments to traditional own resources, VAT, and GNI contribution forecasts, alongside reallocations within the EU budget for fisheries funds and crisis reserves, amid financial pressures from unpaid bills and geopolitical impacts like the Russian agricultural embargo. The Parliament will discuss amendments to the 2014 budget addressing revenue revisions and expenditure realignments.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA firmly approves the reallocation of €6.2 million to humanitarian crisis preparedness, perfectly aligning with their climate resilience priorities and disaster prevention mandates.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the GNI contribution reduction framework, recognizing its critical role in maintaining fiscal equity among member states while preserving essential EU programs.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s adherence to multiannual financial discipline, effectively advancing long-term budgetary stability central to their sustainability agenda.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the increased Ombudsman funding as a vital reinforcement of transparency mechanisms, directly supporting their institutional accountability objectives.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the issue’s balanced Traditional Own Resources adjustment as exemplary fiscal stewardship, ensuring member state contributions reflect current economic realities without programmatic cuts.

GUE/NGL firmly conflicts the austerity-driven budget reductions that disproportionately impact vulnerable sectors like Irish fisheries and humanitarian aid provisions.  
GUE/NGL rejects the Juncker Plan's payment withdrawals from key policy areas as exacerbating neoliberal economic policies favoring financial elites over social welfare.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue's failure to reverse catastrophic cuts to UNWRA funding and its inadequate provisions for Palestinian refugees facing humanitarian crises.  
GUE/NGL denounces the €908 million cut to Heading 2 as directly contradicting commitments to regional development and workers' livelihoods in peripheral EU economies.  
GUE/NGL declares the budget structurally incompatible with combating EU wealth disparities, noting worsened North-South divides through cohesion policy underfunding.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and decisions regarding the adoption of Draft Amending Budget (DAB) No 6/2014, which adjusts the 2014 EU budget by revising revenue forecasts, reducing appropriations for the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and the reserve for Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreements by EUR 76.3 million in commitments and EUR 6.2 million in payments, and increasing funding for the European Ombudsman. The resolution highlighted an overall decrease in Member States’ Gross National Income (GNI) contributions by EUR 4,515.5 million and a EUR 420 million increase in Traditional Own Resources, resulting in a net reduction of EUR 4,095.5 million in own resource requirements. It endorsed reallocating EUR 6.2 million in saved payment appropriations to address potential humanitarian crises and emphasized that the GNI reduction, combined with adjustments from other DABs, fully offsets additional payment needs agreed in joint conclusions. The Parliament approved the Council’s position on DAB No 6/2014, as amended, and instructed its President to finalize the adoption of Amending Budget No 5/2014 and publish it, ensuring alignment with the multiannual financial framework and interinstitutional agreements on budgetary discipline.

title: Draft amending budget No 7/2014: Floods in Serbia, Croatia and Bulgaria: REPORT on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 7/2014 of the European Union for the financial year 2014, Section III – Commission
background: Severe flooding in Serbia (May 2014), Croatia (May 2014), and Bulgaria (June 2014) caused significant infrastructural damage and humanitarian needs, activating eligibility criteria under the EU Solidarity Fund. The Parliament will discuss mobilizing emergency financial assistance through the EUSF mechanism to address recovery efforts in affected regions.

stances.stance:
EFDD partially promotes the flood aid mobilization but demands immediate implementation of EU-level auditing mechanisms to prevent regional corruption scandals like those exposed in Italy.  
EFDD requests revision of payment deferral protocols, citing Marco Zanni's warning that delayed 2014 payments dangerously compound existing €20 billion liabilities.  
This fundamentally disputes with EFDD's principle of fiscal responsibility by normalizing budgetary "singhiozzo" (stopgap) measures that Marco Valli condemned as institutionally destabilizing.  
EFDD insists on amending Article 3 to prohibit member states with unresolved corruption cases – like Italy's immigration fund abuses – from accessing EUSF without third-party monitoring.  
The proposal overlooks Petr Mach's core argument that EU budget structures inherently breed unfair financial burdens, requiring systemic overhaul rather than crisis-driven appropriations.
