ALDE fundamentally supports the mobilization of the EU Solidarity Fund to address flood damages, perfectly aligning with its commitment to rapid crisis response and transnational solidarity.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s prioritization of urgent payment appropriations for 2014, reflecting their principle of fiscal accountability and adherence to prior commitments.  
ALDE fundamentally supports the deferral mechanism for 2015 payments as a necessary enhancement opportunity to stabilize budgetary frameworks while maintaining liquidity for critical recovery efforts.  
ALDE applauds the swift disbursement directive as a manifestation of EU solidarity, directly advancing their priority of tangible support for citizens in disaster-affected regions.  
ALDE underscores the issue’s alignment with their advocacy for transparent debt reconciliation processes, ensuring future budgetary rigor without opposing the immediate aid framework.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need to mobilize the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for €79,726,440 in commitment and payment appropriations to address flood damage in Serbia and Croatia (May 2014) and Bulgaria (June 2014), formalizing this adjustment in the 2014 budget. It stressed the critical shortage of 2014 payment appropriations, which precluded redeployment of funds and necessitated shifting corresponding payment needs to the 2015 budget. The resolution endorsed the Joint Conclusions of 8 December 2014, approving an additional €80 million in 2014 commitment appropriations while deferring payments, and approved the Council’s position on Draft Amending Budget No 7/2014. It finalized the adoption of Amending Budget No 6/2014, emphasizing swift disbursement of aid and instructing its publication in the Official Journal to ensure legal effect.

title: Draft amending budget No 8/2014: Surplus resulting from the implementation of the budget year 2013: REPORT on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 8/2014 of the European Union for the financial year 2014, Section III – Commission
background: The 2013 EU budget implementation generated a €1.005 billion surplus from higher-than-expected income (fines, interest) and under-spent appropriations amid payment shortages. EU financial rules mandate surplus allocation through amending budgets. The Parliament will discuss redistributing the 2013 surplus in line with budgetary procedures.

stances.stance:
EFDD conditionally supports the surplus reallocation but demands structural reforms to prevent recurring payment crises, citing unresolved €20+ billion liabilities.  
EFDD firmly disapproves increased GNI-based contributions, arguing this perpetuates unfair fiscal burdens inconsistent with national sovereignty principles.  
EFDD requests audit mechanisms for all reallocated funds, referencing systemic corruption in Italian reception centers as evidence of current oversight failures.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of budgetary credibility by maintaining the "political commitments over payments" approach EFDD explicitly condemns.  
EFDD warns this temporary fix contradicts their core stance against EU financial integration, emphasizing 58% UK exit sentiment as symptomatic of systemic distrust.

GREEN_EFA completely advocates the surplus reallocation as perfectly aligning with fiscal responsibility principles, ensuring Member States’ contributions reflect actual budgetary needs.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s compatibility with climate resilience priorities by proposing enhanced future allocations to preventive cohesion projects addressing extreme weather impacts.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the critical need to stabilize payment systems through this agreement while advocating accelerated reforms to eliminate structural payment backlogs.  
GREEN_EFA applauds strict adherence to Article 18 of the Financial Regulation as foundational to transparent surplus management across EU institutions.  
GREEN_EFA recognizes the issue’s role in maintaining budgetary continuity while urging intensified negotiations to resolve systemic payment appropriation shortfalls.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to address the 2013 budget surplus of €1,005 million, comprising €771 million in unanticipated income (primarily from fines and interest on late payments totaling €1,331 million, offset by declines in collected own resources and surpluses), €276 million in underspent expenditures due to insufficient payment appropriations in 2012 and 2013 (€107 million and €54 million respectively), and a €42 million exchange rate loss. It approved Draft Amending Budget (DAB) No 8/2014, which reallocates this surplus to reduce Member States’ GNI-based contributions to the EU budget by €1,005 million, partially offsetting their obligations under related DABs. The resolution highlighted that DAB No 8/2014 was necessitated by the failure of the Conciliation Committee to agree on DAB No 2/2014 (identical in purpose) amid broader disputes over 2014 payment needs and the interconnected DAB package (Nos 3-7/2014). By endorsing the Council’s position, Parliament finalized the adoption of the amending budget, emphasizing compliance with Article 18 of the Financial Regulation, which mandates surplus incorporation into the budget.

title: Control of the Register and composition of the Commission's expert groups: REPORT on control of the Register and composition of the Commission’s expert groups
background: The European Commission's 2016 expert group rules followed prior concerns over transparency and stakeholder balance, including 2011/2014 budgetary reserves, a 2016 study identifying imbalances, and European Ombudsman recommendations. The Parliament will discuss oversight of expert group composition and transparency mechanisms under the Commission's revised framework.

stances.stance:
ECR strongly sanctions the issue’s emphasis on transparency and balanced composition of expert groups, aligning perfectly with ECR’s longstanding commitment to institutional accountability and equitable stakeholder representation.  
ECR approves the mandate for systematic publication of expert group agendas, minutes, and dissenting opinions, which advances ECR’s priority of ensuring traceable and participatory policymaking.  
ECR proposes amending Section 4 to explicitly define “balanced composition” criteria tied to sectoral impact assessments, ensuring underrepresented groups like SMEs receive proportional representation.  
ECR applauds the call for financial support mechanisms to facilitate participation of non-economic stakeholders, a measure consistent with ECR’s advocacy for inclusive governance.  
ECR urges strict adherence to the June 2017 deadline for the Commission’s implementation report, emphasizing this as critical to resolving persistent imbalances noted since 2013.

GUE_NGL firmly advocates the issue's emphasis on transparency as perfectly aligning with their foundational principle of citizen-centric governance.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with demands for systematic civil society inclusion, proposing enhanced consultation mechanisms to institutionalize participatory democracy.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's critical role in preventing institutional detachment, noting its provisions effectively advance accountability to marginalized communities.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the issue's call for financial support to underrepresented groups as vital to rebalancing corporate-dominated policy spaces.  
GUE_NGL asserts the linkage between expert group transparency and public trust directly mirrors their decades-long advocacy for open decision-making processes.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over transparency and imbalanced composition in the European Commission’s expert groups (EGs), noting that 9% of EGs remained imbalanced since 2013 despite prior reforms. While welcoming the Commission’s 2016 Decision introducing horizontal rules for EGs—including public calls for expert selection, conflict-of-interest declarations, and improved registers—Parliament criticized the lack of a full public consultation during the reform process. It emphasized the need for balanced representation of economic and non-economic interests, urging clearer criteria for defining "balanced composition" tied to each EG’s mandate and stakeholder impact. Parliament called for greater transparency by publishing agendas, minutes, and dissenting opinions from EG meetings, aligning with the European Ombudsman’s recommendations, and stressed the need for financial support to facilitate participation of underrepresented groups (e.g., SMEs, trade unions). It demanded the Commission address persistent imbalances, ensure systematic oversight of EG rules, and submit an implementation report by June 2017. Additionally, Parliament highlighted the link between transparency, public trust, and regulatory legitimacy, urging the Commission to align EG practices with interinstitutional agreements and improve accessibility of policy documents via updated registers.

title: Draft amending budget No 2/2014 - surplus resulting from the implementation of the budget year 2013: REPORT on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 2/2014 of the European Union for the financial year 2014, Section III – Commission
background: The 2013 EU budget execution generated a €1.005 billion surplus from fines, under-spending, and exchange adjustments, alongside €23.4 billion in unpaid commitments from previous years. The Parliament will discuss allocating the surplus and addressing 2014 payment shortages within budgetary procedures.

stances.stance:
EFDD slightly upholds the surplus reallocation but requests binding commitments to resolve the €20 billion payment backlog before approving any contribution reductions  
EFDD firmly againsts linking DAB 2/2014 to subsequent budgets without ironclad guarantees for honoring existing payment obligations first  
The proposal's procedural interdependence fails to address EFDD's core concern about chronic underfunding of implemented programs from 2012-2013  
EFDD demands amendment of Article 5 to include mandatory quarterly reporting on legacy debt clearance before authorizing GNI contribution adjustments  
 While supporting surplus redistribution, EFDD rejects the assumption that €106 million net increase sufficiently addresses systemic payment capacity flaws

GREEN_EFA fundamentally sanctions the interdependent adoption of Draft Amending Budgets 2/2014, 3/2014, and 4/2014 as critical to maintaining fiscal equilibrium, perfectly aligning with their commitment to responsible budgetary governance.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on procedural coherence, stressing that linking these budgets ensures Member States honor financial commitments in line with the principle of *pacta sunt servanda*.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the Council’s untenable position on debt payments as a pivotal reason to adopt the unamended issue, reinforcing their stance that supranational agreements must be upheld without exception.  
This issue effectively advances GREEN_EFA’s priority of equitable fiscal burden-sharing by redistributing surpluses to reduce GNI contributions while safeguarding EU payment capacities.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s rejection of absorption-related narratives, framing under-implementation as a systemic payment failure that demands strict adherence to the proposed budgetary adjustments.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to address the 2013 budget surplus of €1,005 million, comprising €771 million in higher-than-expected income (primarily from fines and interest totaling €1,331 million), €276 million in expenditure under-spending, and a €42 million negative exchange rate difference. It noted declines in collected own resources (-€226 million) and surpluses, balances, and adjustments revenue (-€360 million), while emphasizing that under-implementation of 2013 (€107 million) and 2012 (€54 million) appropriations reflected payment shortages rather than absorption issues. The resolution linked Draft Amending Budget (DAB) No 2/2014, which allocates the surplus to reduce Member States’ GNI contributions by €1,005 million, to DAB No 3/2014 (requiring €3,170 million in additional payments) and DAB No 4/2014 (providing €2,059 million in own resources). It highlighted that adopting all three unamended would result in a net increase of only €106 million in Member States’ GNI contributions to cover 2014 payment obligations, stressing the procedural interdependence of these budgets to balance revenue and expenditure adjustments.

title: Draft amending budget No 3/2014: Revenue from fines, interest payments, reimbursements and repayments – Payment appropriations – Establishment plans of the Commission, the Committee of the Regions and the European Data Protection Supervisor: REPORT on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 3/2014 of the European Union for the financial year 2014, Section III – Commission
background: Persistent payment backlogs from prior EU programming periods, compounded by the transition to the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework, created pressure to reconcile existing financial obligations with constrained payment appropriations amid member states’ fiscal consolidation efforts. The Parliament will discuss adjustments to the 2014 budget addressing revenue revisions and payment allocation to manage outstanding commitments.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA totally promotes the issue's urgent mobilization of the Contingency Margin to address payment shortfalls, perfectly aligning with their fiscal responsibility principles in cohesion policy implementation.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's critique of Council reservations on MFF flexibility, emphasizing this as critical to preventing further erosion of trust in EU budgetary commitments.  
GREEN_EFA totally promotes the prioritization of Heading 1b allocations while urging accelerated structural reforms to permanently resolve payment backlogs consistent with their sustainable development agenda.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the demand for regular payment backlog reporting, proposing enhanced transparency through public dashboards tracking project-specific disbursement timelines.  
GREEN_EFA totally promotes linking future budget negotiations to climate resilience investments, as emphasized in debate contributions about flood prevention and Cohesion Policy synergies.

GUE_NGL fully condemns the issue's failure to reverse austerity-driven budget cuts that perpetuate North-South economic disparities, directly contradicting their anti-neoliberal principles.  
GUE_NGL rejects the inadequate allocation to Cohesion Policy (Heading 1b) as institutionalizing structural underfunding of regional development, exacerbating inequalities between member states.  
GUE_NGL condemns the 4.5% reduction in humanitarian aid under Heading 4 as morally indefensible given worsening refugee crises, violating their commitment to international solidarity.  
GUE_NGL denounces the Juncker Plan's diversion of payment appropriations from social programs as prioritizing financial market interests over public welfare needs.  
GUE_NGL declares the issue's payment backlog "solution" fraudulent for relying on temporary contingency margins rather than addressing systemic underfunding of EU public services.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the substantial payment backlog in the EU budget, particularly under Heading 1b (Cohesion policy), which reached EUR 23.4 billion at the end of 2013, exceeding initial forecasts and risking further growth. It endorsed Draft Amending Budget (DAB) No 3/2014, which proposed reinforcing payment appropriations by EUR 4,246 million for 2014, including EUR 3,168 million mobilized through the Contingency Margin to address urgent payment needs across budget headings. The resolution highlighted that over 70% of the allocated funds under DAB No 3/2014 would target Heading 1b, though this was deemed the minimum required to address immediate shortfalls, not a structural solution to the recurring backlog exacerbated by unpaid bills since 2010. It stressed the need for unconditional and swift adoption of DAB No 3/2014, noting its impact on the 2015 budget and the broader reduction of Member States’ GNI contributions by EUR 8,688 million through subsequent amendments. The Parliament criticized Council reservations on using the Contingency Margin as contradictory to the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) Regulation’s flexibility intent and urged the Commission to propose long-term solutions, including full utilization of MFF instruments and regular reporting on payment deadlines and backlog evolution under Heading 1b.

title: Amendment of the MFF 2014-2020: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 laying down the multiannual financial framework for the years 2014/2020
background: Delays in adopting the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) Regulation and subsequent legislative acts caused late approval of 300 operational programs, risking €21.1 billion in uncommitted 2014 funds under shared management. The Parliament will discuss amending the MFF to reallocate unused appropriations and prevent financial losses.

stances.stance:
EFDD partly sanctions the MFF adjustment while maintaining fundamental opposition to EU budgetary centralization, as articulated in Jonathan Arnott's critique that "Brussels sends it back... we could achieve better results through national financing".  
EFDD requests revisions to Article 5 provisions on Cohesion Fund allocations, arguing the current structure "drains financial resources from Member States" contrary to subsidiarity principles outlined in their 2014 electoral manifesto.  
This proposal conflicts with EFDD's core position that regional development "should be managed nationally" rather than through EU mechanisms, as Marco Zanni emphasized regarding Italy's need for localized resource allocation.  
The issue overlooks critical EFDD concerns about systemic inefficiency, evidenced by Arnott's calculation that €20 billion in lapsed commitments represents wasted taxpayer funds requiring structural reimbursement reforms.  
EFDD's partial approval remains inconsistent with their broader rejection of EU fiscal integration, as Zanni noted regarding "rash adjustments" mirroring Italy's problematic administrative practices rather than delivering genuine reform.

SD completely advocates the MFF amendment to reallocate €21 billion, perfectly aligning with their commitment to preventing fund expiration and ensuring full utilization of cohesion policy resources.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s urgency in avoiding payment delays, emphasizing its critical role in safeguarding employment projects like Cornwall’s Youth Employment Initiative from bureaucratic stagnation.  
SD fully supports the technical adjustment as foundational to accelerating operational programmes, directly advancing their priority of reducing regional disparities through timely structural fund deployment.  
SD highlights the amendment’s necessity to correct institutional delays in programme adoption, which aligns with their manifesto goal of streamlining EU fund accessibility for local authorities.  
SD endorses the Council Regulation revision as a vital step toward mitigating "payment peaks," thereby reinforcing their longstanding advocacy for predictable, socially impactful EU budgeting.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the draft Council Regulation (05479/2015) amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 to adjust the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for 2014-2020, as outlined in the annexed resolution, under the legal bases of Article 312 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and Article 106a of the Euratom Treaty. This decision formalized the Parliament’s approval of the MFF revision, enabling the updated budgetary framework to proceed, and instructed its President to communicate the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, concluding the legislative process for the amendment.

title: Annual report on the control of the financial activities of the European Investment Bank for 2015: REPORT on the annual report on the control of the financial activities of the EIB for 2015
background: The European Investment Bank's 2015 operations included €77.5 billion in financing, primarily within the EU, alongside external mandates and initiatives like the European Fund for Strategic Investments. The Parliament will discuss the EIB's financial activities, alignment with EU policy objectives, and institutional accountability mechanisms during its annual review.

stances.stance:
ALDE absolutely promotes the issue's climate finance targets, perfectly aligning with ALDE's commitment to achieving 35% climate action funding by 2020 through renewable energy and decarbonized transport systems.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the phase-out of fossil fuel infrastructure investments, emphasizing the critical need to prioritize renewable energy projects and circular economy models as stated in ALDE's sustainability agenda.  
ALDE applauds the focus on enhancing EIB transparency through public project assessments, which directly advances ALDE's governance reform priorities and anti-fraud standards.  
ALDE emphasizes rigorous adherence to additionality principles for cross-border projects, reflecting ALDE's strategic vision for pan-European integration and risk-balanced investments.  
ALDE supports strengthening SME financing mechanisms across all regions, aligning perfectly with ALDE's growth strategy to reduce economic disparities through job-creating initiatives.

GUE/NGL opposes fundamentally the discharge due to the issue's endorsement of defense sector investments, contradicting their staunch commitment to national neutrality and peace.  
GUE/NGL rejects the promotion of speculative financial instruments like PPPs and securitization, which institutionalize the privatization of profits and socialization of losses, directly conflicting with their anti-austerity principles.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue’s alignment with EU migration policies that outsource border control to non-EU states, violating fundamental rights and perpetuating humanitarian crises, inconsistent with their advocacy for refugee protections.  
GUE/NGL highlights the issue’s failure to address the EIB’s lack of additionality, particularly regarding the Juncker Plan’s overstated impact, which mirrors their critique of neoliberal investment frameworks.  
GUE/NGL underscores the issue’s inadequate transparency measures, notably omitting binding anti-fraud protocols and World Bank-level governance standards, thereby enabling conflicts of interest and corporate capture.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined priorities regarding the European Investment Bank’s (EIB) activities, emphasizing its role in advancing EU integration, economic cohesion, and sustainable growth. In 2015, the EIB signed €77.5 billion in operations, with €69.7 billion allocated to EU Member States and €7.8 billion outside the EU, though 73% of EU funding was concentrated in six countries, highlighting geographical imbalances. The resolution stressed the need for greater transparency, accountability, and alignment with EU policies, including the Europe 2020 strategy, climate goals (noting €3.4 billion for renewables), and social cohesion, where the EIB fell short of its 30% target (achieving 25.2%). It called for enhanced support for SMEs, which received 36.6% of funding (leveraging €39.7 billion and supporting 5 million jobs), and urged wider adoption of the SME Initiative, active in six countries with €8.5 billion in favorable loans. The European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) was noted for mobilizing €115.7 billion in investments by 2018, though geographical and sectoral disparities required correction. The Parliament urged the EIB to prioritize additionality, riskier projects with cross-border impact, and environmental sustainability, while phasing out gas infrastructure investments to avoid stranded assets. Transparency improvements were demanded, including public access to project assessments, anti-fraud measures, and alignment with EU tax compliance standards. Concerns were raised about governance, conflicts of interest, and the need for stricter oversight, including collaboration with the European Court of Auditors and Ombudsman. The resolution also highlighted the EIB’s role in global challenges like migration and called for strengthened cooperation with national authorities and EU funds to boost cohesion, innovation, and infrastructure, particularly in underdeveloped regions.

title: 2016 budgetary procedure: joint text: REPORT on the joint text on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 approved by the Conciliation Committee under the budgetary procedure
background: In 2015, the EU faced a migration influx, economic recovery challenges, agricultural market disruptions from the Russian embargo, and heightened security needs following terrorist attacks. The Parliament will discuss finalizing the 2016 EU budget, prioritizing migration management, economic growth, and internal security within existing financial constraints.

stances.stance:
EFDD opposes fundamentally the allocation of €1.5 billion via the Flexibility Instrument for migration management, viewing it as a policy failure that exacerbates security risks and Schengen instability while neglecting vulnerable refugees in third countries.  
EFDD rejects the budget’s structural contradictions, particularly the €140 million payment reduction and agency staffing contortions (e.g., ACER +5 posts, Parliament -9 posts), which perpetuate institutional inefficiencies instead of rationalizing priorities.  
EFDD condemns the issue’s approach to youth unemployment through programs like COSME and Erasmus+, arguing uncontrolled immigration undermines job accessibility for EU citizens without addressing labor market root causes.  
EFDD highlights the budget’s failure to correct systemic overreach, citing the €460.1 million payment appropriation cuts as insufficient to align with national sovereignty principles or address long-term fiscal imbalances.  
EFDD disputes the institutional compromises on Horizon 2020 and pilot project funding, asserting they entangle EU competencies in areas better managed at member-state level.

ALDE fully supports the 2016 budget’s prioritization of migration response and SME funding through the Flexibility Instrument, perfectly aligning with ALDE’s commitment to crisis resilience and economic innovation.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the reversal of Council cuts to Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+, recognizing these enhancements as critical to advancing ALDE’s research and youth mobility agendas.  
ALDE applauds the retention of the Youth Employment Initiative, which directly reflects ALDE’s manifesto focus on combating EU-wide unemployment through targeted fiscal measures.  
ALDE strongly endorses the issue’s emphasis on reducing payment backlogs, a strategic alignment with ALDE’s long-standing advocacy for budgetary accountability and operational efficiency.  
ALDE commends the integration of performance-based budgeting principles, a cornerstone of ALDE’s fiscal policy vision to prevent arbitrary financial cuts in Member States.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the definitive adoption of the EU’s 2016 general budget, setting commitment appropriations at €155,004.2 million (leaving a €2,331.4 million margin below the Multiannual Financial Framework ceiling) and payment appropriations at €143,885.3 million. It mobilized the Flexibility Instrument for €1,506 million (Heading 3: Security and Citizenship) and €24 million (Heading 4: Global Europe) in commitments, with related 2016 payments estimated at €832.8 million. For 2015, Draft Amending Budget 8/2015 was approved, including adjustments to agency staffing and funding: increases for the European Chemicals Agency (-€1.35 million despite +3 posts), European Aviation Safety Agency (+6 posts), European Medicines Agency (+3 posts), ACER (+5 posts, +€325,000), FRA (+2 posts, +€130,000), Eurojust (+2 posts, +€130,000), and EBA (+€928,000), alongside reductions for eu-LISA (-€260,000). Commitments for Horizon 2020, COSME, and Erasmus+ were increased, while institutional adjustments included a 9-post reduction for Parliament and +7 posts (+€300,000) for the Court of Justice. Payment appropriations were adjusted via three mechanisms: a €140 million decrease for non-differentiated expenditures, a €29.5 million increase for pilot/preparatory projects, and a €460.1 million reduction in other payments. The resolution confirmed joint institutional statements and instructed the publication and communication of the adopted budget.

title: 2017 budgetary procedure: joint text: REPORT on the joint text on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 approved by the Conciliation Committee under the budgetary procedure
background: The European Union faced 2016 migration pressures, security challenges, and post-financial crisis economic recovery needs requiring budgetary adjustments under the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework. The Parliament will discuss the 2017 general budget's alignment with priorities including migration management, security reinforcement, youth employment, and growth initiatives within existing fiscal parameters.

stances.stance:
ENF fully challenges with the 10% budget increase for Palestinian aid (€300 million annually), denouncing it as direct support for entities engaging in anti-Semitic violence  
ENF rejects the €6 billion allocation to Turkey as capitulation to "Islamist blackmail" under Erdogan's regime, contrary to European security interests  
ENF opposes the €177 million expenditure for migrant maintenance in Italy, declaring it prioritizes "fake refugees" over unemployed EU citizens  
ENF condemns the issue's failure to address youth unemployment exceeding 50% in Southern Europe while funding "failed economic policies"  
ENF highlights the budget's moral bankruptcy through €1.91 billion contingency margins that perpetuate uncontrolled spending on "EU propaganda projects"

ALDE absolutely upholds the 2017 EU budget issue, highlighting its alignment with priorities such as youth mobility, SME support through COSME, and Horizon 2020 research funding.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the budget’s unprecedented efforts to address the migration crisis and enhance internal security, reflecting their commitment to EU solidarity and protection.  
ALDE applauds the successful mobilization of trust-building measures with the Commission, as exemplified by Vice-President Georgieva’s collaborative approach, ensuring parliamentary involvement in budgetary processes.  
ALDE recognizes the issue’s support for agricultural sectors affected by external embargoes, particularly dairy producers, as a critical component of EU economic resilience.  
ALDE commends the Conciliation Committee’s tenacity in achieving a balanced budget that maintains fiscal responsibility while addressing urgent priorities, reinforcing the efficacy of interinstitutional cooperation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the 2017 EU budget with commitment appropriations set at €157.86 billion, leaving a €1.1 billion margin below the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) ceilings, and payment appropriations at €134.49 billion. Key allocations included mobilizing the Flexibility Instrument (€530 million for Security and Citizenship), the Global Margin (€1.44 billion for Competitiveness), and the Contingency Margin (€1.91 billion for headings 3 and 4, offset by reductions in other headings). Payment appropriations linked to prior Flexibility Instrument mobilizations (2014-2016) totaled €981.1 million. For 2016, amendments included accepting Draft Amending Budgets 4/2016 (Contingency Margin), 5/2016, and 6/2016 (Solidarity Fund), alongside agency adjustments: EUROPOL and EUROJUST each received 10 additional posts (€675,000), the EBA faced a €500,000 reduction, EASO gained €3 million, and EMA was cut by €8.35 million. Agricultural expenditure was reduced by €325 million, administrative expenditure adjusted by €13.4 million, and payment rules for pilot projects set at 50% of commitments. The Solidarity Fund reserve was abolished, and further reductions required enhanced reporting on Trust Funds, annual working documents, and parliamentary involvement in budgetary measures.

title: 2018 budgetary procedure: REPORT on the joint text on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2018 approved by the Conciliation Committee under the budgetary procedure
background: The European Union's 2018 budgetary procedure followed established multiannual financial framework (2014-2020) protocols, with negotiations between the Commission, Council, and Parliament to reconcile competing priorities under constrained fiscal conditions. The Parliament will discuss finalizing annual expenditure allocations across policy areas including migration management, security cooperation, economic competitiveness, and youth employment initiatives within institutional budget ceilings.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA rejects the 2018 budget's allocation of €837.2 million through the Flexibility Instrument for Security and Citizenship, totally challengeing with their principle of prioritizing social cohesion over militarization.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the deferred Contingency Margin adjustments as structurally inadequate, failing to address systemic underfunding of climate transition programs in Heading 1a and 1b.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the Court of Auditors' €1 million transfer for celebratory events, highlighting a pattern of fiscal irresponsibility inconsistent with their manifesto demand for austerity in administrative spending.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as binding environmental safeguards in new pilot projects, which remain capped at 50% commitments without sustainability criteria.  
GREEN_EFA disputes the agricultural expenditure reductions as undermining rural green initiatives, directly contradicting their agricultural biodiversity protection agenda.

ALDE strongly advocates the 2018 budget’s increased funding for research, youth employment initiatives, and SME competitiveness, aligning with their priorities for economic growth and job creation.  
ALDE approves the €105 million reduction in Turkey’s pre-accession funds, reinforcing the EU’s commitment to democratic values and opposition to authoritarian governance.  
ALDE applauds the bolstered resources for Europol, Eurojust, and the Stratcom program, recognizing their critical role in countering terrorism and foreign disinformation campaigns.  
ALDE endorses the climate action allocations while proposing enhanced monitoring to ensure future budgets meet the 20% spending target mandated by the Paris Agreement.  
ALDE advocates for reforming the Multiannual Financial Framework to enable greater flexibility in reallocating funds between priorities and simplifying contingency instrument activation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the adoption of the EU’s 2018 general budget, setting commitment appropriations at €160.1 billion (with a €1.6 billion margin below the Multiannual Financial Framework ceilings) and payment appropriations at €144.7 billion. It mobilized the Flexibility Instrument for €837.2 million under Security and Citizenship (Heading 3) and allocated €1.1 billion from the Global Margin to Competitiveness for Growth and Jobs (Heading 1a) and Economic, Social, and Territorial Cohesion (Heading 1b). Adjustments to the Contingency Margin reduced offsetting in Administration (Heading 5) from €570 million to €318 million in 2018, with €252 million deferred to 2020. Payment appropriations linked to the Flexibility Instrument across 2014–2018 were estimated at €678.3 million. For 2017, agricultural expenditure was reduced by €229.9 million, resulting in a net decrease of €255.3 million, while payment appropriations for new pilot projects and preparatory actions were capped at 50% of commitments (or lower if proposed), adding €50 million. The resolution approved new budget lines, pilot actions, and a dedicated European External Action Service item, aligning with Commission proposals and amendments.

title: 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework and own resources: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the 2021-2027 multiannual financial framework and own resources
background: The European Commission's May 2018 proposal for the 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework addressed post-Brexit budget adjustments and new EU priorities amid existing commitments. With the UK's withdrawal creating funding gaps and evolving challenges in security, migration, and climate action, the Parliament will discuss the seven-year budget structure and revenue sources.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves maintaining cohesion policy funding at 2014-2020 real-term levels, aligning with the issue's emphasis on territorial solidarity and rejecting disproportionate cuts to the Cohesion Fund.  
EPP fully advocates tripling Erasmus+ funding as critical for youth development, reflecting their manifesto priority of investing in Europe's future generations.  
EPP approves the proposed 50% increase in research budgets to €120 billion, recognizing this directly advances EPP's innovation-driven economic agenda.  
EPP proposes marginally adjusting cohesion allocation formulas to better address demographic decline while preserving core funding levels, enhancing alignment with regional needs.  
EPP strongly approves linking budget allocations to rule-of-law conditionality, perfectly aligning with their governance principles to safeguard EU financial interests.

EFDD rejects the proposed MFF budget increase to 1.3% of EU-27 GNI as fiscally irresponsible, entirely opposeing with EFDD's principle of reducing EU centralization and taxpayer burdens.  
EFDD opposes linking EU funding to rule-of-law conditionality mechanisms, denouncing this as bureaucratic overreach that undermines national sovereignty.  
The issue's support for new EU own resources (e.g., environmental taxes) overlooks EFDD's demand to prohibit additional EU-level taxation, which Rolandas Paksas explicitly condemned as "skurdinti Bendrijos valstybių žmonių" (impoverishing EU citizens).  
EFDD condemns cuts to CAP and cohesion policy budgets as destructive to agricultural communities and regional economies, directly contradicting Marco Valli's call to protect small farmers and depressed eurozone areas.  
Jörg Meuthen's characterization of the MFF as "dreiste Fiskalkleptokratie" (brazen fiscal kleptocracy) aligns with EFDD's view that post-Brexit budget expansion constitutes reckless financial overreach incompatible with member-state interests.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the Commission’s proposed 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) of €1.1 trillion (1.08% of EU-27 Gross National Income), deeming it insufficient to address emerging challenges and political priorities, noting it represents a real-term reduction compared to the current MFF. It criticized significant cuts to key policies, including a 15% reduction for the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), 10% for cohesion policy, and sharper cuts to the Cohesion Fund (45%) and European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (over 25%), while opposing a 6% cut to the European Social Fund despite its expanded scope. Parliament advocated maintaining CAP and cohesion funding at 2014-2020 levels in real terms, tripling Erasmus+ funding, doubling SME and youth unemployment support, increasing research and innovation budgets by 50% (to €120 billion), doubling LIFE+, expanding the Connecting Europe Facility, and boosting security, migration, and external relations funding. It stressed the MFF should reach 1.3% of EU-27 GNI and integrate UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), gender equality, and climate action, targeting 30% climate-related spending by 2027. While supporting Commission proposals for new EU own resources (e.g., environmental and internal market-linked revenues) and simplified VAT, it questioned the absence of digital sector taxes and a financial transaction tax. Parliament emphasized linking MFF negotiations to revenue reforms, backed a rule-of-law mechanism to protect the budget from member state deficiencies, and demanded a legally binding mid-term review to adjust the MFF. It urged the Council to adopt a more ambitious, citizen-focused framework through structured dialogue.

title: Establishing the InvestEU Programme: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the InvestEU Programme
background: The European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), launched post-2008 crisis under the Juncker Plan, aimed to address investment gaps and stimulate growth. Despite economic recovery, persistent underinvestment in sustainable infrastructure, innovation, and social sectors prompted the Commission to propose consolidating 13 financial instruments into a unified programme. The Parliament will discuss establishing the InvestEU Programme to streamline strategic investment support.

stances.stance:
ENF rejects the InvestEU Programme’s centralized governance model, which undermines national sovereignty by consolidating financial instruments under EU institutions like the EIB Group.  
ENF opposes the mandatory integration of ESG criteria into risk assessments, viewing this as ideological overreach inconsistent with member states’ autonomy to set economic priorities.  
The issue totally condemns with ENF’s fiscal principles by endorsing a €38 billion EU budget guarantee, perpetuating unsustainable financial centralization.  
ENF highlights the failure to address geographic balance in practice, as advisory hubs and investments risk favoring established EU corridors over local or national projects.  
 Despite superficial praise for advisory hubs, ENF condemns the programme’s alignment with EU climate targets, which impose top-down constraints on industrial and transport sectors.

SD fully accepts the strategic consolidation of dispersed financial instruments under InvestEU, creating a unified framework that perfectly aligns with SD’s vision for simplified, impact-driven sustainable growth mechanisms.  
SD perfectly aligns with the mandatory ESG criteria integration in risk assessments, advancing SD’s climate leadership priorities through standardized metrics that operationalize Paris Agreement commitments.  
SD fully accepts the cross-sectoral advisory hub and TEN-T infrastructure focus, reflecting SD’s manifesto pledge to interconnect sustainable mobility, digitalization, and energy systems for territorially balanced development.  
SD perfectly aligns with the elevation of national development banks’ roles, amplifying SD’s longstanding advocacy for localized investment channels that address regional socioeconomic disparities.  
SD fully accepts the 40% climate contribution target as a transformative leap beyond EFSI 2.0, directly mirroring SD’s demand for public finance to prioritize decarbonization and green innovation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the InvestEU Programme, emphasizing the strategic orientation, operational policies, and rules for investment platforms under the InvestEU Fund. It mandated a six-member Steering Board, chaired by a Commission-appointed member for a renewable three-year term, to make decisions by majority if consensus fails, with detailed records of member positions. The resolution required risk assessment methodologies incorporating ESG criteria, standardized risk ratings, and metrics for exposure and loss defaults. It directed the Commission to partner with the EIB Group and others to establish a unified InvestEU Advisory Hub for cross-sectoral support, prioritizing geographic balance and synergies between transport, energy, and digital sectors. Specific transport investments were outlined, including TEN-T telematic priorities, sustainable mobility, infrastructure upgrades, and workforce adaptation, alongside automated mobility and cross-border projects. Tourism projects were to shift toward sustainability and innovation, while maintaining a 40% climate contribution target aligned with EFSI 2.0. The Parliament urged the Commission to resubmit proposals if substantially amended and instructed forwarding its position to relevant EU bodies and national parliaments.

title: Discharge 2015: Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (ACER): REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators for the financial year 2015
background: The Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (ACER) reported a 3.55% budget increase in 2015, with carry-over challenges linked to implementing REMIT regulations and delayed establishment of a European School by Slovenia. The Parliament will discuss ACER's 2015 budget discharge procedure, focusing on financial management and institutional accountability.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the issue's emphasis on fiscal accountability and transparency, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to rigorous oversight of EU budget execution.  
EPP proposes enhancing ACER's public communication strategies to better showcase operational achievements, addressing concerns about underreported agency performance while maintaining full endorsement of audit findings.  
EPP approves the call for accelerated infrastructure issues in Ljubljana, effectively advancing EPP's priority of functional EU agency operations through host-state cooperation.  
EPP fully advocates maintaining explicit references to past administrative irregularities, as this strengthens institutional integrity and matches EPP's manifesto pledge for uncompromised budgetary scrutiny.  
EPP recommends streamlining future discharge timelines to increase procedural credibility, a minor adjustment that would reinforce rather than challenge the issue's core accountability framework.

ECR rejects the discharge due to unresolved high carry-over expenditures (€1.36 million operational, €790k administrative), reflecting systemic financial mismanagement conflicting with their fiscal accountability principles.  
ECR opposes fundamentally the lack of progress in staff diversity, citing under-representation of post-2004 Member States in ACER's managerial roles, contradicting equitable resource distribution commitments.  
ECR condemns the delayed European School establishment in Ljubljana as emblematic of broader infrastructure failures, mirroring the criticized Europa building delays.  
ECR highlights incomplete anti-fraud measures despite ACER's 2015-2017 strategy, aligning with Court of Auditors' concerns over persistent payment errors.  
ECR disputes the adequacy of internal controls, noting partial implementation of audit recommendations and unresolved 2014 findings, demonstrating insufficient accountability frameworks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined key findings regarding the Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (ACER) for the 2015 financial year, granting discharge and approving the closure of its accounts. The Agency’s budget was €11.27 million, a 3.55% increase from 2014, entirely funded by the EU, with a 95.09% implementation rate and 74.88% payment execution. Carry-overs for operational expenditure (Title III) amounted to €1.36 million (59% of committed appropriations), linked to the multi-annual implementation of Regulation (EU) No 1227/2011, while administrative expenditure (Title II) saw €790,000 (35%) in carry-overs, attributed to undelivered studies and services. Staffing included 54 temporary agents and 20 contract agents, with 67.83% of roles classified as operational. Internal controls met standards, though improvements were urged, and audits by the Commission’s Internal Audit Service (IAS) noted partial implementation of recommendations, with two pending from 2014. A 2015 stakeholder survey assessed regulatory performance, and a study on gas network code impacts was initiated. The Agency adopted a conflict-of-interest policy and anti-fraud strategy (2015–2017), but gaps remained in publishing CVs and declarations for some board members. It criticized delays in establishing a European School in Ljubljana despite a 2016 host-state agreement, highlighting unresolved infrastructure issues. Performance metrics emphasized transparency and accountability, urging continued reporting on audit outcomes and stakeholder engagement.

title: Discharge 2015: Bio-based Industries Joint Undertaking (BBI): REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the Bio-based Industries Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2015
background: The Bio-based Industries Joint Undertaking, established in 2014 under Horizon 2020 as a public-private partnership, transitioned to operational autonomy in October 2015 after initial Commission management. The Parliament will discuss the 2015 discharge procedure, focusing on budgetary execution, financial controls, and adherence to EU regulatory frameworks.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly accepts the transparency measures in publishing contracts over €15,000, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to institutional accountability and public trust.  
ALDE approves the BBI JU’s operational autonomy and high budget utilization rates, recognizing these as critical steps toward effective governance of EU-funded initiatives.  
ALDE proposes enhancing guidelines for in-kind contribution reporting to ensure timely and accurate valuation, addressing the Court of Auditors’ concerns without opposing the issue’s core objectives.  
ALDE commends the establishment of anti-fraud controls and ex-post audit plans, which effectively advance their manifesto priorities for rigorous financial oversight.  
ALDE endorses the inclusion of BBI JU in Horizon 2020’s mid-term review to harmonize procedures, reflecting their advocacy for streamlined EU innovation frameworks.

ECR rejects the issue for failing to address systemic payment errors and the Council’s refusal to cooperate in discharge accountability mechanisms.  
ECR opposes fundamentally the omission of concrete measures to rectify under-representation of post-2004 Member States in managerial posts, as highlighted in audit findings.  
ECR condemns the issue’s silence on enforcing strict anti-fraud controls comparable to ENISA relocation scrutiny, creating institutional inconsistency.  
ECR highlights contradictions in endorsing staffing improvements while ignoring persistent vacancy rates undermining operational credibility.  
ECR asserts the proposal overlooks critical transparency gaps in private sector IKOP reporting, perpetuating financial governance risks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised key points regarding the Bio-based Industries Joint Undertaking (BBI JU) for 2015, highlighting its operational autonomy achieved in October 2015, with a maximum EU contribution of €975 million from Horizon 2020 and private sector commitments of at least €2.73 billion over its 10-year mandate. The resolution noted the BBI JU’s successful transition to financial independence, leveraging €71 million from private partners in its first projects. The 2015 budget included €209.4 million in commitment appropriations (87% utilized) and €21.1 million in payment appropriations (89% utilized), with two calls for proposals: one flagship call (€100 million) funding three projects (€73.7 million) and a second call (€106 million) evaluated in 2016. Challenges included delays in reporting in-kind contributions (IKOPs) by private members, with only €3.5 million estimated from grant agreements, and staffing shortfalls (13 of 22 posts filled by 2015, later increased to 20 by 2016). The Court of Auditors affirmed the reliability of accounts but urged clearer guidelines for financial management, addressed by December 2016. Internal controls, anti-fraud measures, and conflict-of-interest policies were established, alongside ex-ante controls and plans for ex-post audits. The resolution called for the BBI JU’s inclusion in Horizon 2020’s mid-term review to streamline processes and harmonize joint undertakings.

title: Discharge 2015: Clean Sky 2 Joint Undertaking: REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the Clean Sky 2 Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2015
background: The Clean Sky 2 Joint Undertaking, established under Horizon 2020 to advance aeronautics research through public-private partnerships, received EU funding with a 2015 budget of €440.7 million in commitments. The European Court of Auditors verified accounts but highlighted challenges in payment execution and in-kind contribution validation. The Parliament will discuss compliance with financial regulations and budgetary management for the 2015 discharge.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly endorses the issue’s focus on transparency and accountability, particularly the publication of contractor lists exceeding €15,000, which aligns perfectly with ALDE’s longstanding commitment to open governance and citizen trust in EU institutions.  

ALDE approves the issue’s acknowledgment of high budget utilization rates and progress in widening participation, including SME engagement, as critical to advancing innovation and competitiveness within the EU’s aerospace sector.  

ALDE proposes enhancing financial management procedures to mitigate payment execution delays caused by project timelines, ensuring smoother alignment between commitments and disbursements without opposing the issue’s core objectives.  

ALDE underscores the urgency of correcting gender imbalances in technical and governance bodies, urging accelerated measures to achieve equitable representation, consistent with ALDE’s prioritization of diversity and inclusion.  

ALDE applauds the call for closer cooperation with Structural Funds and simplification via Horizon 2020’s mid-term review, reflecting ALDE’s manifesto goals for cohesive, efficient EU research frameworks.

ECR rejects the discharge approval due to unresolved high error rates in payments, directly conflicting with their demand for rigorous financial accountability.  
ECR completely againsts the issue's oversight of under-representation in managerial posts for post-2004 Member States, contradicting their principle of equitable EU institutional representation.  
ECR highlights the Council’s refusal to cooperate in discharge procedures as a critical flaw, rendering the issue’s assurances on legal compliance incomplete.  
ECR condemns the misallocation of resources exemplified by ENISA’s contested relocation costs, which undermines budgetary efficiency priorities.  
ECR asserts the issue inadequately addresses fraud prevention gaps despite the 1.52% audit error rate, violating their stance on stringent anti-fraud measures.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and observations regarding the Clean Sky 2 Joint Undertaking’s 2015 financial management, noting its final budget included €440.7 million in commitment appropriations and €245.99 million in payment appropriations, with high utilization rates of 99.47% for commitments and 75.44% for payments. It highlighted challenges in payment execution due to project delays and technical alignment. Under FP7, 94.6% of €800 million operational funds were committed, with 92.5% paid, while Horizon 2020 saw €436.68 million committed and €89.8 million paid. The Joint Undertaking reported €47.1 million in certified and pending in-kind contributions for Horizon 2020, alongside concerns over delays in validating private members’ contributions. The Parliament acknowledged progress in widening participation, with 76 new core partners and 36% SME involvement by 2016, though initial 2015 rates fell below targets. It noted the completion of 106 FP7 projects and delivery of 10 demonstrators, alongside internal controls and a 1.52% error rate in ex-post audits. Gender imbalance in technical and governance bodies (3.2–16.7% female representation) was criticized, urging corrective measures. Cooperation with Structural Funds was encouraged, and the Commission was called to involve the Joint Undertaking in Horizon 2020’s mid-term review for simplification. The resolution affirmed the Court of Auditors’ findings of reliable accounts and legal transactions but stressed ongoing improvements in fraud prevention and dissemination of research results.

title: Discharge 2015: ECSEL Joint Undertaking: REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2015
background: The ECSEL Joint Undertaking, established in 2014 under Horizon 2020 to consolidate EU electronics research, faced challenges in financial oversight due to divergent national audit methodologies under the Seventh Framework Programme, prompting a qualified opinion from the Court of Auditors on 2015 transactions. The Parliament will discuss compliance with budgetary execution standards and control mechanisms for joint undertakings.

stances.stance:

EPP entirely accepts the issue's recognition of resolved Horizon 2020 audit methodologies, aligning with EPP's prioritization of harmonized financial controls.  
EPP proposes enhancing Participating States' contribution timelines to match the EU's 100% commitment rate, ensuring equitable burden-sharing in future funding cycles.  
EPP applauds the emphasis on fraud risk mitigation and ex-post controls as critical to safeguarding public funds, directly advancing EPP's governance principles.  
EPP urges accelerated adoption of performance-based budgeting reforms highlighted in the issue, reinforcing EPP's 2015 manifesto goals for fiscal efficiency.

ECR rejects the discharge approval as it totally rejects with ECR's insistence on resolving persistent audit irregularities, particularly the unresolved carry-over appropriations and building policy delays cited by the Court of Auditors, which the issue inadequately addresses.  
ECR opposes the issue’s failure to mandate equitable representation of post-2004 Member States in managerial roles, directly contradicting ECR’s principle of fair intra-EU institutional parity.  
ECR condemns the issue’s silence on ENISA’s contentious relocation costs, viewing this as fiscal negligence inconsistent with ECR’s demand for prudent resource allocation.  
ECR rejects the discharge due to the Council’s refusal to provide transparency during the procedure, undermining accountability—a core ECR priority.  
ECR opposes the issue’s dismissal of material payment errors flagged by auditors, which starkly contradicts ECR’s uncompromising stance on budgetary integrity.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and approved actions regarding the ECSEL Joint Undertaking’s 2015 financial management, granting discharge to its Executive Director while noting budgetary execution rates of 100% for commitments (€108.5 million) and 90.95% for payments (€168 million). It highlighted the Court of Auditors’ qualified opinion due to inconsistencies in national funding authorities’ (NFAs) audit methodologies for Seventh Framework Programme projects, though acknowledging this issue was resolved for Horizon 2020. Contributions totaled €1.18 billion from the EU, €1.17 billion from Participating States, and €1.66 billion from Private Members over Horizon 2020’s duration, with 2015 payments including €56 million from the EU and €15.8 million from only 11 of 28 Participating States. Private Members’ in-kind contributions reached €58.7 million, alongside €3.6 million in administrative cash contributions. The resolution noted internal audit risks in fraud management and ex-post controls but commended mitigation efforts, urged improved Participating State contributions, and called for the Commission to involve ECSEL in Horizon 2020’s mid-term review for procedural harmonization.

title: Discharge 2015: EU general budget - Committee of the Regions: REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015, Section VII – Committee of the Regions
background: The Committee of the Regions’ 2015 budget execution involved €88.9 million in administrative expenditure, with audit observations on procurement, gender imbalance in management, and cooperation agreements with the European Economic and Social Committee. The Parliament will discuss compliance with financial regulations and governance standards for granting discharge under EU budgetary rules.

stances.stance:
ECR rejects the discharge due to fundamental failures in addressing Council non-cooperation, contradicting transparency demands in Articles 12-14  
ECR opposes the issue's oversight of ENISA's unauthorized relocation costs, violating building policy rationalization clauses  
ECR fundamentally disputes the acceptance of underrepresentation in management tiers, conflicting with HR governance improvements under Section VII  
ECR condemns the failure to resolve systemic payment errors highlighted by the Court of Auditors, opposing budget approval despite Article 5 provisions  
ECR refuses endorsement while 2004+ member states' staff imbalances persist, contravening the issue's equality principles

GUE_NGL fundamentally agrees the issue’s emphasis on rigorous financial accountability, perfectly aligning with their unyielding stance against systemic payment errors and insufficient supervisory controls highlighted in the Court of Auditors’ findings.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with demands for urgent whistleblower case issues and harassment ruling follow-ups, reflecting their historic advocacy for institutional integrity and worker protections.  
GUE_NGL applauds the call for gender balance improvements and well-being initiatives, advancing their manifesto priorities for equitable workplaces and robust staff welfare frameworks.  
GUE_NGL underscores the necessity of performance-based budgeting with SMART targets, a measure that directly addresses their long-standing critique of opaque EU financial practices.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and recommendations regarding the Committee of the Regions’ (CoR) 2015 budget implementation, noting its €88.9 million budget (98.2% utilization rate) primarily allocated to administrative costs, including staff and operational expenses. It emphasized the need for performance-based budgeting (PBB) with SMART targets across departments and staff, while welcoming the CoR’s cooperation agreements with the European Economic and Social Committee (EESC) and Parliament, though urging clarity on "intensified" collaboration terms. Concerns included a 2015 payment execution rate decline linked to the CoR’s sixth term transition, gender imbalances in senior (25% female) and middle management (38% female), high staff sick leave rates, delayed IT project audits, and increased translation outsourcing (10% in 2015) requiring cost-effectiveness reviews. The resolution demanded transparency in members’ mission expenses, adherence to a future transparency register, and urgent resolution of whistleblower cases and harassment rulings, including follow-up on tribunal and OLAF reports. It praised environmental efforts (EMAS renewal) and rationalized building policies but called for improved HR governance, gender balance measures, and well-being initiatives to reduce absenteeism.

title: Discharge 2015: EU general budget - European Court of Auditors: REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015, Section V – Court of Auditors
background: The European Court of Auditors’ 2015 financial management, governed by EU treaties and the Financial Regulation, underwent standard audit procedures as part of the EU’s annual budgetary oversight. The Parliament will discuss granting discharge for the Court’s 2015 budget implementation, assessing compliance with administrative and financial accountability frameworks.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the issue's emphasis on performance-based budgeting with SMART targets, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to fiscal accountability and results-driven governance.  
EPP fundamentally approves the transparency measures including mandatory declarations of interest and whistleblowing rules, which effectively advance EPP's priority of institutional integrity and public trust.  
EPP proposes enhancing the EIB's reporting to include concrete data on SME funding accessibility as a minor refinement to strengthen performance evaluation frameworks.  
EPP strongly approves addressing gender and geographical imbalances in staffing through targeted recruitment strategies, consistent with EPP's equality and cohesion principles.  
EPP emphasizes the critical need to maintain accountability for past leadership irregularities, as highlighted in the issue, to uphold rigorous budgetary oversight standards.

ECR fundamentally doubts the discharge issue for failing to mandate stricter corrective measures on geographical imbalance in senior roles, inconsistent with their principle of equitable representation for post-2004 member states.  
ECR rejects the issue as it overlooks the ENISA relocation controversy, which they view as financial mismanagement the Court failed to audit adequately.  
ECR opposes the discharge due to unresolved systemic payment errors in the EU budget, highlighting the Court’s ineffective oversight role despite its mandate.  
ECR criticizes the issue’s silence on enforcing Council cooperation in the discharge process, a critical flaw in addressing transparency and accountability gaps.  
ECR deems the issue incompatible with fiscal responsibility by not addressing the 22nd consecutive year of error-ridden EU budget payments, a core ECR concern.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and recommendations regarding the Court of Auditors’ 2015 budget implementation, noting its final appropriations totaled €132.9 million (slightly lower than 2014’s €133.5 million) with a 98.68% execution rate. It emphasized the need for performance-based budgeting (PBB) with SMART targets across departments and welcomed the Court’s reform progress while urging a mid-term review of its 2013-2017 strategy. Parliament highlighted gender imbalance, with only 5 women among 28 Court members in 2015 and 30.4% female representation in senior/middle management, urging corrective measures. Geographical balance in staffing, particularly for post-2004 member states, was noted as improving but still lagging in higher-level roles. Concerns included delays in adopting EMAS environmental certification, high staff sick leave rates (with calls for revised calculation methods), and insufficient progress on a 2012-requested special report on conflicts of interest in EU agencies, which Parliament demanded by June 2017. Transparency measures, such as a mandatory transparency register, whistleblowing rules, and declarations of interest (vs. absence of conflicts), were stressed, alongside calls for stricter revolving door policies. The resolution urged rationalizing official vehicle use, improving translation directorate efficiency, and enhancing cooperation with universities on auditing education. It also pressed for clearer communication on the EU budget’s purpose to citizens and reiterated the Court’s role in auditing decentralized agencies without excessive administrative burdens.

title: Discharge 2015: EU general budget - European Court of Justic: REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015, Section IV – Court of Justice
background: The Court of Justice's 2015 budget execution, audited by the Court of Auditors, showed high utilization and structural reforms, including the Civil Service Tribunal's dissolution. The Parliament will discuss the institution's budgetary discharge, focusing on financial accountability and governance reforms.

stances.stance:
EPP totally upholds the issue's alignment with strict budgetary accountability and commends the Court of Justice’s 99% budget utilization as exemplary fiscal stewardship.  
EPP perfectly aligns with demands for enhanced judicial transparency through mandatory disclosure of judges’ external activities and independently evaluated conflict-of-interest declarations.  
EPP unequivocally supports the issue’s emphasis on addressing historical administrative irregularities, particularly those linked to former Parliament leadership, as vital to preserving institutional integrity.  
EPP applauds the Court’s caseload efficiency reforms, including the General Court expansion, which directly advances the EPP’s priority of effective EU judicial governance.  
EPP emphasizes the issue’s alignment with gender balance progress while urging accelerated efforts to rectify geographical representation gaps in line with EPP’s equity principles.

ECR rejects the issue's failure to implement enforceable measures addressing the under-representation of post-2004 member states in CJEU management roles, firmly disputeing with their demand for equitable geographical balance.  
ECR opposes the discharge due to the issue's omission of mechanisms to compel Council cooperation in budgetary oversight, a critical flaw contradicting ECR's insistence on institutional accountability.  
ECR fully disputes the budget approval while ENISA's unauthorized relocation expenditures persist, highlighting the issue's disregard for rigorous fiscal controls across EU agencies.  
ECR rejects the lack of binding reforms to reduce carryover appropriations and property-related financial irregularities, directly opposing their stance against budgetary mismanagement.  
ECR opposes the discharge as it ignores systemic transparency failures in evaluating judges' conflicts of interest, undermining judicial accountability principles central to ECR's agenda.

resolution: The European Parliament raised key points regarding the 2015 budget implementation and operations of the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU), noting its total appropriations of €357 million with a 99% utilization rate and €49.5 million in established entitlements (10.4% above estimates). It welcomed the Court of Auditors’ findings of no material errors in payments and no significant weaknesses in procurement or human resources. The CJEU’s judicial productivity was highlighted, with 1,711 new cases and 1,755 completed cases—the highest annual caseload in its history—though the Court of Justice itself saw a decline in completed cases (616 vs. 719 in 2014). Average case durations improved, including 15.3 months for preliminary rulings and 17.6 months for direct actions. The resolution emphasized reforms, such as doubling General Court judges by 2019, to enhance efficiency and reduce backlogs. Transparency concerns included calls for disclosing judges’ external activities, publishing lobbyist meeting details, and revising conflict-of-interest rules to require declarations evaluated independently. Gender balance in management reached 35-65%, while geographical imbalance persisted for post-2004 member states. Other points included high staff turnover (98% occupancy despite 5% reduction targets), improved e-Curia application usage by all member states, translation productivity gains (7% via outsourcing), environmental commitments, and requests for clarifications on mission budget underutilization (€41,209 spent of €295,500) and allowances. The Parliament urged stricter revolving door rules, carbon offsetting measures, and enhanced public communication.

title: Discharge 2015: EU general budget - European Data Protection Supervisor: REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015, Section IX – European Data Protection Supervisor
background: In 2015, the European Data Protection Supervisor managed an €8.76 million budget with 96% implementation rate, receiving its fourth consecutive clean audit while addressing internal control improvements and gender representation. The Parliament will discuss EDPS's budgetary execution, operational effectiveness, and regulatory compliance within EU data protection frameworks.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely sanctions the issue's recognition of the EDPS's exemplary budget management, perfectly aligning with their commitment to fiscal responsibility and efficient EU resource utilization.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the emphasis on developing SMART performance targets, viewing this as crucial for advancing accountability in line with their governance priorities.  
EPP fully supports the issue's call for enhanced transparency through public disclosure mechanisms, seeing this as vital to maintaining citizen trust in EU institutions.  
EPP strongly endorses the exemption request from staff reduction mandates, recognizing this as essential for maintaining the EDPS's capacity to handle growing digital privacy challenges.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the innovation imperative in data protection, viewing the issue's technology balance approach as advancing both competitiveness and fundamental rights.

ECR rejects the discharge approval for failing to address systemic payment errors and the Council's refusal to provide transparency, completely conflicting with ECR's demand for rigorous fiscal accountability.  
ECR opposes the issue's omission of ENISA's orchestrated relocation from Heraklion, which disregards contractual obligations and wastes public resources—a critical oversight in governance integrity.  
ECR condemns the lack of progress on fair representation of post-2004 member states in senior roles, a disparity the issue ignores despite ECR's emphasis on equitable EU institutional staffing.  
ECR rejects the endorsement of EDPS budgetary compliance while broader EU financial mismanagement—including delayed infrastructure projects and excessive carry-over appropriations—remains unscrutinized.  
ECR opposes the issue's focus on EDPS internal reforms as insufficient, given its failure to mandate conflict-of-interest disclosures or rectify gender imbalances in leadership tiers.

resolution: The European Parliament raised key points regarding the European Data Protection Supervisor’s (EDPS) 2015 budget implementation, noting a clean audit from the Court of Auditors for the fourth consecutive year, with no serious weaknesses identified in audited recruitment, procurement, or financial transactions. The EDPS’s 2015 budget totaled €8,760,417 (a 1.09% increase from 2014), achieving a 96% implementation rate and 86.5% utilization of payment appropriations. While welcoming improved financial management, Parliament highlighted concerns over three internal control objectives requiring substantial effort, particularly the need to develop SMART targets for performance-based budgeting (PBB) across departments. It noted a gender imbalance in middle management (40% female/60% male) and urged balanced recruitment, while commending low sick leave (6.6 days average) and staff well-being initiatives. Parliament acknowledged the EDPS’s adoption of a code of conduct but criticized its lack of conflict-of-interest rules, urging public disclosure of CVs, declarations of interest, and a conflict-of-interest track record. Transparency measures, such as publishing meetings with external entities and awarded contracts, were welcomed, though more detailed mission reports were requested. The resolution emphasized the EDPS’s advisory role in critical legislation, including the General Data Protection Regulation, EU-US Privacy Shield, and Europol reform, and its involvement in establishing the European Data Protection Board. It endorsed the EDPS’s 2015-2019 strategy and key performance indicators but called for clearer distinctions between internal and external metrics. Parliament urged exemption from a 5% staff reduction mandate due to increasing workloads, while welcoming compliance with transparency reforms, including whistleblowing rules (adopted June 2016) and future adherence to revolving door guidelines. Finally, it encouraged the EDPS to enhance privacy innovation in big data and emerging technologies, balancing innovation with fundamental rights protection.

title: Discharge 2015: EU general budget - European Economic and Social Committee: REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015, Section VI – European Economic and Social Committee
background: The European Economic and Social Committee’s 2015 budget execution faced scrutiny due to its €129 million allocation, 95.9% utilization rate, and audit findings on administrative expenditure. Institutional challenges included gender imbalances in senior management, procurement reforms, and cooperation agreements with other EU bodies. The Parliament will discuss compliance with budgetary procedures, operational efficiency, and accountability mechanisms.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the issue's emphasis on accountability for past administrative irregularities, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to fiscal transparency and institutional integrity.  
EPP applauds the integration of Court of Auditors' findings into budgetary oversight, proposing accelerated implementation of the 5% staff reduction plan to enhance operational efficiency.  
EPP approves the performance-based budgeting framework while urging stricter SMART target alignment across all EESC departments to maximize policy impact.  
EPP emphasizes the need to resolve gender and geographic staffing imbalances through measurable recruitment benchmarks, reinforcing equity principles central to EPP's agenda.  
EPP endorses anti-fraud collaboration and EMAS certification as critical steps toward public trust, matching EPP's 2015 manifesto priorities for ethical governance.

ECR rejects the discharge issue for failing to address the Council's systemic non-cooperation in budget oversight, which directly contradicts ECR's demands for institutional accountability.  
ECR opposes the issue's silence on persistent under-representation of post-2004 accession states in senior management roles, violating ECR's principle of equitable geographic representation.  
ECR fully disputes the ENISA relocation controversy, viewing the attempted move from Heraklion as a breach of prior operational agreements that the issue inadequately investigates.  
The issue overlooks critical audit findings about recurring payment errors flagged by the Court of Auditors, conflicting with ECR's fiscal rigor priorities.
