resolution: The European Parliament raised key observations on the European Economic and Social Committee’s (EESC) 2015 budget implementation, noting its €129.1 million budget (95.9% utilization rate, slightly higher than 2014) was predominantly administrative, with significant spending on personnel and operational costs. It welcomed the Court of Auditors’ finding of no material errors in payments and no significant weaknesses in human resources or procurement, while urging broader application of performance-based budgeting (PBB) with SMART targets across departments. The resolution highlighted the need to clarify and fully implement the 2015 Cooperation Agreement with Parliament, including joint assessments of budgetary savings, and called for streamlined integration of EESC opinions into parliamentary workflows. It noted gender (30% female senior management) and geographic imbalances in staffing, urging corrective measures, and expressed concern over high vacancy rates and delays in a 5% staff reduction plan. Administrative reforms, such as revised travel reimbursement systems and a members’ portal, were welcomed, alongside calls for transparency via a comparative travel expense overview and participation in a future Transparency Register. The resolution emphasized cost-efficiency in translation (10% outsourcing rate) and interpretation (3.5% unused services), supported anti-fraud cooperation, and praised environmental initiatives like EMAS certification. Concerns included inadequate sick-leave reporting, limited staff participation in well-being activities, and the need to prioritize policy impact over publicity in communications. Security-related building access closures and collaboration with the Committee of the Regions to avoid functional duplication were also addressed.

title: Discharge 2015: EU general budget - European External Action Service: REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015, Section X – European External Action Service
background: In 2015, the European External Action Service's budget increased by 16.2%, incorporating transferred Commission funds. The Court of Auditors identified weaknesses in delegation recruitment, procurement, and building management, highlighted in a 2016 report. The Parliament will discuss the EEAS's 2015 budget discharge, focusing on financial management, procurement, human resources, and building policies.

EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's transparency demands, reinforcing EPP's legacy of combating misinformation through fact-based governance as emphasized in Special Report 07/2016 adherence.  
EPP fully supports the call for streamlined budget discharge timelines, mirroring EPP's institutional reform priorities to strengthen parliamentary oversight credibility.  
EPP proposes enhancing public communication strategies for delegation achievements to maximize citizen engagement, building upon the issue's transparency provisions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and recommendations regarding the European External Action Service’s (EEAS) 2015 budget implementation, noting a low error rate of 0.6% in administrative spending but highlighting weaknesses in procurement and recruitment procedures for local agents in delegations, including lack of transparency and incorrect technical appraisals. The EEAS’s total 2015 budget was €602.8 million, a 16.2% increase from 2014, with €383.9 million allocated to delegations (primarily for buildings, staff, and administrative costs) and €218.9 million to headquarters (64.7% for salaries). Parliament urged simplification of fragmented funding sources, including Commission contributions from 33 budget lines, and noted imbalances in staffing, with 32.9% of AD staff from Member States (43.1% in delegations), underrepresentation of post-2004 Member States in leadership roles, and persistent gender disparities (21.4% female in management). It called for improved human resources policies, including gender balance, geographical equity, and training for heads of delegations. On building management, Parliament highlighted inefficiencies, including €7.8 million in unnecessary costs from underused spaces, and urged better co-location (86 projects by 2015) and use of the €200 million loan facility to reduce rental reliance (80% of delegations rented). It demanded stricter oversight of procurement, adherence to the Court of Auditors’ recommendations in Special Report 07/2016, and enhanced security and sustainability in building policies. Lastly, Parliament stressed the need for improved communication with citizens and transparency, including participation in a future EU Transparency Register.

title: Discharge 2015: EU general budget - European Ombudsman: REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015, Section VIII – European Ombudsman

The Parliament will discuss the institution’s 2015 budgetary implementation, focusing on financial accountability, governance practices, and operational effectiveness.

 While the issue advances key transparency goals, GUE_NGL’s debate argument opposes discharge due to unresolved budget errors, suggesting a tension between procedural approval and systemic critique.

resolution: The European Parliament raised key observations and decisions regarding the European Ombudsman’s 2015 budget implementation, noting the Court of Auditors found no significant weaknesses in human resources or procurement and confirmed administrative expenditures were free from material error. The Ombudsman’s budget totaled €10,346,105 (up from €9,857,024 in 2014), with 92.32% of appropriations committed and 86.19% paid, reflecting a declining utilization rate that prompted reductions in budget lines for missions, representation, and translations. Parliament urged wider application of performance-based budgeting (PBB) with SMART targets across departments and staff, while acknowledging the Ombudsman’s transparency leadership but calling for improved recruitment transparency, updated organizational charts, and clarified roles for senior advisers. It welcomed the Ombudsman’s investigations into "revolving door" cases and whistleblower protection rules but highlighted concerns over geographic imbalance in management (particularly overrepresentation from the Ombudsman’s home country) and requested analysis of compliance rates (90% in 2015) and reasons for non-compliance by EU institutions. Gender balance at management level was praised, while staff reduction plans (5% over five years) and new post creations in 2016 required clarification. Environmental efforts like EMAS compliance and green mobility were endorsed, alongside calls for carbon offsetting rules. Parliament also sought details on two 2015 data protection complaints, stressed the need for annual impact reports, and urged national ombudsmen and EU bodies to promote citizen awareness of the Ombudsman’s role in addressing maladministration.

title: Discharge 2015: Euratom Supply Agency (ESA): REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the Euratom Supply Agency for the financial year 2015
background: The Euratom Supply Agency's 2015 budget execution showed a 20.19% budget increase from 2014, with 95.2% EU-funded. The Court of Auditors reported reliable accounts but noted administrative expenditure carry-overs and procurement delays. The Agency processed 375 nuclear supply transactions and proposed rule updates to align with market practices. The Parliament will discuss compliance with financial regulations and budgetary accountability for the 2015 fiscal year.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the issue's emphasis on budgetary discipline and accountability, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to responsible management of EU funds.  
EPP applauds the Agency’s 98.92% commitment execution rate as evidence of operational efficiency while proposing enhanced procurement planning to reduce future carry-overs linked to DIGIT framework delays.  
EPP absolutely endorses the Court of Auditors’ validation of transactions, effectively advancing EPP’s priority of maintaining nuclear supply security through 375 verified safeguards.  
EPP recommends accelerating rule revision timelines to modernize market alignment practices beyond the current 1975 framework, reinforcing transparency without opposing the issue’s core objectives.  
EPP strongly approves performance-based budget reforms highlighted in cross-cutting observations, urging continued collaboration with the Court to improve payment execution rates.

ECR rejects the discharge procedure due to the Council's persistent refusal to provide essential transparency on budgetary errors and property expenditure carry-overs, firmly againsting with ECR's principle of institutional accountability.  
ECR opposes the issue's acceptance of €41,482 in administrative carry-overs for delayed IT procurement, deeming it inconsistent with strict annuality principles central to fiscal conservatism.  
ECR condemns the unresolved under-representation of 2004+ accession states in senior EU agency roles, directly contradicting their stance on equitable geographic distribution in governance.  
ECR opposes the ENISA relocation from Heraklion to Athens as a self-inflicted financial burden, rejecting its classification as necessary expenditure amid existing free infrastructure - a misalignment with prudent resource management.  
The proposal overlooks critical governance flaws in building policy delays and job-tier imbalances, conflicting with ECR's demands for operational efficiency and merit-based staffing parity.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and observations regarding the Euratom Supply Agency’s 2015 budget implementation, noting a final budget of €125,000 (a 20.19% increase from 2014), with 95.2% funded by the EU budget and 4.8% from agency revenues. It highlighted a 98.92% commitment appropriations execution rate (up 7.84% from 2014) but a 62.86% payment execution rate (down 18.27%), urging adherence to the principle of annuality. Carry-overs for administrative expenditure surged to €41,482 (50.5% of Title II), attributed to delayed IT hardware procurement and consulting services linked to delays in using the Commission’s DIGIT framework contracts. The Agency had 17 staff members (all Commission officials) and one vacant contractual agent post. It processed 375 transactions to ensure nuclear material supply security and proposed revising its rules (unchanged since 1975) to align with market practices, pledging updates to the discharge authority. The Parliament granted discharge based on the Court of Auditors’ assurance of reliable accounts and legal/regular transactions, while referencing broader cross-cutting observations in its resolution on agency performance and financial management.

title: Discharge 2015: European Agency for Safety and Health at Work (EU-OSHA): REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Agency for Safety and Health at Work for the financial year 2015
background: The European Agency for Safety and Health at Work (EU-OSHA) reported a 2.34% budget reduction in 2015, with increased EU contributions. The Court of Auditors verified legal regularity but noted administrative expenditure carry-overs and staffing reductions aligned with EU efficiency policies. The Parliament will discuss EU-OSHA’s 2015 budgetary compliance, operational execution, and governance frameworks.

stances.stance:
ECR rejects the discharge approval due to unresolved Council non-cooperation in budget oversight, fully opposeing with transparency demands.  
ECR opposes the closure of accounts as it ignores under-representation of post-2004 Member States in managerial roles, violating equity principles.  
The issue overlooks critical procurement irregularities in ENISA’s relocation, which ECR deems a misuse of allocated resources.  
ECR condemns the failure to address high carry-over rates (40.80% operational), inconsistent with fiscal responsibility commitments.  
This discharge fully opposes with ECR’s stance on anti-fraud enforcement, lacking whistleblowing rules for external staff.

GUE_NGL totally endorses the issue’s approval of the 2015 discharge, as it perfectly aligns with their unwavering commitment to institutional accountability and rigorous adherence to legal-financial standards.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the critical importance of the Court of Auditors’ assurance on transaction legality, viewing this as foundational to their demand for error-free budgetary execution and systemic control reforms.  
GUE_NGL applauds the issue’s recognition of the Agency’s anti-fraud strategy and IT security advancements, which directly advance their manifesto priorities for transparency and worker-centric digital tools.  
GUE_NGL highlights the budgetary transfers and procurement framework as exemplary practices in responsive resource management, urging further reinforcement of open-procedure ratios to match their equity principles.  
GUE_NGL underscores the necessity of continuous oversight on workplace safety initiatives like OiRA, aligning with their strategic focus on preemptive risk mitigation and age-inclusive labor policies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised key points regarding the European Agency for Safety and Health at Work’s 2015 financial management, noting a final budget of €16,852,526 (a 2.34% decrease from 2014) with a 97.5% implementation rate, though payment execution fell to 72.1%. It acknowledged the Agency’s adoption of activity-based budgeting and progress on an e-tool for resource management, while highlighting high carry-over rates for administrative (25.56%) and operational (40.80%) expenditures, attributed to multi-year contracts and delayed projects. The Parliament approved the closure of the 2015 accounts, citing the Court of Auditors’ assurance on their legality and regularity, and noted €723,300 in budgetary transfers to address resource needs. Procurement totaled €7.9 million, with 16.64% via open procedures and 64.73% through framework contracts. Staff reductions (5%) aligned with EU austerity measures, though concerns persisted over compliance with the 2004 Staff Regulation. The Agency adopted an anti-fraud strategy (2015–2018) but lacked whistleblowing rules, prompting calls to expand conflict-of-interest policies to external staff and ensure transparency. IT security improvements and a redesigned multilingual website with an OSH wiki were commended. The Agency’s role in advancing the EU Strategic Framework on Health and Safety at Work 2014–2020, including pilot projects like ‘Safer work at any age’ and the Online interactive Risk Assessment (OiRA), was recognized, alongside calls to monitor workplace safety and propose enhancements.

title: Discharge 2015: European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union (Frontex): REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union (now European Border and Coast Guard Agency (Frontex)) for the financial year 2015
background: The European Border and Coast Guard Agency (Frontex) received a 46% budget increase in 2015 for Mediterranean operations, with the EU Court of Auditors identifying accounting errors in maritime surveillance costs and irregular reimbursements to member states. The Parliament will discuss Frontex’s 2015 financial compliance, budget execution, and operational accountability.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the issue's emphasis on budgetary accountability and enhanced operational transparency, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to rigorous financial oversight of EU agencies.  
EPP applauds the recognition of Frontex's life-saving maritime operations and proposes accelerating whistleblower rule implementation to further strengthen governance frameworks.  
EPP endorses the call for simplified cost mechanisms between Member States, effectively advancing EPP's priority of eliminating redundant expenditures in border management programs.  
EPP recommends enhancing performance reporting metrics in future discharge procedures to better quantify border security outcomes, building on the Court of Auditors' methodological improvements.  
EPP urges continued prioritization of conflict-of-interest policy reforms while maintaining full support for the Agency's expanded search-and-rescue capabilities demonstrated during the Mediterranean crisis.

ECR rejects the discharge approval due to the Council’s systemic lack of cooperation in budgetary oversight, fully conflicting with ECR’s demands for institutional transparency and accountability.  
ECR opposes the issue’s failure to address high carryover rates (38% administrative, 35% operational) and €1.4 million overpayment irregularities, which exemplify fiscal negligence incompatible with rigorous financial stewardship.  
ECR condemns the under-representation of post-2004 Member States in leadership roles, a governance imbalance directly contradicting ECR’s principle of equitable geographical representation in EU agencies.  
ECR fully conflicts with the relocation of ENISA’s operations to Athens despite available infrastructure in Heraklion, reflecting reckless resource allocation unaddressed by the issue’s oversight mechanisms.  
ECR highlights the unresolved €800,000 non-recovery from Iceland and delayed whistleblower rules as critical failures in accountability, undermining the issue’s claims of effective budgetary control.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the European Border and Coast Guard Agency’s (formerly Frontex) 2015 financial management, noting a 46.31% budget increase to €143.3 million, driven by Mediterranean operations (€28 million). While the Court of Auditors affirmed the legality and regularity of transactions, it issued a qualified opinion due to a €1.7 million underestimation of accrued maritime surveillance costs, which misstated financial statements but did not involve misspent funds. Irregularities included a €1.4 million overpayment to Iceland for vessel depreciation, with partial recovery of €600,000. The Parliament highlighted risks of double funding under the Internal Security Fund (ISF) and urged simplified cost mechanisms to address divergent reimbursement practices among Member States. Despite a 99.86% budget execution rate, carryovers remained high (38% for administrative expenses, 35% for operational), attributed to multiyear contracts and IT projects. Governance shortcomings included insufficient conflict-of-interest policies, delayed whistleblower rules, and a 93% male-dominated management board. The Agency was commended for saving over 250,000 lives at sea, enhancing search-and-rescue capacity, and cooperating with Europol on migration and security, while being urged to strengthen fundamental rights safeguards, internal controls, and strategic planning with measurable outcomes.

title: Discharge 2015: European Agency for the operational management of large-scale IT systems in the area of freedom, security and justice (eu-LISA): REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Agency for the Οperational Management of Large-Scale IT Systems in the Area of Freedom, Security and Justice for the financial year 2015
background: The European Agency for the operational management of large-scale IT systems (eu-LISA) faced a 13.77% budget increase in 2015, with the Court of Auditors identifying procurement compliance gaps, data security incidents, and challenges in securing Schengen-associated countries' financial contributions. The Parliament will discuss budgetary discharge procedures and financial governance compliance for EU agencies.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly promotes the transparency measures requiring publication of contracts exceeding €15,000, aligning perfectly with their commitment to open governance and bolstering public trust in EU institutions.  
ALDE approves the emphasis on rigorous budget oversight and reduced administrative carry-overs, which reflect their priorities for fiscal efficiency and accountability in EU agencies.  
ALDE applauds the progress in implementing anti-fraud frameworks and urges finalization to fully align with their manifesto’s focus on institutional integrity and corruption prevention.  
ALDE proposes strengthening procurement rules to explicitly require competitive tendering, addressing irregularities while maintaining strong support for the issue’s objectives.  
ALDE highlights the necessity of accelerating gender balance initiatives in management roles to uphold equitable representation principles central to ALDE’s values.

ECR absolutely againsts the discharge approval due to unresolved procurement irregularities and lack of explicit compliance with EU financial rules, directly conflicting with ECR's mandate for stringent fiscal oversight.  
ECR rejects the Agency's budgetary management citing excessive carry-over reductions achieved through questionable negotiated procedures, undermining transparency and anti-corruption safeguards.  
ECR condemns the persistent gender imbalance (33% female staff) and incomplete Schengen country contributions as institutional failures contradicting ECR's equality and fiscal responsibility principles.  
ECR highlights ENISA's controversial relocation attempts from Heraklion as wasteful operational mismanagement, demanding maintained EU agency decentralization.   
ECR opposes the discharge until post-2004 Member States achieve proportional representation in leadership roles, reflecting systemic governance inequities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns while granting discharge to the European Agency for the Operational Management of Large-Scale IT Systems (eu-LISA) for its 2015 budget, noting a €67.56 million budget (13.77% increase from 2014) fully funded by the EU. It acknowledged the Court of Auditors’ assurance on the legality and reliability of transactions but highlighted irregularities, including a €2 million framework contract for procurement services lacking explicit compliance with financial rules and a €20 million negotiated procedure launched without proper delegation, risking inefficiency and corruption. The Agency achieved a 99.68% budget implementation rate and 99.4% payment execution, with reduced carry-overs (€9 million for administrative expenses, down from €15 million in 2014). Concerns persisted over incomplete financial contributions from Schengen Associated Countries to administrative costs and gender imbalance (33% female staff). The Parliament urged improved procurement practices, finalization of anti-fraud measures (60% implemented by 2016), adoption of whistleblowing policies, and transparency in conflicts of interest. It noted two 2015 data breaches, mitigated by enhanced security protocols, and welcomed headquarters agreements with France and Estonia. Performance indicators adopted in 2015 were deemed insufficient to reflect impacts on migration and security, prompting calls for better resource monitoring and public visibility. The Agency’s progress in internal controls and staff training was acknowledged, but further alignment with EU financial regulations and gender balance in management were emphasized.

title: Discharge 2015: European Asylum Support Office (EASO): REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Asylum Support Office for the financial year 2015
background: In 2015, the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) operated amid unprecedented migration flows, managing EU asylum coordination and crisis response mechanisms. The agency's expanded mandate under the European Agenda on Migration included hotspot support, while audits highlighted prior administrative challenges in procurement and staffing. The Parliament will discuss EASO's budgetary execution and compliance with financial regulations.

stances.stance:
ECR rejects the discharge issue due to the Council’s refusal to provide critical information on budgetary weaknesses, fundamentally challengeing with ECR’s demand for transparent EU financial oversight.  
ECR opposes the closure of accounts for perpetuating excessive administrative carry-overs (€1.08 million) and infrastructure delays, contradicting ECR’s principles of fiscal accountability and operational efficiency.  
ECR fundamentally challenges with the issue’s failure to address under-representation of post-2004 Member States in managerial roles, opposing ECR’s stance on equitable governance within EU institutions.  
ECR rejects the issue’s approval as it overlooks ENISA’s contentious relocation costs, highlighting imprudent resource allocation inconsistent with ECR’s fiscal responsibility commitments.  
ECR opposes the discharge for tolerating persistent late payments (29.2% of transactions), which undermines ECR’s advocacy for strict compliance and anti-fraud measures in EU spending.

GUE_NGL firmly endorses the issue’s emphasis on corrective actions and improved budget compliance, aligning with their longstanding commitment to fiscal accountability in asylum governance.  
GUE_NGL proposes strengthening audit transparency by requiring quarterly public reports on error-rate reduction progress, directly addressing the 3.8% irregularity pattern noted since 2007.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with demands for robust whistleblower protections, urging immediate implementation of encrypted reporting channels to enhance anti-fraud measures.  
GUE_NGL supports accelerated recruitment policy reforms to eliminate procedural irregularities while preserving the Office’s 63% female staffing parity as a model achievement.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the need for real-time public disclosure of Management Board conflicts of interest to fully realize transparency objectives in crisis operations.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and observations regarding the European Asylum Support Office’s (EASO) 2015 budget implementation, approving the closure of its accounts while noting a final budget of €15.9 million (a 1.76% increase from 2014, with 94% funded by the EU). It acknowledged the Court of Auditors’ assurance of reliable accounts and legal transactions but highlighted persistent issues from 2012–2014, including late payments (29.2% of transactions, averaging 29 days delay), recruitment irregularities, and high staff turnover, urging corrective actions by 2017. Budget execution improved to 93.74%, with administrative carry-overs at €1.08 million (36.9%), linked to ICT and staffing needs amid the migration crisis. Staffing included 93 members (63% female), with reforms in recruitment policies for temporary agents. The Office supported Member States through training (3,611 officers), emergency operations in Greece and Italy, and managing a record 1.4 million asylum applications. Transparency shortcomings included delayed publication of management CVs and incomplete conflict-of-interest declarations by some Management Board members. Performance highlights included 117 meetings, 272 relocations, and 17,000 country-of-origin documents, though the Parliament urged better communication of impacts, improved payment compliance, and stronger anti-fraud measures, including whistleblower protections.

title: Discharge 2015: European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA): REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Aviation Safety Agency for the financial year 2015
background: The European Aviation Safety Agency's 2015 budget execution followed an 11.58% budget increase, with 18.27% funded by EU contributions. The Court of Auditors issued a report validating accounts but noted administrative expenditure carryovers and procurement planning challenges. The Parliament will discuss compliance with financial regulations and governance standards for EU agencies.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the issue's emphasis on anti-fraud measures and financial accountability, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to rigorous EU budget oversight.  
EPP applauds EASA's 98% budget implementation rate and 20% operational cost reductions through headquarters optimization as exemplary models of fiscal responsibility.  
EPP proposes enhancing gender balance provisions in Management Board appointments to strengthen governance while fully endorsing the issue's workforce management achievements.  
EPP approves the strategic focus on emerging aviation challenges like drone regulation, urging accelerated resource allocation to maintain Europe's safety leadership.  
EPP highlights procurement planning improvements as an enhancement opportunity, suggesting quarterly progress reports to complement existing transparency frameworks.

ECR rejects the discharge issue due to unresolved under-representation of post-2004 Member States in managerial roles, directly conflicting with ECR's principle of equitable EU governance.  
ECR opposes the issue's endorsement of excessive carry-over expenditures (€4.4 million administrative, €2 million operational), reflecting systemic financial mismanagement contrary to ECR's fiscal accountability mandates.  
ECR completely disputes with the lack of Council transparency and cooperation in budgetary oversight, a failure that undermines ECR's core demand for rigorous EU institutional accountability.  
ECR highlights the unresolved ENISA relocation controversy as emblematic of opaque resource allocation, rejecting budget approvals while such geographically discriminatory practices persist.  
The proposal overlooks critical deficiencies in addressing staffing imbalances and institutional transparency gaps, opposing ECR's commitment to fair representation and anti-fraud rigor in EU agencies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and observations regarding the European Aviation Safety Agency’s (EASA) 2015 budget implementation, noting a final budget of €204.9 million (an 11.58% increase from 2014), with 18.27% funded by the EU. It acknowledged a 98% budget implementation rate and 91% payment execution, alongside reduced staff costs (53% of the budget) due to turnover and delayed recruitment, while administrative expenses rose to €21.9 million (15.7% of the budget) for relocation and IT investments. Carry-overs for administrative (€4.4 million) and operational (€2 million) expenditures were linked to multi-year projects and IT developments. Recruitment efforts included 24 hires from reserve lists and 113 selection procedures, achieving full staffing, with 79.5% of roles operational. Procurement involved 33 major procedures and 350 framework contracts, though planning needed improvement. Anti-fraud measures were praised, with no fraud reported, but transparency gaps remained in conflict-of-interest declarations and lobbyist interactions. Internal audits confirmed compliance, though gender imbalance on the Management Board (23% female) was criticized. The resolution stressed EASA’s critical role in aviation safety, urging adequate resources for emerging challenges like drones, and highlighted cost savings from its new headquarters (20% lower costs) and adoption of a 2016-2020 strategic plan.

title: Discharge 2015: European Banking Authority (EBA): REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Banking Authority for the financial year 2015
background: The European Banking Authority’s 2015 budget saw a 0.54% decrease, funded by EU and member state contributions, amid operational challenges from budget cuts and euro-pound volatility. Post-UK referendum uncertainties raised concerns over its London-based operations and contractual liabilities. The Parliament will discuss the EBA’s 2015 financial governance, Brexit-related risks, and funding structure adequacy.

stances.stance:
EPP firmly approves the issue's emphasis on budgetary discipline and transparency, perfectly aligning with EPP's longstanding commitment to rigorous financial oversight and accountability in EU agencies.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the call to shift EBA's funding model to EU sources and market fees, advancing EPP's priority of reducing fragmented national contributions while proposing strengthened safeguards against exchange rate volatility impacts.  
EPP firmly approves the demand for immediate publication of management body CVs and meeting minutes, recognizing this as critical to reinforcing public trust in banking supervision frameworks.  
EPP strongly sanctions the issue's Brexit contingency measures, particularly its focus on mitigating relocation risks through proactive lease renegotiation strategies that protect taxpayer funds.  
EPP applauds the emphasis on inter-agency cooperation to reduce operational costs, mirroring EPP's 2015 manifesto goals for streamlined EU financial governance.

ECR rejects the discharge issue due to the Council's refusal to cooperate in budgetary oversight, firmly againsting with ECR's principles of institutional transparency and accountability.  
ECR opposes the issue's approval for ignoring persistent financial mismanagement in high carryover rates and property project delays, contradicting reported improvements in the EBA's budget execution.  
ECR disputes the issue's adequacy in addressing under-representation of post-2004 Member States in senior management roles, a critical governance failure overlooked in staff statistics.  
ECR condemns the issue's silence on ENISA's controversial relocation costs, reflecting broader concerns about agency financial mismanagement absent from Brexit-related risk assessments.  
ECR opposes the discharge process for failing to rectify systemic opacity in EU decision-making, exemplified by unresolved transparency gaps despite the issue's emphasis on accountability.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined key decisions regarding the European Banking Authority’s (EBA) 2015 operations, noting its €33.4 million budget (a 0.54% decrease from 2014, funded 40% by the EU and 60% by Member States) and the Court of Auditors’ confirmation of reliable accounts and legal transactions. Despite a 99.34% budget implementation rate and 89.70% payment execution, a 6% budget cut forced delays in work programs and reduced participation in key forums like the Basel Committee. A €1.9 million budget amendment was necessitated by GBP/EUR exchange rate volatility. Staff increased to 156 (45% female), with improved carryover rates (9.7% in 2015, down from 15.9% in 2014), though transparency gaps remained, including unpublished CVs of management bodies. Post-Brexit risks were highlighted, including the EBA’s London lease (break clause penalty of €3.2 million) and potential relocation costs, urging transparent decision-making. The Parliament criticized the EBA’s reliance on national contributions, advocating a shift to EU funding and market participant fees. It called for timely publication of meeting minutes (currently delayed by three months), enhanced whistleblower protections, and stricter adherence to mandates, emphasizing proportionality and stakeholder involvement in regulatory processes. Performance audits noted manageable HR and IT recommendations, while cooperation with other EU agencies was encouraged to reduce costs.

title: Discharge 2015: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC): REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control for the financial year 2015
background: The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) managed a 2015 budget of €58.45 million, primarily EU-funded, amid cross-border health threats like Ebola and Zika. Audit reports identified procurement transparency gaps, currency risks from operating in Sweden (non-Eurozone), and staffing delays. The Parliament will discuss granting discharge for the agency’s 2015 budget implementation.

stances.stance:
EPP completely agrees the issue's rigorous validation of ECDC's financial accountability mechanisms, perfectly aligning with their commitment to transparent EU fund management.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's commendation of ECDC's crisis response frameworks, reflecting their prioritization of robust continental health security systems.  
EPP completely agrees the emphasis on procurement procedure enhancements as critical opportunities to strengthen institutional trustworthiness in line with EPP anti-corruption principles.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's approval of ECDC's conflict-of-interest safeguards, reinforcing their longstanding advocacy for ethical governance standards.  
EPP completely agrees the proposed impact indicator development as a natural progression of their performance-driven agenda for EU agency effectiveness.

ECR rejects the discharge approval due to unresolved Council non-cooperation in budget oversight, firmly disputeing with ECR's demands for institutional accountability and transparency.  
ECR opposes the issue’s failure to address ENISA’s unjustified relocation plans from Heraklion, which contradicts ECR’s commitment to equitable regional development and fiscal responsibility.  
ECR highlights the omission of measures to rectify under-representation of post-2004 Member States in senior roles, directly opposing ECR’s principle of fair representation in EU governance.  
ECR condemns the lack of actionable solutions for excessive budgetary carry-overs and procurement opacity, conflicting with ECR’s stringent anti-waste standards.  
 ECR’s emphasis on structural accountability gaps and regional equity underscores total misalignment with the issue’s narrow focus on procedural compliance.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the approval of the 2015 budget discharge for the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), noting its final budget of €58.45 million (a 3.36% decrease from 2014), with 97.03% funded by the EU. It acknowledged the Court of Auditors’ assurance of reliable accounts and legal transactions but highlighted procurement transparency weaknesses, including insufficient links to annual work programs and inadequate financial benchmarks. The budget implementation rate was 94.05%, with payment execution at 76.27%, impacted by delayed recruitment and exchange rate risks from operating in Sweden (a non-Eurozone country). Carry-overs for administrative (23%, €1.6 million) and operational (42%, €7.5 million) expenditures were justified by multi-annual projects. Staff decreased to 260 statutory posts, with temporary and contract agents totaling 260, alongside delayed senior recruitment. The resolution commended ECDC’s conflict-of-interest policies, internal controls, and efforts during health crises like Ebola, Zika, and MERS-CoV, noting 88 notifications via the Early Warning System leading to 280 exchanges. It urged stricter procurement checks, proactive transparency with lobbyists, and development of impact indicators to measure effectiveness, while endorsing continued stakeholder engagement and efficiency improvements through Lean methodology.

title: Discharge 2015: European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training (Cedefop): REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training for the financial year 2015
background: The European Centre for Vocational Training (Cedefop), funded by the EU budget, faced a 6.27% budget increase in 2015 alongside structural risks from its building’s location on an active fault line, requiring repairs. The Parliament will discuss Cedefop’s 2015 financial management, building safety compliance, and operational accountability.

stances.stance:
EPP fundamentally accepts the issue's recognition of Cedefop's exemplary budget implementation and its alignment with EU vocational training priorities, perfectly reflecting EPP's commitment to fiscal responsibility and educational advancement.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on structural risk mitigation, applauding Cedefop's proactive measures in addressing seismic safety concerns as a model for institutional accountability.  
EPP commends the issue's focus on gender balance within Cedefop's leadership, highlighting this achievement as a testament to EPP's unwavering advocacy for equality in EU agencies.  
EPP fully supports the Court of Auditors' validated findings on Cedefop's financial management, reinforcing EPP's longstanding dedication to transparent and lawful use of EU taxpayer funds.  
EPP celebrates Cedefop's contributions to the European Skills Panorama and Riga Conclusions, recognizing these initiatives as critical advancements in EPP's skills-based growth agenda.

ECR rejects the discharge issue for fundamentally failing to address systemic financial mismanagement evidenced by excessive 28% administrative expenditure carry-overs and unresolved building safety liabilities.  
ECR opposes the lack of transparency in Council cooperation, directly contradicting accountability principles by withholding essential answers about property policy errors and delayed infrastructure projects.  
ECR condemns the persistent under-representation of post-2004 Member States in senior roles, rendering the issue's gender balance claims incompatible with geographic equity priorities.  
ECR highlights unresolved structural risks from the Centre's fault-line location as indicative of broader negligence in EU agency oversight, despite 2016 facade repairs.  
 While the ENISA relocation debate exceeds Cedefop's scope, ECR views agency displacement patterns as symptomatic of flawed EU resource allocation requiring unified opposition.

resolution: The European Parliament raised key points regarding the European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training (Cedefop) in its 2015 resolution, noting its budget of €18,356,560 (a 6.27% increase from 2014) fully funded by the EU. It acknowledged the Court of Auditors’ assurance on the reliability of accounts and legality of transactions, while highlighting a 98.55% budget implementation rate and a 28% carry-over for administrative expenditures (€477,994), largely due to delayed IT equipment deliveries for building refurbishment. The Centre executed 57 budget transfers (€586,100) within financial rules and increased procurement procedures by 32% (70 total), with 79% negotiated. Gender balance was emphasized, with 61% female staff, including management. Structural risks from the Centre’s location on an active fault line were addressed through completed repairs (2015) and ongoing safety measures, though concerns persisted over glass façade and skylight integrity, with repairs finalized in 2016 and liability discussions with Greek authorities ongoing. The resolution commended Cedefop’s contributions to EU vocational training policies, including the European Skills and Jobs Survey and Skills Panorama, aligning with Riga Conclusions priorities (2015–2020). It urged vigilance on salary adjustments to avoid negative staff impacts, noted internal restructuring under the Commission’s DG Employment, and called for enhanced performance measurement, transparency in conflict-of-interest declarations, and updates on building safety and financial liability.

title: Discharge 2015: European Chemicals Agency (ECHA): REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Chemicals Agency for the financial year 2015
background: The European Chemicals Agency’s 2015 budget execution, governed by REACH and financial regulations, underwent Court of Auditors review, noting fee income reliance, staffing challenges in biocides, and transparency measures. The Parliament will discuss compliance with budgetary rules, financial management, and operational effectiveness in fulfilling chemical safety mandates.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the Court of Auditors’ validation of ECHA’s financial reliability, aligning perfectly with EPP’s longstanding commitment to rigorous fiscal accountability and taxpayer fund stewardship.  
EPP applauds the Agency’s 95% document accessibility rate under Regulation 1049/2001 as matching their 2023 manifesto pledge for institutional transparency, while proposing standardized metrics to quantify regulatory strategy impacts on sustainability goals.  
EPP approves the justified carryovers for IT modernization under Title IV, urging accelerated recruitment to address biocides workload challenges without opposing the current staffing framework.  
EPP endorses the issue’s emphasis on fee-based financing effectiveness, advocating for expanded performance indicators to demonstrate SME support linkages to Europe 2020 targets.  
EPP proposes formalizing staff childcare subsidy protocols in future financial disclosures to preempt audit observations, reinforcing ECHA’s compliance with budgetary rules.

ECR fundamentally rejects the discharge approval due to systemic accountability failures in Council cooperation, contradicting their transparency principles  
ECR rejects the issue for perpetuating under-representation of post-2004 Member States in senior posts, violating fair governance commitments  
ECR condemns the handling of ENISA's relocation as budget misuse, inconsistent with fiscal responsibility despite being unrelated to ECHA's direct mandate  
ECR opposes legitimizing error-prone payment systems flagged by auditors, conflicting with their anti-waste manifesto pledges  
ECR disputes the closure validity given unresolved carryover irregularities in property expenditures, undermining financial oversight

resolution: The European Parliament raised key points regarding the European Chemicals Agency’s (ECHA) 2015 operations, approving the closure of its accounts with a final budget of €114,412,841 (a 0.26% increase from 2014) and granting discharge to its Executive Director. The Agency’s funding included €7.3 million in EU subsidies, €5.4 million from biocides fees (up from €1.3 million in 2014), and €307,791 from EFTA contributions. Budget execution reached 98.48%, with 87.84% of payment appropriations utilized. The EIT’s 2015 budget was €266.57 million (a 14.35% increase from 2014), with €215.03 million from the EU (26.63% higher than 2014). Staffing reached 59 out of 63 authorized posts, though salary challenges in Hungary persisted. The EIT’s partial financial autonomy since 2011 and ongoing efforts for full autonomy were noted, alongside concerns about coordination with EU programs and irregularities in KIC expenditures, including excessive performance-based remuneration (€646,000) and high procurement costs. The Parliament emphasized compliance with Horizon 2020 rules, sound financial management, and stronger accountability mechanisms.

background: The European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction's 2015 budget increased by 18.15%, primarily from own revenue and IPA funds, with 79.9% EU-funded. The Court of Auditors confirmed reliable accounts but identified procurement irregularities, prompting corrective actions. The Parliament will discuss the agency's 2015 budget discharge, focusing on financial compliance and operational governance.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly agrees the issue’s emphasis on transparency in budgetary execution and procurement oversight, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s longstanding commitment to institutional accountability and public trust.  
ALDE applauds the publication of high-value contracts exceeding €15,000 as a critical step toward reinforcing transparency, matching their 2015 priorities for EU agency operational integrity.  
ALDE welcomes the improved commitment and payment implementation rates, which demonstrate the Centre’s progress in aligning financial practices with efficiency goals central to ALDE’s fiscal policy agenda.  
ALDE proposes enhancing real-time monitoring of procurement ceilings to prevent future contractual breaches, ensuring strict adherence to financial safeguards without opposing the issue’s core approval.  
ALDE commends the Centre’s anti-fraud strategy and audit compliance as exemplary measures that advance ALDE’s vision of robust, fraud-resistant EU governance frameworks.

ECR rejects the discharge due to unresolved systemic financial mismanagement and lack of Council accountability, contradicting their demand for rigorous budgetary oversight.  
ECR opposes the issue for failing to address under-representation of post-2004 member states in EU agencies' leadership roles, a core ECR equity principle.  
ECR fully doubts with the discharge approval as it ignores ENISA's unauthorized relocation attempts, undermining regional development commitments.  
The proposal overlooks critical audit deficiencies highlighted by the Court of Auditors, perpetuating error-prone payment practices ECR vehemently condemns.  
ECR demands rejection until procurement breaches and administrative carry-over issues receive stricter sanctions aligned with their fiscal responsibility mandate.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and acknowledged the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction’s (EMCDDA) 2015 financial management, noting its final budget of €18,519,843 (an 18.15% increase from 2014, driven by €5 million from property sales and €600,000 in IPA 5 funds), with 79.9% sourced from the EU budget. It highlighted a 99.83% commitment implementation rate and 97.35% payment execution rate, alongside reduced administrative carry-overs (8% in 2015 vs. 26% in 2014) and 93.69% utilization of prior-year funds. The Parliament noted a procurement breach where a framework contract exceeded its €250,000 ceiling by 50% (totaling €382,181), prompting contract termination and improved monitoring processes. It welcomed the Centre’s anti-fraud strategy (2016), internal audit compliance, and closure of a 2013 audit recommendation, while urging action on six IT project management audit findings. Staff allocation was 68.56% operational, 20.68% administrative, and 10.76% neutral. The Centre’s achievements included 45 publications, 300 event contributions, 27 scientific articles, and identification of 98 new psychoactive substances, with emphasis on monitoring online drug supply. Cooperation with EU agencies, particularly in Justice/Home Affairs and health, was praised, alongside cost-sharing synergies. The Parliament encouraged a longer-term strategy beyond 2016–2018, enhanced ICT alignment, and broader dissemination of results via digital tools, while affirming the Centre’s critical role in drug threat assessment and public health protection.

title: Discharge 2015: European Network and Information Security Agency (ENISA): REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Union Agency for Network and Information Security for the financial year 2015
background: The European Union Agency for Network and Information Security (ENISA) faced challenges in 2015, including budget execution, staff recruitment difficulties due to contract types and Greek salary coefficients, transparency gaps in management disclosures, and operational inefficiencies from maintaining dual offices in Heraklion and Athens. The Parliament will discuss ENISA’s 2015 budgetary implementation, governance compliance, and measures to address administrative and transparency shortcomings.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the issue's emphasis on budgetary discipline, aligning with our commitment to rigorous financial oversight as demonstrated by ENISA's 100% budget implementation and reduced carry-overs.  
EPP applauds the focus on operational efficiency through office consolidation in Athens, proposing enhanced interagency collaboration to maximize relocation cost savings while maintaining cybersecurity preparedness.  
EPP endorses strict transparency reforms, urging immediate publication of management board members' updated declarations of interest and CVs to reinforce public trust in EU agencies' governance structures.  
EPP emphasizes the critical need to modernize ENISA's recruitment framework, suggesting targeted EU salary adjustments for specialized IT security roles to address Greece's market limitations.  
EPP firmly rejects attempts to obscure past institutional irregularities, affirming Parliament's duty to uphold accountability through unmodified discharge reports that name specific governance failures.

ECR rejects the discharge due to unresolved governance failures, particularly the unjustified relocation of ENISA's offices which contradicts fiscal responsibility principles.  
ECR opposes the issue's handling of staffing imbalances, as newer Member States remain underrepresented in managerial roles, undermining equitable resource management.  
ECR absolutely againsts with the issue's acceptance of ENISA's relocation costs, which were artificially inflated by leadership decisions against available infrastructure in Heraklion.  
The proposal overlooks critical transparency deficits, such as unpublished management board CVs and interest declarations, eroding accountability.  
ECR condemns the lack of Council cooperation in addressing high budgetary carry-overs and delayed projects, reflecting systemic mismanagement.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and observations regarding the European Union Agency for Network and Information Security (ENISA) based on its 2015 financial management, noting a final budget of €10,064,274 (a 3.37% increase from 2014) with a 92.89% payment execution rate, up 7.28% from 2014. It acknowledged ENISA’s 100% budget implementation and reduced carry-overs (7% in 2015 vs. 15% in 2014), including €150,000 for administrative expenditures, linked to planned IT investments. Staffing challenges were highlighted, with 69 employees, 17 new hires, and difficulties in recruitment due to contract types and low salary coefficients in Greece. Transparency issues included the lack of published CVs and updated declarations of interest for management board members (except the chair) and the absence of a proactive lobby policy. The Agency was urged to adopt whistleblowing rules by 2017, ensure staff protections, and report cases annually. Relocation costs for consolidating offices in Athens (€360,000 for 14 staff and furniture) were noted, urging resolution to improve efficiency. Internal controls showed progress, with one audit recommendation closed in 2015 and ex-post checks on 70.99% of 2014 transactions. The Court of Auditors affirmed the reliability of accounts, though ENISA was called to enhance governance, accountability, and risk management.

title: Discharge 2015: European Police College (CEPOL): REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Police College (now European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Training) (CEPOL) for the financial year 2015
background: The European Police College (CEPOL) relocated from the UK to Hungary in 2014, impacting 2015 budget execution with high implementation rates, payment delays, and carry-overs for new contracts, alongside a counter-terrorism training grant. The Parliament will discuss compliance with financial regulations and operational transparency in CEPOL’s 2015 budget discharge.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the issue's emphasis on enhancing transparency and accountability measures, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to rigorous fiscal oversight and institutional integrity. The call for adopting whistleblowing policies and conflict-of-interest declarations is a critical step toward reinforcing public trust.  
EPP applauds the documented operational achievements of CEPOL, particularly the 25% increase in trained law enforcement professionals and 94% satisfaction rates, which effectively advance EPP's priority of strengthening EU security through practical capacity-building.  
EPP proposes extending evaluation frameworks to systematically assess the impact of training programs on counter-terrorism outcomes, ensuring future budgetary allocations are tightly linked to measurable performance indicators.  
EPP underscores the necessity of allocating additional human and financial resources to CEPOL, as highlighted in the issue, to fully meet its expanded mandate while maintaining operational efficiency—a principle central to EPP’s advocacy for robust EU agencies.  
EPP welcomes collaboration with the Court of Auditors to streamline budget discharge timelines, addressing concerns over procedural delays while preserving the credibility of the discharge process.

ECR entirely rejects the discharge approval due to the Council’s refusal to cooperate in audit processes, undermining accountability and contradicting ECR’s core principles of transparent governance.  
ECR rejects the issue’s failure to rectify under-representation of post-2004 Member States in senior agency roles, a critical equity issue central to ECR’s advocacy.  
ECR condemns the unresolved financial mismanagement in agency relocations, citing CEPOL’s €1.01 million relocation costs and parallels to ENISA’s controversial transfer, which exemplify fiscal irresponsibility.  
ECR highlights the issue’s inadequate response to high carry-over rates (17% of CEPOL’s budget) as incompatible with rigorous fiscal stewardship demanded by ECR.  
ECR opposes the discharge for overlooking systemic administrative failures, including delayed infrastructure projects and opaque building policies, which the issue insufficiently addresses.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and observations regarding the European Police College (CEPOL, now the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Training) based on its 2015 financial and operational performance. The resolution highlighted that CEPOL’s 2015 budget was €8.47 million (a 1.22% increase from 2014), with a 95.51% implementation rate and 79% payment execution. Carry-overs of €1.41 million (17% of the budget) were noted, partly due to its 2014 relocation from the UK to Hungary, costing €1.01 million, with 50% funded by the UK and Commission. The Court of Auditors affirmed the reliability of accounts and legality of transactions. Training outputs increased, with 12,992 law enforcement professionals trained (25% more than 2014) through 151 activities, including 85 residential courses and 66 webinars, achieving 94% participant satisfaction. However, Parliament urged better reporting on the impact of these activities on EU security. It acknowledged a €2.5 million EU/MENA counter-terrorism training grant but called for its evaluation and potential extension. Transparency shortcomings were flagged, including unpublished expert conflict-of-interest declarations, and CEPOL was urged to adopt whistleblowing and anti-revolving door policies. Parliament also stressed the need for increased human and financial resources to meet CEPOL’s expanded mandate, citing insufficient current capacity. Lastly, it welcomed collaboration with other agencies and improvements in payment timeliness (89% on-time payments).

title: Discharge 2015: European Police Office (Europol): REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Police Office (Europol) for the financial year 2015
background: In 2015, Europol’s budget rose 12.55% to address expanded counter-terrorism and migration mandates, with high budget execution rates but notable administrative carry-overs and procurement scrutiny. The Parliament will assess financial compliance and accountability in Europol’s 2015 budget discharge, including operational effectiveness and transparency in conflict-of-interest management.

stances.stance:
EPP fully sanctions the issue's recognition of Europol's operational achievements, particularly the establishment of critical counter-terrorism structures like the European Counter Terrorism Centre, which perfectly aligns with EPP's security-focused agenda.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the emphasis on rigorous financial accountability, applauding the 99.8% commitment implementation rate as exemplary adherence to EPP's principles of prudent EU budget management.  
EPP proposes enhancing transparency protocols regarding third-party data sources like WorldCheck to strengthen public trust in counter-terrorism operations, while fully supporting ongoing security collaborations.  
EPP emphasizes the necessity to accelerate internal audit reforms, particularly in addressing the remaining 25% of critical recommendations, as a natural progression of Europol's commitment to operational excellence.  
The issue effectively advances EPP's priority of institutional integrity by demanding full publication of Management Board conflict-of-interest declarations, ensuring alignment with the new Europol Regulation's governance standards.

ECR rejects the discharge approval due to unresolved under-representation of post-2004 Member States in managerial roles, contradicting ECR's principle of equitable geographic balance in EU agencies.  
ECR opposes fundamentally the lack of Council transparency in budgetary oversight, which undermines accountability mechanisms central to ECR's fiscal governance priorities.  
ECR condemns the ENISA relocation controversy as emblematic of wasteful expenditure and procedural manipulation, conflicting with ECR's stance against bureaucratic overreach.  
ECR highlights the excessive €42 million administrative carry-overs as indicative of poor financial planning, inconsistent with ECR's demands for rigorous budget discipline.  
ECR disputes the issue's operational praise while ignoring unresolved security vulnerabilities in Europol's data practices, overlooking critical risks to EU citizens' rights.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and decisions regarding Europol’s 2015 operations, approving the closure of its accounts and granting discharge to its Director. The final budget was €94.9 million, a 12.55% increase from 2014, driven by expanded mandates. The Court of Auditors confirmed the reliability of accounts and legality of transactions, with a 99.8% commitment implementation rate and 89% payment execution. Carry-overs for administrative expenditure reached €42 million (41%), mainly for ongoing building works. Staffing totaled 627, with 86 new hires and 62 departures, alongside 386 non-staff personnel. Concerns included the use of the WorldCheck database, criticized for unverified terrorism links, prompting a call for transparency on its use. Europol’s operational impact included processing 732,000 messages via SIENA, 633,000 EIS searches, supporting 812 operations, and coordinating 98 joint actions. New initiatives like the EU Internet Referral Unit, European Counter Terrorism Centre, and European Migrant Smuggling Centre were highlighted. The Parliament urged improved data security, conflict of interest transparency (noting unpublished Management Board declarations), and adherence to the new Europol Regulation effective May 2017. Internal audits addressed 75% of critical recommendations, while security measures were heightened due to a substantial threat level (4/5) in the Netherlands.

title: Discharge 2015: European Railway Agency (ERA): REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Railway Agency (now European Union Agency for Railways) for the financial year 2015
background: The European Railway Agency's 2015 budget execution, including financial management, procurement, and gender balance, followed a Court of Auditors report confirming reliable accounts but highlighting risks in operational controls amid its transition to the European Union Agency for Railways under new regulatory mandates. The Parliament will discuss compliance with budgetary and accountability standards for EU agencies.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the issue’s emphasis on budgetary accountability and transparency, aligning with its commitment to rigorous financial oversight and taxpayer fund protection.  
EPP proposes enhancing communication strategies for EU agencies to better showcase their operational achievements, addressing concerns about underreported progress.  
EPP firmly accepts the Court of Auditors’ role in improving discharge processes and urges accelerated Council discharge timelines to strengthen institutional credibility.  
EPP applauds the focus on fraud prevention and internal controls, matching its manifesto priorities for ethical governance and robust financial management.  
EPP emphasizes the critical need to address gender imbalances in senior roles, urging concrete quotas and monitoring mechanisms to ensure equitable representation.

ECR rejects the discharge approval due to unresolved systemic payment errors and Council non-cooperation, totally rejecting with ECR's demand for transparent fiscal governance.  
ECR opposes the closure as it overlooks critical under-representation of post-2004 Member States in managerial posts, contradicting ECR's principle of equitable EU institutional representation.  
The issue totally rejects with ECR's stance by tacitly accepting ENISA's unauthorized relocation plans, which ECR condemns as financial mismanagement undermining regional commitments.  
ECR rejects the discharge due to unaddressed infrastructure delays like the Europa building project, indicative of poor budgetary execution contrary to ECR's efficiency benchmarks.  
The proposal overlooks critical flaws in job-tier balance and carry-over appropriations, directly opposing ECR's insistence on strict compliance with Court of Auditors' standards.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the discharge of the European Union Agency for Railways’ 2015 budget, approving the closure of its accounts with a final budget of €26,345,000—a 2.45% increase from 2014—and noted a 99.10% budget implementation rate and 89.78% payment execution rate, reflecting improvements from 2014. It acknowledged reduced carry-over rates (18.98% for Title II and 29.42% for Title III), meeting the Court of Auditors’ indicative ceilings, and highlighted staffing changes, including 154 permanent staff (62% male, 38% female), while expressing concern over severe gender imbalances in senior management (86% male) and management boards (85% male). The resolution urged corrective action on gender disparities, delayed invoice payments (92.6% paid on time), and called for transparency in conflict-of-interest policies, whistleblower protections, and updates on fee mechanisms for new competencies under the 2016 Agency Regulation. It noted progress in fraud prevention training, internal audits, and compliance with 11 out of 12 Internal Control Standards, while stressing risks linked to the Agency’s expanded mandate under the Fourth Railway Package and budgetary constraints. The Agency’s strategic role in rail safety, interoperability, ERTMS development, and cross-agency cooperation was emphasized, alongside concerns over funding cuts conflicting with increased responsibilities.

title: Discharge 2015: European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA): REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Securities and Markets Authority for the financial year 2015
background: The European Securities and Markets Authority’s (ESMA) 2015 financial management, including budget execution and compliance with EU financial regulations, was scrutinized following the European Court of Auditors’ annual report. The Parliament will discuss ESMA’s discharge procedure for the 2015 budget, focusing on financial accountability and regulatory compliance.

stances.stance:
EPP completely agrees the issue's emphasis on rigorous budget implementation and fiscal accountability, perfectly aligning with EPP's longstanding commitment to responsible stewardship of EU taxpayer funds.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the call for enhanced supervisory convergence and proportional resource allocation, recognizing ESMA's critical role in maintaining market stability through performance-driven governance.  
EPP fully supports the mandated transparency measures including accelerated publication of meeting minutes and whistleblower protections, which effectively advance EPP's priority of institutional integrity and public trust.  
EPP endorses the issue's validation of ESMA's gender balance and multinational staffing achievements as exemplary models for EU agency governance, reflecting EPP's values of inclusive policymaking.  
EPP strongly commends the issue's insistence on resolving legacy audit issues through activity-based costing systems, aligning perfectly with EPP's 2015 manifesto pledge for technocratic precision in financial oversight.

ECR fundamentally challenges the discharge issue due to the Council’s refusal to cooperate in accountability procedures, directly contradicting ECR’s insistence on institutional transparency and rigorous oversight.  
ECR rejects the issue’s failure to address under-representation of post-2004 Member States in managerial roles, undermining ECR’s principle of equitable EU-wide representation in governance structures.  
ECR opposes the discharge over ENISA’s contested relocation efforts, which exemplify fiscal mismanagement and disregard for established operational frameworks, conflicting with ECR’s commitment to fiscal discipline and procedural integrity.  
 ECR’s arguments focus on ENISA and Council accountability gaps rather than ESMA-specific provisions, signaling a foundational misalignment with the issue’s scope.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined key decisions regarding the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) for 2015, noting its budget of €34.03 million (a 2.3% increase from 2014 due to expanded tasks) and a 12.35% reduction in EU contributions to €9.7 million. It acknowledged a 99.64% budget implementation rate and an 84.54% payment execution rate, alongside two budget amendments reducing expenditures by €372,709. While the Court of Auditors confirmed the reliability of ESMA’s accounts and legality of transactions, unresolved corrective actions from 2011, 2012, and 2014 audits persisted, including fee calculations based on estimates rather than actual costs, prompting ESMA to develop an activity-based costing system. Staffing increased by 10.7% to 186 employees, with a gender balance of 44% female and 56% male, and 22 EU nationalities represented. Governance measures included conflict-of-interest policies for staff and non-staff, an Anti-Fraud Strategy (2015–2017), and publication of CVs and declarations of interest for board members, though Management Board declarations remained unpublished. The resolution urged ESMA to prioritize supervisory convergence over legislative tasks, enhance transparency through faster publication of meeting minutes (reducing a three-month delay) and web streaming, and establish whistleblower rules by 2017. It called for a review of ESMA’s financing model, proposing fees for market participants to replace some national contributions while safeguarding autonomy. Performance concerns included underutilization of legal mandates and delayed communication with EU institutions, stressing the need for proportional resource allocation and timely reporting on audit action plans.

title: Discharge 2015: European Training Foundation (ETF): REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Training Foundation for the financial year 2015
background: The European Training Foundation (ETF), an EU agency supporting education and training reforms in partner countries, reported a 2015 budget of €20.15 million, a 0.02% decrease from 2014, with financial management flagged by the Court of Auditors for banking risks and carry-over irregularities. The Parliament will discuss granting discharge for the ETF’s 2015 budget execution.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly advocates the issue’s emphasis on budgetary transparency and accountability, aligning with ALDE’s longstanding commitment to institutional integrity and citizen trust in EU governance.  
ALDE applauds the publication of contractor lists exceeding €15,000 as a critical step toward enhancing public scrutiny, while proposing stricter accessibility standards for conflict-of-interest declarations to eliminate password barriers.  
ALDE approves the Foundation’s 99.89% budget implementation rate and reduced carry-overs, underscoring the need to maintain rigorous financial safeguards for operational activities.  
ALDE highlights the importance of resolving low-rated bank holdings to ensure optimal liquidity management, urging accelerated progress in line with ALDE’s fiscal responsibility principles.  
ALDE commends the Foundation’s contributions to education reforms and migration dialogue, which align with ALDE’s priorities for inclusive growth and labor market integration.

ECR rejects the discharge issue due to unresolved systemic financial mismanagement, including €7.5 million held in low-rated banks and excessive 36.4% operational carry-overs, contradicting their demand for rigorous fiscal accountability.  
ECR opposes the Foundation's governance model as fundamentally flawed, citing incomplete publication of conflict-of-interest declarations (some password-protected) as violating transparency principles central to their anti-corruption agenda.  
ECR condemns the persistent under-representation of post-2004 Member States in senior EU posts highlighted in the issue, viewing this as institutional discrimination incompatible with their commitment to equitable representation.  
ECR denounces the ENISA agency's unauthorized relocation attempts from Heraklion to Athens, interpreting this as financial impropriety and regional marginalization opposing their stance on decentralized EU resource distribution.  
ECR challenges the claimed 96% work program achievement rate, arguing that delayed funding transfers and internal audit deficiencies reveal operational inefficiencies irreconcilable with their efficiency-focused governance standards.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and observations regarding the European Training Foundation’s 2015 financial management, noting its final budget of €20,153,042 (a 0.02% decrease from 2014) fully funded by the EU. While acknowledging the Court of Auditors’ assurance of reliable accounts and legal transactions, it highlighted unresolved issues, including €7.5 million held in a low-rated bank (reduced to €1.8 million in 2015) due to banking constraints. The Foundation achieved a 99.89% budget implementation rate and 96.04% payment execution, with carry-overs decreasing to 3.3% overall (1.4% for staff expenditure, 16.1% for administrative costs) but rising to 36.4% for operational activities due to delayed funding transfers. Nine budgetary transfers were made, aligned with financial rules. Criticisms included incomplete publication of governing board members’ conflict-of-interest declarations, some accessible only via password, urging stricter transparency measures. Internal audits noted one open recommendation (downgraded to “important”) and positive ex-post audit results despite areas for improvement. The Parliament commended the Foundation’s 96% work program achievement rate, contributions to education reforms, migration dialogue (noting the MISMES inventory and NEETs analysis), compliance with EU Staff Regulations, and efforts to secure assets. It called for continued corrective actions on financial safeguards and governance transparency.

title: Discharge 2015: European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA): REPORT on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights for the financial year 2015
background: In 2015, the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA) implemented its budget with a 100% commitment rate, underwent a Court of Auditors review, and received a Council discharge recommendation. The agency’s activities included migration, Roma integration, and compliance with financial regulations. The Parliament will discuss FRA’s 2015 budgetary discharge, focusing on governance, performance, and financial accountability.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the issue's emphasis on budget efficiency and performance monitoring reforms, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to fiscal responsibility and accountability in EU agencies.  
EPP applauds the Agency’s focus on refugee rights and Roma integration as effectively advancing EPP's priority of safeguarding fundamental freedoms while proposing enhanced public communication strategies to better showcase operational achievements.  
EPP endorses maintaining strict accountability for past parliamentary irregularities, urging amendment of Clause 38 to preserve findings about procedural violations by former leadership as a transparency enhancement.  
EPP proposes accelerating the budgetary cycle reform highlighted in the issue to strengthen discharge credibility, particularly regarding delayed Council assessments, while fully supporting current performance metrics.  
EPP strongly advocates rejecting unsubstantiated claims against oversight processes, aligning with EPP's principles of institutional integrity, and recommends expanding anti-fraud strategy evaluations to cover all agency interactions.

ECR fully disputes the discharge issue due to the Council's refusal to provide essential information, undermining parliamentary oversight and accountability in the budgetary process.  
ECR rejects the approval citing excessive carry-over amounts and delays in critical infrastructure projects like the Europa building, highlighting systemic financial mismanagement.  
ECR opposes the issue as it fails to address the under-representation of post-2004 Member States in senior roles, contradicting principles of equitable EU governance.  
ECR condemns the issue for ignoring wasteful expenditures such as ENISA's unnecessary relocation, which squanders existing resources and inflates costs.  
ECR highlights ENISA's insistence on relocation despite available facilities as emblematic of broader EU financial negligence, justifying opposition to the discharge.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined key findings regarding the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights’ 2015 operations, noting its budget remained unchanged at €21.23 million (98.23% EU-funded) with full commitment execution and a 71.62% payment rate (up 2.17% from 2014). While acknowledging high carry-overs (€5.7 million, 70% for operational expenditure) due to multi-year studies, it highlighted efficient budget management, including a 98.32% utilization of 2014 carry-overs and compliant transfers of €835,734. The Agency’s reforms in performance monitoring and evaluation were noted, alongside substantial outputs: 60 events, 240 expert presentations, 32 reports, and 122 opinions. Criticisms included the Agency’s limited mandate to proactively advise on legislation and cover all Charter rights, particularly police and judicial cooperation. Gender imbalance in senior management (5/6 positions held by one gender) was flagged. The Agency’s focus on refugee/migrant rights, including assessments of Greek and Italian "hotspots," and Roma integration efforts, including anti-Gypsyism measures, were commended. Internal audits showed most recommendations addressed, with an anti-fraud strategy adopted.
