GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s focus on rule-of-law conditionality, urging expansion to include a dedicated EU fund for civil society protection as highlighted by Terry Reintke, thereby reinforcing democratic accountability alongside anti-corruption mechanisms.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for comprehensive reform of the EU’s financing system to enhance stability, transparency, and fairness, focusing on reducing reliance on national contributions (69.1% from GNI and 12.4% from VAT in 2016) and replacing them with genuine own resources. Key proposals include introducing a financial transaction tax (FTT), corporate income tax reforms (e.g., allocating part of the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base revenue to the EU budget), and sustainability-linked measures such as a CO2 levy or emissions-based customs duties to incentivize climate-friendly trade and generate revenue. The resolution emphasizes modernizing the customs union (which contributed 12.8% of EU revenue in 2015) to combat fraud, improve duty collection, and address revenue losses from free trade agreements, while ensuring WTO compliance. It calls for abolishing rebates and correction mechanisms, advocating for at least 50% of EU budget revenue to come from new own resources, and stresses the need to offset Brexit-related revenue losses (€9–12 billion annually). Climate action is prioritized, with demands to align the budget with the Paris Agreement and allocate resources to high-value projects like energy transition. The Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) is highlighted as vital, costing citizens 32 cents daily and supporting 500 million Europeans, though reforms are urged to enhance equity and environmental benefits. The resolution also supports creating a euro area budgetary capacity, a European Minister of Economy and Finance, and shifting to qualified majority voting for budgetary decisions to strengthen democratic accountability and EU added value.

title: Multiannual financial framework for 2014-2020: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 laying down the multiannual financial framework for the years 2014-2020
background: The EU's 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework, established in 2013, faced evolving challenges including migration pressures, security threats, and youth unemployment. Institutional requirements for budgetary adjustments to address emerging priorities necessitated framework revisions. The Parliament will discuss amendments to the 2014-2020 financial framework to enhance budgetary flexibility and respond to new policy demands.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the amendment for disregarding critical proposals on equitable funding distribution, contradicting their manifesto pledge to prioritize cohesion policies.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the compromise’s rigidity in financial planning, which undermines adaptive responses to emerging crises—a core principle of their fiscal strategy.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s failure to address Greens’ amendments for climate-action earmarking, inconsistent with their 2020 budgetary advocacy.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the Council’s exclusion of parliamentary input on flexibility mechanisms, violating procedural transparency they staunchly defend.  
GREEN_EFA asserts the amendment perpetuates austerity imbalances, clashing with their demand for social and green investment parity.

SD fully sanctions the MFF revision's allocation of €6 billion to reinforce research, youth employment, and migration management, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to EU solidarity and future-oriented investment.  
SD applauds the issue's focus on Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe Facility as effectively advancing SD's priority of scientific collaboration and pan-European infrastructure development.  
SD highlights enhancement opportunities for future frameworks to address structural underfunding in defense and migration policies, building on this revision’s foundational progress.  
SD perfectly aligns with the strengthened Youth Employment Initiative, recognizing its critical role in fulfilling SD’s manifesto pledge to combat youth unemployment across member states.  
SD emphasizes the issue’s role in enabling rapid responses to crises while proposing intensified future efforts to establish EU-owned revenue streams for budgetary sustainability.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the draft Council regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013, which establishes the multiannual financial framework (MFF) for the EU budget covering the period 2014–2020. The resolution endorsed the proposed adjustments to the MFF, aimed at addressing evolving priorities and financial needs within the existing budgetary framework. By approving the amendment, Parliament supported the Council’s revisions to ensure alignment with current challenges, though specific numerical adjustments or funding reallocations were not detailed in the resolution text. The decision reaffirmed Parliament’s role in the budgetary process under Article 312 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and Article 106a of the Euratom Treaty, emphasizing procedural adherence while focusing on the substantive approval of the updated financial framework.

title: Multiannual financial framework for 2014-2020 (Resolution): REPORT containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 laying down the multiannual financial framework for the years 2014-2020
background: The 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework included provisions for mid-term review, with emerging priorities like migration pressures, security challenges, and youth unemployment requiring budgetary adjustments. The European Commission proposed amendments in 2016, followed by Council negotiations. The Parliament will discuss revisions to the MFF regulation to address evolving funding needs and institutional flexibility mechanisms.

stances.stance:
ALDE absolutely supports the issue's enhanced flexibility mechanisms and targeted funding increases for youth employment and emergency aid, perfectly aligning with their commitment to dynamic EU budgetary responsiveness.  
ALDE emphasizes the necessity of preserving parliamentary budgetary authority, as reflected in their unilateral declaration rejecting attempts to restrict strategic program growth through non-treaty-altering Council statements.  
ALDE applauds the issue's adherence to fiscal discipline through maintained payment ceilings and operational efficiency targets, consistent with their advocacy for responsible financial stewardship.  
ALDE strongly sanctions the provisions addressing payment backlog risks and liquidity optimization, ensuring uninterrupted implementation of critical programs within existing MFF constraints.  
ALDE highlights the imperative for future financial frameworks to integrate robust reality-based forecasting, building on this revision's incremental progress toward budgetary agility.

GUE/NGL absolutely challenges the MFF revision's failure to allocate dedicated Brexit mitigation funds for Irish farmers, SMEs, and communities, directly contradicting their demand for targeted economic protections.  
GUE/NGL rejects the austerity-driven 0.28% budget increase as perpetuating harmful fiscal constraints that deepen social inequalities across peripheral EU states.  
GUE/NGL opposes reliance on undemocratic private investment mechanisms instead of establishing progressive EU-wide taxation to fund socio-ecological public projects.  
GUE/NGL condemns the prioritization of military/security spending over cohesion policies, exacerbating regional disparities denounced in their 2014 opposition.  
GUE/NGL highlights the issue's systemic failure to address youth unemployment through binding employment guarantees, violating core redistributive principles.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined its position on the mid-term revision of the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), emphasizing the need to address budgetary pressures from unforeseen challenges such as migration crises, youth unemployment, and security threats. It approved joint statements with the Council annexed to the resolution, which aimed to adjust the MFF to enhance flexibility and allocate additional funds to priority areas, including the Youth Employment Initiative and emergency aid. The Parliament also endorsed its own annexed statement, stressing the importance of maintaining budgetary discipline while ensuring sufficient resources for EU programs, and took note of unilateral declarations by the Council and Commission. The resolution referenced prior positions from July and October 2016, which advocated for a revised MFF to better align with evolving priorities, and acknowledged the Council’s March 2017 agreement in principle on the revision. Key documents underpinning the revision included the Commission’s 2016 proposal (COM(2016)0604) and the draft Council regulation (14942/2016), which sought to reallocate funds within the existing framework without exceeding overall expenditure ceilings. The Parliament underscored the necessity of transparent and collaborative adjustments to ensure the MFF’s effectiveness through 2020.

title: Protection of the Union's budget in case of generalised deficiencies as regards the rule of law in the Member States: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of the Union's budget in case of generalised deficiencies as regards the rule of law in the Member States
background: Growing concerns over rule of law deficiencies in EU member states impacting financial management prompted the 2018 Commission proposal linking budget protection to adherence to EU values. The Parliament will discuss establishing a mechanism to safeguard EU funds against financial risks arising from systemic rule of law breaches.

stances.stance:
ENF rejects the regulation as an illegitimate power grab that absolutely doubts with ENF's position on national sovereignty by allowing unelected EU officials to withhold funds over subjective rule-of-law assessments.  
ENF opposes the conditionality mechanism outlined in Articles 2-4, which overlooks critical aspects of fiscal autonomy by enabling political retaliation against member states refusing migrant quotas or progressive social policies.  
ENF condemns the proposal's Article 5 budgetary sanctions as punitive colonialism inconsistent with treaty principles, noting Poland and Hungary already contribute more to EU coffers than they receive.  
ENF denounces the "generalized deficiencies" framework in Section II for weaponizing rule-of-law rhetoric to suppress democratically elected governments challenging Brussels' federalist agenda.  
ENF declares the issue incompatible with EU founding values of voluntary cooperation, urging member states to reclaim control over national tax revenues and legal systems.

ALDE strongly promotes the regulation's linkage of rule of law compliance to EU budget integrity, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to institutional accountability and Treaty-based governance.  
ALDE approves the creation of an independent expert panel for annual rule of law assessments, effectively advancing transparency in monitoring Member State adherence to Article 2 values.  
ALDE proposes enhancing implementation mechanisms by simplifying bureaucratic procedures to ensure timely fund disbursement while maintaining rigorous beneficiary protections.  
ALDE applauds the parity granted to Parliament and Council in adopting budgetary measures, reinforcing democratic checks central to ALDE's federalist principles.  
ALDE emphasizes the critical need to shield final beneficiaries from governmental deficiencies, endorsing direct payment safeguards as vital to upholding EU financial interests.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s proposal COM(2018)0324, grounded in Articles 294(2) and 322(1)(a) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and Article 106a of the Euratom Treaty, while incorporating the Court of Auditors’ opinion from 17 August 2018. The resolution, developed through joint deliberations by the Committees on Budgets and Budgetary Control and consultations with other committees, formally adopted the Parliament’s stance, urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantially amended, and directed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to ensure alignment and accountability in EU budgetary governance.

title: The MFF mid-term revision: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the mid-term revision of the MFF 2014-2020
background: Emerging challenges including migration pressures, security threats, agricultural sector instability, persistent youth unemployment, and climate commitments strained the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), established prior to these crises. The Parliament will discuss adjusting the MFF’s budgetary allocations to address evolving priorities and unforeseen demands within the existing financial framework.

stances.stance:
SD strongly endorses the issue’s emphasis on flexibility instruments and crisis reserves, aligning perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to adaptive governance in times of unforeseen challenges.  
SD fundamentally approves the reinforcement of youth employment programs but proposes enhancing the Youth Employment Initiative allocation to €6 billion to match initial funding levels and address systemic underinvestment.  
SD applauds the focus on cohesion policy technical adjustments, which directly advance SD’s priority of reducing regional disparities through targeted EU funding.  
SD urges accelerated Council engagement in parallel negotiations for the 2017 budget and MFF revision, ensuring coherence and timely payment obligations to beneficiaries across Europe.  
SD strongly endorses the issue’s call for post-2020 own-resources reforms, perfectly aligning with SD’s manifesto goals to reduce GNI dependence and phase out rebates.

GUE/NGL rejects the MFF revision's failure to increase funding ceilings, fundamentally againsting with their demand for transformative economic justice across Europe.  
GUE/NGL opposes the inadequate migration response funding as inconsistent with their principle of solidarity-driven crisis management for refugees.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue's youth employment measures for maintaining token investments that fail to combat systemic precarity among European youth.  
GUE/NGL denounces the technical cohesion adjustments as perpetuating austerity-driven policies contrary to their anti-neoliberal development model.  
GUE/NGL fundamentally againsts with the issue's Brexit approach for insufficiently protecting Northern Ireland's peace process through dedicated budgetary guarantees.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the insufficiency of the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) to address emerging crises, including migration, security threats, agricultural challenges, youth unemployment, and climate commitments. It stressed the need for increased funding, particularly under Headings 1a (Competitiveness), 1b (Cohesion), 3 (Security), and 4 (Global Europe), to align the EU budget with political priorities. The resolution highlighted the Commission’s proposed MFF revision, totaling EUR 12.8 billion, which includes targeted reinforcements such as EUR 0.4 billion each for Horizon 2020 and CEF-Transport, EUR 0.2 billion each for Erasmus+ and COSME, and EUR 1 billion for the Youth Employment Initiative. It noted additional legislative proposals worth EUR 1.6 billion (e.g., EFSI extension, External Investment Plan) and a EUR 4.6 billion technical adjustment for cohesion policy. Parliament criticized the lack of upward revisions to MFF ceilings and insufficient funding for migration responses, while welcoming flexibility measures like removing limits on the Global Margin for Commitments. It emphasized resolving payment delays, citing a EUR 7.3 billion reduction in 2016 payments and EUR 339 billion in outstanding commitments by 2015, advocating a binding payment plan and full use of the Global Margin for Payments. The resolution called for reinvesting decommitted funds, establishing an EU Crisis Reserve, simplifying financial rules, and ensuring unity of the budget. It urged reforms for post-2020 MFF, including new own-resources to reduce GNI reliance, phasing out rebates, and addressing Brexit’s budgetary implications, particularly for regions affected by the UK’s withdrawal. Parliament also advocated youth initiatives like the "18th-birthday interrail pass" and stressed protecting the Good Friday Agreement.

title: Union own resources – adjustment of Member States' national contributions: REPORT on the proposal for a Council regulation amending Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1150/2000 implementing Decision 2007/436/EC, Euratom on the system of the European Communities' own resources
background: Recent statistical revisions by EU Member States revealed discrepancies in national contributions to the EU budget, with some states underpaying and others overpaying due to updated economic data. The Council requested amended payment rules to address these imbalances. The Parliament will discuss adjustments to Member States’ financial obligations under the EU’s own resources system.

stances.stance:
ALDE firmly approves the issue's insistence on annual transparency reports for VAT/GNI calculations, perfectly aligning with their commitment to fiscal accountability and budgetary integrity.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the call for Council accountability in maintaining approved payment schedules, recognizing this as essential to preserving EU financial credibility.  
ALDE firmly approves the linkage of debt issue to the 2016 multiannual financial framework revision, viewing it as a critical enhancement opportunity to address systemic revenue flaws.  
ALDE strongly sanctions the emphasis on solidarity through urgent debt apurement mechanisms, proposing strengthened treasury safeguards to prevent future liquidity strains.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s alignment with their manifesto priorities by rejecting discretionary contribution delays, thereby advancing responsible multiannual budget governance.

GUE_NGL rejects the amended regulation for perpetuating austerity-driven budget cuts that disproportionately harm vulnerable populations and exacerbate EU inequalities.  
GUE_NGL opposes the deferral mechanisms for national contributions as a capitulation to fiscal irresponsibility, enabling wealthier states to evade solidarity obligations.  
GUE_NGL condemns reduced cohesion funding and education cuts in the 2015 budget as fundamentally incompatible with social justice priorities.  
GUE_NGL denounces the Juncker Plan's financial engineering for redirecting public funds to private investors rather than addressing systemic underfunding of essential services.  
GUE_NGL declares the issue's approval of retroactive adjustments a betrayal of fiscal transparency, entrenching North-South economic disparities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over amendments to Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1150/2000, prompted by statistical revisions revealing underpayments and overpayments of Member States’ contributions to the EU budget. It noted that existing rules would have corrected these imbalances but criticized the Council’s prioritization of deferring contributions over timely negotiations on the 2014-2015 budgets, which contributed to the failure of the Conciliation Committee. Parliament expressed alarm over granting Member States discretion to delay GNI-based contributions, warning this could undermine budget credibility, strain the Commission’s treasury, and set a problematic precedent. While acknowledging the exceptional financial burden of 2014 VAT and GNI adjustments for some states, it stressed the proposal’s complexity and its retroactive overlap with pending legislative reforms, urging the High Level Group on Own Resources to address systemic flaws. Despite reservations, Parliament approved the amended proposal as part of a broader package including the 2014 amending budgets and 2015 Budget, insisting on annual transparency reports detailing VAT/GNI calculations and Member States’ installment plans. It called for Council accountability if deviating from the approved text and reaffirmed the need for timely consultations on substantive changes.

title: The role of whistleblowers in the protection of EU´s financial interests: REPORT on the role of whistle-blowers in the protection of EU’s financial interests
background: Existing EU sectoral whistleblower protections, international anticorruption obligations, and high-profile financial misconduct cases highlighted gaps in legal safeguards. Varied national frameworks and risks faced by individuals reporting irregularities underscored systemic vulnerabilities. The Parliament will discuss enhancing whistleblower roles in safeguarding EU financial interests and establishing comprehensive legal protections across member states.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA firmly sanctions the issue’s demand for a horizontal EU whistleblower protection framework, perfectly aligning with our commitment to transparency and combating corruption.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on safeguarding anonymity and legal support, which directly advances our priority of shielding public-interest disclosures across environmental and financial domains.  
GREEN_EFA underscores the moral imperative cited in the issue, as strengthening whistleblower protections is vital to restoring citizen trust in EU institutions—a cornerstone of our policy agenda.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call to harmonize national laws with international standards, ensuring consistent defense of human rights and the rule of law.  
GREEN_EFA urges swift Commission action to implement this framework, as delays contradict the urgency of protecting those exposing fraud against EU financial interests.

ECR rejects the establishment of a centralized EU legal framework for whistleblower protection, as it entirely opposes with their principle of subsidiarity and national sovereignty in legal matters.  
The issue’s harmonization demands overlook critical aspects of member state autonomy, inconsistent with ECR’s opposition to EU overreach in domestic judicial systems.  
ECR opposes retroactive protections and EU-wide penalties for retaliation, viewing these as violations of legal certainty and national jurisdiction over punitive measures.  
The proposal’s financial rewards for whistleblowers are rejected by ECR as excessive EU interference, contradicting their stance against incentivizing litigation through supranational mechanisms.  
 While ECR members emphasize whistleblower protection, their foundational opposition to EU-level mandates supersedes alignment with the issue’s methods.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the lack of comprehensive whistleblower protection across the EU, emphasizing the critical role whistleblowers play in exposing corruption, fraud, and irregularities affecting the EU’s financial interests, public health, safety, human rights, and the rule of law. It criticized the Commission’s failure to propose a legislative framework for minimum protections despite previous calls, urging immediate action to establish a horizontal legal framework ensuring anonymity, legal and financial support, and safeguards against retaliation. The resolution highlighted that only a few Member States have robust whistleblower protections, violating their obligations under the UN Convention Against Corruption, and called for harmonized national laws aligned with EU and international standards. It stressed the need for secure reporting channels, independent advisory bodies, and annual evaluations by institutions like OLAF and the Court of Auditors to monitor whistleblower protections. The Parliament also warned that the Trade Secrets Directive risks discouraging disclosures and advocated protections for journalists and financial rewards for whistleblowers in certain cases. It demanded retroactive protection for whistleblowers, penalties for retaliation, and transparency reforms within EU institutions, including revised codes of conduct and public awareness campaigns. Additionally, the resolution called for EU-wide mechanisms to ensure confidentiality, digital security, and access to justice, while urging Member States to decriminalize whistleblowing and enforce anti-corruption measures effectively.

title: Draft Council decision on the system of own resources of the European Union: REPORT on the draft Council decision on the system of Own Resources of the European Union | A9-0146/2020 | European Parliament
background: The EU's longstanding reliance on member state contributions and unchanged own resources system since 1988, coupled with COVID-19 economic impacts and the 2020 Next Generation EU recovery plan requiring joint borrowing, prompted institutional proposals for budget modernization. The Parliament will discuss reforming the EU's revenue framework to address fiscal sustainability and crisis response financing.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA fully accepts the issue's push for fair taxation targeting financial sectors and digital giants, perfectly aligning with their manifesto commitment to combat fiscal evasion by multinational corporations.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the urgency to implement border carbon adjustments and social levies, emphasizing that delayed adoption beyond 2027 would irreparably undermine climate action and industrial fairness.  
GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the democratic imperative for autonomous EU revenue streams, rejecting Council veto power over budgetary sovereignty as critical to fulfilling citizens' post-pandemic recovery expectations.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the explicit linkage between reformed own resources and ecological transition funding, mirroring their 2020 policy demand for "climate-conditioned budget instruments."  
GREEN_EFA fully accepts binding parliamentary oversight of Council amendments, ensuring no dilution of proposed financial transaction taxes or environmental benchmarking mechanisms.

ID rejects the creation of EU-wide taxes through the own resources system as a direct assault on national fiscal sovereignty, completely disputeing with ID's principle that taxation must remain under exclusive member state control.  
ID opposes the mutualized debt repayment mechanism as an irreversible step toward permanent EU taxation powers, inconsistent with treaty requirements for unanimity on fiscal matters.  
ID condemns the carbon border tax proposal for disproportionately burdening consumers with inflation and job losses while failing to address non-European competitors' pricing strategies.  
ID challenges the democratic legitimacy of EU-imposed revenue streams, noting the issue overlooks critical aspects of parliamentary accountability by bypassing national legislatures' exclusive tax authority.  
ID warns that Germany's disproportionate financial contributions under this system exemplify how EU fiscal integration erodes national economic stability, directly contradicting ID's manifesto commitment to protect citizens from supranational overreach.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the amended Council draft on the 2021-2027 multiannual financial framework (MFF) and own resources, emphasizing alignment with previous resolutions from March 2018, May 2018, October 2019, and May 2020, which stressed meeting citizens’ expectations, reforming the EU’s revenue system, and supporting the recovery plan post-COVID-19. It referenced the Commission’s communication on the EU budget powering the recovery (COM(2020)0442) and the 2016 High-Level Group report on own resources. The Parliament insisted the Council notify any departure from the approved text, consult Parliament on substantial amendments, and reiterated the need for a revised MFF that addresses contemporary challenges through adequate funding and reformed own resources, including potential new revenue streams. The resolution also instructed forwarding its position to relevant EU institutions and national parliaments to ensure transparency and adherence to agreed frameworks.

title: Conclusions of the extraordinary European Council meeting of 17-21 July 2020: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the conclusions of the extraordinary European Council meeting of 17-21 July 2020 | B9-0229/2020 | European Parliament
background: The COVID-19 pandemic caused severe health and economic crises across the EU, leading the European Council to negotiate a €750 billion recovery instrument (Next Generation EU) and 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework. Disagreements among member states delayed adoption, focusing on grant-loan ratios, rule of law conditionality, and budget allocations. The Parliament will discuss aligning the MFF and recovery funding with EU priorities, including climate, digitalization, and health, while addressing governance and repayment mechanisms.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA completely advocates the issue's demand to reverse funding cuts to Horizon Europe, Erasmus+, and EU4Health, perfectly aligning with their commitment to research, education, and pandemic resilience.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s climate spending targets while advocating enhanced safeguards to exclude fossil fuels and ensure full Paris Agreement compatibility across all EU projects.  
GREEN_EFA completely advocates binding rule-of-law conditionality for EU funds, rejecting the Council’s diluted mechanism as incompatible with democratic accountability and European values.  
GREEN_EFA completely advocates the creation of new own resources through digital and carbon border taxes, aligning with their vision for fiscal autonomy and intergenerational equity in NGEU repayment.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s rejection of the current MFF proposal, supporting Parliament’s ultimatum to withhold consent unless climate, health, and rule-of-law priorities are strengthened.

ECR completely conflicts the rule of law conditionality mechanism as an extra-treaty political tool targeting sovereign member states' internal governance.  
ECR rejects the mutualization of EU debt through Next Generation EU, which violates fiscal sovereignty and imposes intergenerational financial burdens.  
ECR condemns the disproportionate cuts to agricultural and regional development funds, directly contradicting cohesion policy priorities.  
ECR opposes the creation of new EU taxes through "own resources," viewing this as an unconstitutional power grab over national fiscal systems.  
ECR denounces the governance model as centralizing crisis response in Brussels rather than empowering national governments.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the COVID-19 pandemic’s devastating impact, emphasizing the need for a recovery anchored in the European Green Deal, Digital Agenda, and social resilience. It criticized the European Council’s delayed agreement on the 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and the reduction of grants in the Next Generation EU (NGEU) recovery instrument, warning that cuts to health, research, education, digital transformation, asylum, and climate transition programs undermine EU priorities. Parliament rejected the current MFF proposal, demanding negotiations to restore funding for flagship programs like Horizon Europe, Erasmus+, the Just Transition Fund, and EU4Health, which face immediate drops in funding, risking the EU’s climate (30% spending target) and biodiversity (10%) goals. It insisted on new own resources—such as digital taxes, carbon border adjustments, and financial transaction taxes—to repay NGEU debt, rejecting national contributions or further budget cuts. Parliament stressed the need for a rule-of-law mechanism tied to EU funding, gender mainstreaming in budgeting, and transparency in Recovery and Resilience Facility (RRF) spending, opposing the Council’s intergovernmental governance approach. It demanded a legally binding MFF mid-term revision by 2024, flexibility to address crises, and a repayment plan starting by 2025 to avoid burdening future budgets. Parliament warned it would withhold consent for the MFF unless these issues are resolved, setting an October 2020 deadline to avoid program delays under Article 312(4) TFEU.

title: Budget 2021 - technical adjustments: REPORT on the Council position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2021 | A9-0206/2020 | European Parliament
background: Delays in finalizing the 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework, compounded by COVID-19 economic impacts and proposed EU Recovery Plan implementation, created budgetary uncertainties requiring technical adjustments. The Parliament will discuss reconciling pandemic response measures with long-term climate and digital transition goals within the 2021 EU budget framework.

stances.stance:
SD completely agrees the €15 billion increase in commitment appropriations for 2021, perfectly aligning with S&D’s demand for proportional funding to address global crises and strengthen the EU’s humanitarian action as emphasized by Mónica Silvana González.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s 30% climate expenditure target and biodiversity protection commitments, advancing S&D’s climate neutrality agenda as highlighted by Eero Heinäluoma’s focus on a carbon-free Europe.  
SD completely agrees the reinforced funding for Europol and anti-money laundering measures, effectively advancing financial integrity priorities central to S&D’s governance principles.  
SD perfectly aligns with the tripled Erasmus+ budget and €1 billion European Child Guarantee, directly supporting social cohesion and youth opportunities as championed by Josianne Cutajar.  
SD completely agrees the rejection of Council cuts to flagship programs, upholding Parliament’s transparency demands and S&D’s commitment to rule-of-law conditionality as critical for institutional credibility.

ID slightly agrees increased climate spending only if accompanied by binding protections for traditional agriculture and fisheries sectors, as current biodiversity targets risk undermining EU food sovereignty.  
ID requests revisions to eliminate funding for the Mediterranean Search and Rescue Fund, which directly incentivizes irregular migration routes contrary to border security priorities.  
The proposal totally againsts with ID's opposition to fiscal centralization by maintaining VAT-based EU revenues rather than returning €2 billion annually to national taxpayers as demanded.  
ID insists on amending cohesion policy allocations to mandate simplified access for overseas territories, addressing the administrative barriers harming French DOM regions' water infrastructure and SME competitiveness.  
The issue overlooks critical aspects of industrial competitiveness by prioritizing Green Deal measures that disadvantage European producers against Chinese counterparts without reciprocal environmental standards.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over delays in finalizing the 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and Own Resources system, exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic, which hindered timely budgetary planning. It emphasized prioritizing recovery efforts aligned with the European Green Deal and digital transformation, targeting climate neutrality by 2050, biodiversity protection (at least 10% of spending), and climate-related expenditures (30% mainstreaming). The resolution demanded stringent criteria for climate and biodiversity spending under Regulation (EU) 2020/852, phasing out fossil fuel subsidies. It allocated €181.76 billion in commitment appropriations for 2021, a €15 billion increase over the Commission’s draft budget, with additional €1.63 billion from decommitments. Key funding boosts included Horizon Europe (€120 billion over 2021-2027 for research, health, and climate), InvestEU (supporting SMEs and recovery), Erasmus+ (tripling its budget), and the EU4Health Programme (addressing COVID-19 impacts). The Just Transition Fund received a €500 million increase to support green transitions, while LIFE programme funding rose by €237 million for biodiversity and climate goals. Migration and border management programs, including the Integrated Border Management Fund and Frontex, saw reinforced funding. External action funding under NDICI was increased, with new lines for Libya support and Palestinian refugees. Parliament rejected Council cuts to flagship programs, restored transparency in budget lines, and created new lines for the European Child Guarantee (€1 billion), Union values promotion, and a proposed Search and Rescue Fund. It stressed adequate staffing for agencies like EPPO, Europol, and ECDC, while criticizing insufficient support for tourism and SMEs. The resolution insisted on Parliament’s role in overseeing NGEU expenditures and called for new own resources to finance recovery, urging adjustments to MFF ceilings to accommodate increased priorities. Gender mainstreaming, rule of law conditionality, and COVID-19 response measures, including vaccine transparency, were underscored as cross-cutting priorities.

title: Collection of own resources accruing from value added tax: REPORT on the draft Council regulation amending Regulation (EEC, Euratom) No 1553/89 on the definitive uniform arrangements for the collection of own resources accruing from value added tax | A9-0049/2021 | European Parliament
background: The EU’s adoption of the Next Generation EU recovery plan and 2020 Own Resources Decision necessitated reforms to existing VAT collection mechanisms under Regulation (EEC, Euratom) No 1553/89, alongside introducing new funding streams like the 2021 plastic waste levy. The Parliament will discuss amendments to harmonize VAT-based contributions with updated fiscal frameworks.

stances.stance:
SD totally endorses the historic modernization of EU own resources as perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to fiscal autonomy and crisis-responsive governance, particularly through Next Generation EU's debt repayment mechanisms.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's roadmap for polluter-pays principles, applauding the targeting of digital multinationals and carbon-intensive industries without burdening citizens as emphasized in the S&D climate justice agenda.  
SD unequivocally supports the urgency of ratifying the own resources system across all Member States, recognizing this as foundational to preserving European unity against economic fragmentation and anti-EU narratives.  
SD celebrates the issue's institutional balance provisions as critical to transforming EU budget negotiations from technical haggling into strategic debates about Europe's geopolitical future, per SD's federalist vision.  
SD emphasizes the issue's alignment with intergenerational equity through plastic packaging levies and future green/digital taxes, ensuring Next Generation EU's debt servicing doesn't compromise welfare state resilience.

ECR rejects the proposed VAT-based own resources as exceeding EU fiscal authority, totally disapproveing with their stance that taxation sovereignty resides solely with member states.  
ECR opposes the plastic tax and emissions trading revenue mechanisms for disproportionately burdening less wealthy nations, directly contradicting their principle of equitable fiscal responsibility.  
ECR condemns the issue’s failure to address spending efficiency reforms, a critical omission inconsistent with their demand for budgetary rigor before new revenue streams.  
ECR challenges the institutional imbalance created by centralized VAT collection, arguing it undermines national autonomy in fiscal matters as outlined in TFEU Article 322(2).  
ECR disputes the issue’s bureaucratic approach to recovery funding, emphasizing their opposition to EU-level tax innovations that bypass member-state prerogatives.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined its position on the EU’s budgetary framework and own resources system, emphasizing adherence to the Interinstitutional Agreement of 16 December 2020 on budgetary discipline, cooperation, and new own resources. It approved the Council’s draft decision (12771/2020) on the EU’s own resources system as amended, while urging the Council to notify Parliament of any deviations from the approved text and to re-consult Parliament if proposing substantial amendments. The resolution reiterated longstanding priorities from previous resolutions, including reforms to the 2021-2027 multiannual financial framework (MFF) and the need for a robust recovery plan, aligning with Treaty provisions (TFEU Article 322(2) and Euratom Article 106a). It stressed the importance of transparency and institutional balance in budgetary negotiations, instructing its President to formally communicate Parliament’s position to the Council and Commission. The amendment to Article 1(8) of the draft regulation highlighted specific adjustments to the own resources mechanism, though detailed content was not specified in the resolution text.

title: Guidelines for the 2022 Budget - Section III: REPORT on general guidelines for the preparation of the 2022 budget, Section III – Commission | A9-0046/2021 | European Parliament
background: The COVID-19 pandemic caused severe economic contraction, rising unemployment, and strained health systems across the EU, exacerbating existing challenges like climate targets under the Paris Agreement, digital infrastructure gaps, and regional disparities. The Parliament will discuss 2022 budget priorities to address recovery, green and digital transitions, health resilience, and cohesion.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA absolutely advocates the issue's climate prioritization, perfectly aligning with their mandate to channel 30% of MFF funds toward decarbonization and green industrial innovation as critical for Paris Agreement compliance.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the gender-responsive budgeting provisions, emphasizing their structural requirement for equitable recovery and parity-driven investment frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA absolutely advocates tripling Erasmus+ funding and dedicating RRF education allocations, recognizing these as foundational to youth empowerment and intergenerational equity.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the conditional Frontex funding as fully congruent with their demand for rigorous human rights oversight and rejection of border agency impunity.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s integration of Creative Europe and Horizon Europe, vital for sustaining cultural resilience alongside green-digital research ecosystems.

ID rejects the issue's emphasis on expanded funding mechanisms as totally rejecting with ID's principle of fiscal restraint, citing unresolved citizen distrust in EU financial management.  
ID opposes the climate allocation quotas (30% MFF) as emblematic of empty "green transition" rhetoric that neglects SME operational realities across member states.  
The proposal's Great Reset-aligned societal restructuring totally rejects with ID's demand for political honesty over ideological buzzwords like "inclusive recovery."  
ID condemns the lack of accountability safeguards in Frontex funding increases as perpetuating the EU's pattern of creating problems rather than solving them.  
The issue's focus on new own resources (digital levy, carbon tax) overlooks critical ID warnings about compounding economic burdens during ongoing inflation crises.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the imperative of aligning the 2022 EU budget with recovery from the COVID-19 crisis, emphasizing support for SMEs (constituting 99% of EU businesses and 75% of jobs) through enhanced funding via the Single Market Programme, InvestEU, and Horizon Europe to drive innovation, digital skills, and green transitions. It stressed the need to allocate 30% of the MFF and recovery funds to climate action, with 7.5% of annual spending for biodiversity by 2024 and 10% by 2026, while prioritizing cohesion policy to reduce regional disparities and foster job creation. The resolution highlighted the EU4Health programme as the bloc’s largest health initiative, urging investments in vaccine production, HERA, and cancer research (noting 2.7 million cancer diagnoses and 1.3 million deaths in 2020), alongside strengthening EMA and ECDC. It called for inclusive recovery measures, including boosting Erasmus+, dedicating 10% of RRF funds to education, addressing youth unemployment, and implementing gender-responsive budgeting. The Parliament emphasized expanding Schengen to Bulgaria, Romania, and Croatia, increasing Frontex funding with accountability, and upholding rule of law via the EPPO. It demanded accelerated MFF implementation, including EURI commitments (60% by 2022) and new own resources (carbon border tax, digital levy) by July 2022, while addressing delays in programme rollouts and ensuring adequate payments to avoid fiscal crises. Tourism, cultural sectors, and defense innovation were flagged for targeted support, alongside migration management and NDICI funding for external challenges. The resolution underscored strict monitoring of climate and digital targets, including 20% RRF allocations for digital transition, and robust tracking methodologies for budgetary transparency.

title: Guidelines for the 2023 budget – Section III: REPORT on general guidelines for the preparation of the 2023 budget, Section III – Commission | A9-0062/2022 | European Parliament
background: Persistent COVID-19 impacts, supply chain disruptions, rising energy costs, inflationary pressures, and Russia's 2022 invasion of Ukraine created economic uncertainty and humanitarian challenges across Europe. The Parliament will discuss 2023 EU budget priorities addressing pandemic recovery, green/digital transitions, health system resilience, and geopolitical stability within existing financial frameworks.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA entirely promotes the issue's integration of climate and biodiversity protection across all budgetary lines, particularly through strengthened LIFE Programme funding and Just Transition Mechanism allocations to phase out fossil fuel dependencies.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the insistence on strict rule of law conditionality to safeguard EU funds, emphasizing the critical need for independent judiciaries as exemplified in debates about Poland’s constitutional governance.  
GREEN_EFA entirely promotes the prioritization of gender mainstreaming through dedicated resources for the Daphne strand and systematic tracking of gender-related expenditures, advancing intersectional equality frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the unequivocal condemnation of Russia’s aggression against Ukraine and the allocation of urgent humanitarian aid, reflecting their commitment to European solidarity and democratic sovereignty.  
GREEN_EFA entirely promotes enhanced climate expenditure verification methodologies and biodiversity safeguards, ensuring alignment with IPCC-recommended 1.5°C pathways across all EU spending instruments.

ECR rejects the prioritization of rule of law conditionality mechanisms as disproportionate to Poland’s demonstrated humanitarian leadership in hosting Ukrainian refugees.  
ECR opposes gender-based budget allocations and references to reproductive rights, deeming them secondary to urgent security and refugee crisis expenditures.  
ECR fully againsts with claims of systemic EU fund misuse in Poland, demanding concrete evidence over political accusations.  
ECR condemns the issue’s delayed recognition of Ukraine war impacts, insisting on immediate budgetary flexibility for refugee integration costs in frontline states like Poland.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of energy price inflation and agricultural disruptions caused by Russian aggression, requiring dedicated crisis-response funding streams.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for the 2023 EU budget to prioritize economic recovery, resilience, and strategic investments amid challenges such as the COVID-19 pandemic, energy crises, and Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. It emphasized aligning spending with the European Green Deal to achieve climate neutrality by 2050, including increased funding for LIFE, the Just Transition Mechanism, and green infrastructure under the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF). The digital transition was highlighted as critical, with calls to bolster Horizon Europe, Digital Europe, and CEF-Digital to enhance competitiveness, cybersecurity, and AI development. The resolution stressed the importance of cohesion policy, allocating 2% of Recovery and Resilience Facility (RRF) funds to cultural sectors, 10% to education, and 5% of European Social Fund Plus (ESF+) resources to the European Child Guarantee. Health priorities included reinforcing EU4Health, addressing HERA’s funding gaps, and supporting the Beating Cancer Plan. Support for SMEs, tourism, and cultural sectors impacted by the pandemic was urged, alongside demands for fresh resources for initiatives like the New European Bauhaus. The Parliament insisted on strict application of the rule of law conditionality mechanism (Regulation 2020/2092) to protect EU funds, adequate funding for the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO), and increased resources for the Citizens, Equality, Rights and Values programme. Youth-focused measures, including Erasmus+ expansion and addressing pandemic-related educational gaps, were prioritized. The resolution condemned Russia’s aggression against Ukraine, demanding urgent humanitarian aid, support for refugees, and enhanced defense funding via the European Defence Fund. It called for increased migration and asylum funding, emphasizing solidarity among Member States. To finance these priorities, the Parliament urged swift adoption of new own resources, including a carbon border adjustment mechanism and emissions trading revenues, while opposing cuts to existing programmes. Gender equality measures, such as funding the Daphne strand to combat gender-based violence and tracking gender-related expenditures, were emphasized. Lastly, the resolution highlighted the need for sufficient payment appropriations to avoid payment backlogs, improved climate and biodiversity expenditure tracking, and adequate staffing for EU agencies to fulfill their mandates.

title: European Parliament resolution on the new multiannual financial framework, own resources and the recovery plan: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the new multiannual financial framework, own resources and the recovery plan | B9-0158/2020 | European Parliament
background: The COVID-19 pandemic severely strained EU member states’ welfare systems, deepened socio-economic inequalities, and disrupted economic activity, with a projected 7.4% GDP contraction. Pre-existing debates on the 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and EU commitments to climate neutrality, digitalization, and cohesion required reassessment amid crisis conditions. The Parliament will discuss integrating recovery measures into the MFF while balancing long-term strategic priorities and fiscal sustainability.

stances.stance:
SD firmly advocates the integration of the €2 trillion Recovery and Transformation Fund within the MFF framework, perfectly aligning with SD's decades-long commitment to EU solidarity and parliamentary budgetary authority.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's insistence on grants-based financing over loans, recognizing this as essential to prevent asymmetric debt burdens across member states while maintaining social cohesion.  
SD firmly advocates the creation of permanent EU own resources through financial transaction taxes, viewing this as a transformative step toward fiscal justice and sustainable financing beyond national GNI contributions.  
SD strongly sanctions the strict conditionality linking funds to climate neutrality and social rights compliance, seeing this as operationalizing SD's Green Deal leadership and social protection manifesto pledges.  
SD firmly advocates the issue's rejection of intergovernmental bypass mechanisms, perfectly reflecting SD's constitutional vision of empowered parliamentary democracy in EU financial governance.

ID rejects fundamentally the proposed €2 trillion Recovery and Transformation Fund as an unacceptable expansion of EU debt mechanisms that would impose permanent fiscal burdens on member states through new digital and financial transaction taxes.  
ID opposes the issue's climate neutrality conditionality as ideological overreach, citing evidence from reduced emissions during lockdowns that disproves the Green Deal's scientific basis while ignoring urgent family economic needs.  
ID condemns the issue's reliance on EU-guaranteed bonds as a direct path to fiscal colonialism, forcing indebted nations like Italy into austerity traps disguised as solidarity through repayment obligations.  
ID rejects the undemocratic centralization of oversight powers in EU institutions, demanding absolute national control over strategic sectors and veto rights against Chinese economic infiltration as outlined in Article 3.  
ID opposes the carbon border adjustment mechanism as a disguised protectionist tool that would escalate trade tensions with China while failing to address Europe's critical dependency on foreign medical supplies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the severe socio-economic impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic, including a projected 7.4% contraction in EU GDP, increased inequalities, unemployment, and strain on welfare systems, while emphasizing the need for a robust, equitable recovery strategy anchored in the multiannual financial framework (MFF) 2021-2027. It demanded that the revised MFF integrate a €2 trillion Recovery and Transformation Fund financed through EU-guaranteed long-term bonds, prioritizing grants, direct investments, and equity to support SMEs, green and digital transitions, health systems, and strategic industrial sovereignty, while ensuring alignment with the European Green Deal, UN Sustainable Development Goals, and social rights. The resolution stressed that recovery efforts must not compromise existing EU programs or long-term priorities, insisting on new own resources—such as digital taxes, carbon border adjustments, and financial transaction taxes—to fund the MFF and avoid over-reliance on member states’ GNI contributions. It warned against intergovernmental approaches, demanding Parliament’s central role in oversight and rejecting any MFF proposal lacking democratic accountability or sufficient ambition. Additionally, the Parliament called for strict conditionality linking funds to climate neutrality, tax compliance, and rule of law, while advocating international solidarity and a standalone EU health program to bolster crisis resilience.

title: General Budget for the year 2021 - Budgetary Amendments: REPORT on the Council position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2021 | A9-0206/2020 | European Parliament
background: Delays in 2021-2027 MFF negotiations since 2018, compounded by COVID-19 impacts and the European Council’s July 2020 conclusions, necessitated adjustments to the EU’s 2021 budget proposal, including the Next Generation EU recovery instrument. The Parliament will discuss finalizing the 2021 budget to align with the new MFF while addressing pandemic recovery, climate targets, and digital transition.

stances.stance:
SD fundamentally endorses the issue’s prioritization of climate action through binding 30% climate mainstreaming and 10% biodiversity allocations, perfectly aligning with S&D’s Green New Deal advocacy.  
SD perfectly aligns with the reinforced commitment to Horizon Europe and tripled Erasmus+ funding, recognizing these as transformative investments in innovation and social mobility as outlined in S&D’s 2021-2027 policy agenda.  
SD fully supports the €1 billion European Child Guarantee and €237 million LIFE program allocations, which directly advance S&D’s social justice and environmental protection priorities.  
SD endorses the insistence on strict eligibility criteria excluding fossil fuel subsidies, a critical safeguard consistent with S&D’s climate-neutrality roadmap.  
SD applauds the issue’s rejection of Council cuts to humanitarian aid and external action, reflecting S&D’s demand for a globally assertive EU through strengthened NDICI and crisis-response mechanisms.

ID rejects the issue's establishment of a Mediterranean Search and Rescue Fund, which firmly disputes with ID's opposition to migration facilitation policies and NGO funding.  
ID opposes the Green Deal's climate spending targets as economically destructive to European industries, contradicting ID's defense of traditional agriculture and fisheries sectors.  
ID denounces the budget's increased appropriations for gender mainstreaming and social programs, viewing these as ideological impositions irrelevant to pandemic recovery needs.  
ID condemns continued funding for external actors like Turkey and Libya through NDICI, which directly violates ID's sovereignty-first approach to EU spending.  
ID demands cancellation of all EU budget increases, insisting instead on repatriating funds to national treasuries through VAT reductions - a critical omission in the issue's fiscal framework.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over delays in adopting the 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and Own Resources system, exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic, which hindered the 2021 budget process. It emphasized prioritizing recovery efforts through the EU Recovery Plan and Next Generation EU (NGEU), focusing on the European Green Deal, digital transformation, and socioeconomic convergence. The resolution set ambitious climate and biodiversity targets, demanding at least 30% climate mainstreaming and 10% biodiversity spending in 2021, with strict eligibility criteria aligned with the EU Taxonomy Regulation to exclude fossil fuel subsidies. Key flagship programs, including Horizon Europe (€120 billion over 2021-2027), Erasmus+ (tripled funding), EU4Health, and the Just Transition Fund, were reinforced, with total commitment appropriations for the 2021 budget raised to €181.76 billion, an increase of €15.02 billion over the Commission’s draft. Specific allocations included €1 billion for the European Child Guarantee, €500 million for the Just Transition Fund, and €237 million for the LIFE program. The Parliament also prioritized support for COVID-19-affected sectors like tourism, culture, and SMEs, while demanding transparency in budget lines and enhanced resources for agencies such as Frontex, ECDC, and EMA. It rejected Council cuts to critical areas, insisted on gender mainstreaming, and called for a dedicated Search and Rescue Fund in the Mediterranean. The resolution stressed the need for sufficient payment appropriations to address outstanding commitments and ensure liquidity, while opposing rule of law deficiencies affecting EU budget integrity. External action funding was bolstered, with NDICI allocations aligned with Parliament’s priorities, and humanitarian aid was increased to address global challenges worsened by the pandemic.

title: General budget of the European Union for 2020 - all sections: REPORT on the Council position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2020 | A9-0017/2019 | European Parliament
background: The impending conclusion of the 2014-2020 EU budgetary cycle, climate targets under the Paris Agreement, uneven youth unemployment rates across member states, and migration management demands necessitated final budgetary allocations. The Parliament will discuss the 2020 EU budget's alignment with climate objectives, employment initiatives, cohesion policies, and external action priorities.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely agrees the restoration of Horizon 2020 funding to €737.8 million, perfectly aligning with its commitment to innovation leadership and climate research through strategic redeployment of de-commitments.  
EPP perfectly aligns with Parliament’s climate expenditure targets, championing the reinforced €2 billion allocation as critical for achieving 21% climate-related commitments and long-term decarbonization goals.  
EPP absolutely agrees the €363.3 million boost to youth employment initiatives and Erasmus+ expansion, recognizing these as essential investments in Europe’s human capital and social cohesion.  
EPP unequivocally supports maintaining cohesion policy funding at €373.3 million, viewing it as foundational to reducing regional disparities and fulfilling treaty obligations on economic convergence.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the rejection of Council cuts to migration management instruments, emphasizing border security and solidarity through full AMIF/ISF funding as non-negotiable priorities.

ID rejects the issue's prioritization of increased climate expenditure, which allocates over €2 billion and reinforces Horizon 2020 with €737.8 million, as ideologically driven symbolism that neglects global realities, absolutely opposeing with ID's stance that EU climate actions lack measurable global impact while burdening taxpayers.  
ID opposes the €363.3 million boost to the Youth Employment Initiative and €123.4 million Erasmus+ expansion, condemning the latter’s persistent 1.8% allocation for disabled inclusion through sport as tokenistic, inconsistent with ID's demand for proportional funding equity over nominal increases.  
ID fundamentally disputes the restoration of cohesion policy funding by €373.3 million and AMIF/ISF migration program budgets, arguing this perpetuates bureaucratic excess and incentivizes irregular migration, directly contradicting ID's sovereignty-first principles.  
ID condemns the €5 million reduction to Turkey’s pre-accession aid as insufficient, citing Ankara’s destabilizing military actions in Syria, and rejects the issue’s failure to fully sever funding for migration management linked to Turkey.  
ID opposes the €5.5 million allocation for the Conference on European Democracy as wasteful administrative bloat, aligning with its broader critique that the issue entrenches EU centralization rather than empowering national fiscal responsibility.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the Council’s proposed cuts of €1.51 billion to the 2020 EU budget, which it deemed contradictory to EU priorities, and restored funding to the Commission’s original draft levels. Emphasizing climate action, the resolution allocated over €2 billion to reinforce climate-related expenditure across programs, targeting a 20% climate spending goal for 2014-2020, with 21% of the proposed 2020 commitments already climate-related. It highlighted the need for €175–290 billion annually to meet climate targets and reinforced Horizon 2020 by €737.8 million, including €280.7 million from de-commitments for climate research. Youth initiatives were prioritized, with a €363.3 million increase for the Youth Employment Initiative and a €123.4 million boost for Erasmus+ to expand participation. The resolution strengthened cohesion policies (€373.3 million), biodiversity protection via LIFE+ (€233 million), and security/migration programs, rejecting Council cuts to AMIF and ISF. External action funding rose by €257.2 million, including support for the Western Balkans and disaster response, while reducing Turkey’s pre-accession aid by €5 million. Administrative budgets were restored, with €5.5 million added for a Conference on European Democracy. Overall commitments were set at €170.97 billion (a €2.7 billion increase from the draft budget), with payments at €159.15 billion, utilizing special instruments like the Flexibility Instrument and Contingency Margin. Gender equality, digitalization, SMEs, and cancer research were also prioritized, alongside criticism of the Commission’s cuts to Parliament’s administrative budget.

title: 2020 budgetary procedure: joint text: REPORT on the joint text on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2020 approved by the Conciliation Committee under the budgetary procedure | A9-0035/2019 | European Parliament

resolution: The European Parliament raised the definitive adoption of the EU’s 2022 general budget, which aligns with the Commission’s draft budget of 9 July 2021 (COM(2021)0300) and incorporates adjustments from the Council’s position of 6 September 2021 (11352/2021) and Letter of Amendment No 1/2022 of 12 October 2021 (COM(2021)0642). title: Own resource based on non-recycled plastic packaging waste and certain aspects of the GNI-based own resource: REPORT on the draft Council regulation on the calculation of the own resource based on plastic packaging waste that is not recycled, on the methods and procedure for making available that own resource, on the measures to meet cash requirements, and on certain aspects of the own resource based on gross national income | A9-0048/2021 | European Parliament
background: The EU's COVID-19 recovery efforts, including the Next Generation EU instrument, necessitated sustainable funding mechanisms amid calls to modernize the traditional own-resources system reliant on national contributions. The Parliament will discuss implementing a new plastic-packaging-waste-based revenue stream and adjustments to GNI-based contributions to support budgetary obligations.

It stressed adherence to the Interinstitutional Agreement of 16 December 2020, which outlines budgetary discipline, cooperation, and a roadmap for introducing new own resources, including potential revenue streams to repay EU debt from the recovery instrument. The resolution reiterated Parliament’s longstanding demands for sufficient funding to meet citizens’ expectations, referencing prior positions from 2018 to 2020 on MFF adequacy, equitable burden-sharing, and transparency. It approved amendments to specific articles and recitals of the draft regulation, focusing on clarifying implementation timelines, ensuring alignment with existing treaties, and reinforcing parliamentary oversight. Parliament insisted the Council notify it of any deviations from the approved text and consult again if proposing substantial changes, underscoring the need for continued collaboration in budgetary matters while safeguarding institutional prerogatives.

title: Council regulation laying down the multiannual financial framework for the years 2021 to 2027: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council regulation laying down the multiannual financial framework for the years 2021 to 2027 | A9-0260/2020 | European Parliament

The resolution underscored the legal basis of the MFF under Article 312 TFEU and Euratom Treaty provisions, while omitting specific numerical allocations but implicitly upholding the 2021-2027 timeline and structural priorities outlined in previous parliamentary positions.

title: Motions for resolutions - MFF, Rule of Law Conditionality and Own Resources: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027, the InterInstitutional Agreement, the EU Recovery Instrument and the Rule of Law Regulation | B9-0428/2020 | European Parliament
background: The COVID-19 pandemic caused severe socio-economic disruption across the EU, delaying negotiations on the 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and Recovery Instrument due to disagreements over rule-of-law conditionality and budget allocations. The Parliament will discuss the adoption of the MFF, Recovery Instrument, and related rule-of-law regulation to address crisis recovery and EU budgetary governance.

EPP applauds the German Presidency's leadership in securing the agreement, recognizing it as vital for maintaining European solidarity and overcoming national egoism in budget allocation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined key decisions regarding the EU’s response to the COVID-19 crisis, the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021-2027, and the Rule of Law Regulation. It welcomed the historic political agreements reached in November 2020, including the MFF, the Interinstitutional Agreement (IIA), the EU Recovery Instrument (EURI), and the Rule of Law Regulation, which aim to address the pandemic’s socio-economic impacts, support the Green Deal, digital transition, and protect EU values and taxpayer funds. The Parliament emphasized the necessity of linking EU budget access to adherence to the rule of law, stressing that the Rule of Law Regulation must apply unconditionally from 1 January 2021 without requiring additional guidelines, as its legal text is sufficiently clear. It criticized delays caused by the unanimity rule in the Council, which hindered timely adoption of the package, and rejected attempts by the European Council to interpret legislation, asserting that only the Court of Justice holds interpretive authority. The resolution underscored the Commission’s obligation to enforce EU law independently, including defending the Rule of Law Regulation against potential legal challenges, and affirmed Parliament’s readiness to use legal tools, such as Article 265 TFEU, to ensure compliance. It also highlighted the need for enhanced parliamentary oversight of the Next Generation EU recovery fund and called for addressing unanimity requirements in the upcoming Conference on the Future of Europe to streamline decision-making.

title: Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027 and own resources: time to meet citizens' expectations: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the 2021-2027 multiannual financial framework and own resources: time to meet citizens’ expectations | B9-0110/2019 | European Parliament
background: The European Commission’s 2018 proposals for the 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and own resources system, alongside the UK’s impending withdrawal, necessitated adjustments to EU budget priorities addressing climate action, migration, and defense under Treaty obligations, with the current MFF expiring in 2020. The Parliament will discuss the MFF and own resources reform.

stances.stance:

SD approves integrating rule-of-law conditionality to protect EU funds, proposing enhanced transparency metrics to track climate spending effectiveness without opposing the core mechanism.  
SD endorses establishing new own resources through digital taxation and carbon border adjustments, urging accelerated legislative proposals to match von der Leyen's commitments on EU fiscal integration.  
SD emphasizes strengthening rural investment safeguards in cohesion policy to prevent Euroscepticism, enhancing agricultural subsidies in line with Mercosur competition challenges as a budget enhancement priority.  
SD welcomes Parliament's insistence on trilateral negotiations to prevent funding gaps, advocating strict application of SDG mainstreaming across all programs to meet citizens' regional development expectations.

ID rejects the proposed €1.3 trillion budget increase as absolutely condemning with ID's principle of fiscal restraint and national sovereignty over spending priorities.  
ID opposes the creation of EU-wide taxes through "own resources," denouncing carbon border adjustments and digital levies as illegitimate bureaucratic overreach inconsistent with subsidiarity.  
ID condemns the issue's conditional funding mechanisms as antidemocratic tools enabling Brussels to politically punish member states through budget allocations.  
ID challenges the climate spending mandates as economically destructive to European industries while failing to address global competitors' environmental practices.  
ID warns that Germany's disproportionate financial burden – exacerbated by Brexit contributions – violates fair burden-sharing and amplifies existing Eurozone subsidy imbalances.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need for a robust 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) aligned with EU political priorities, proposing a budget of €1,324.1 billion (1.3% of EU-27 gross national income) to address challenges such as climate change, youth empowerment, research, digitalization, social rights, migration, and defense. It emphasized boosting flagship programs while maintaining cohesion, agriculture, and fisheries funding, and integrating the UN Sustainable Development Goals, climate action, and gender equality across all policies. The resolution demanded a reformed EU revenue system, including new own resources such as a carbon border adjustment mechanism, digital services tax, and financial transaction tax, while abolishing rebates and simplifying VAT. It insisted on a rule-of-law mechanism to protect the EU budget from systemic violations of EU values. The Parliament criticized the Council’s delays in negotiations, called for immediate trilateral talks, and urged the Commission to propose an MFF contingency plan by early 2020 to extend current funding ceilings if needed, preventing program disruptions. It welcomed the incoming Commission’s commitments, including the European Green Deal, but stressed that new initiatives must not compromise the MFF’s ambition, warning against reduced funding as a setback. Climate mainstreaming was underscored as essential, requiring transparent methodologies and Parliament’s involvement in tracking climate-related spending. The resolution reaffirmed Parliament’s refusal to approve any MFF that undermines its legislative role or EU added value, stressing solidarity and efficiency through pooled resources.

title: System of own resources of the European Union: RECOMMENDATION on the draft Council regulation laying down implementing measures for the system of own resources of the European Union and repealing Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 608/2014 | A9-0047/2021 | European Parliament

resolution: The European Parliament raised its consent to the draft Council regulation (10045/2020) on the EU’s system of own resources, aligning with the Interinstitutional Agreement of 16 December 2020 on budgetary discipline, cooperation, and the introduction of new own resources, including a roadmap for their implementation. The resolution emphasized the importance of the 2021-2027 multiannual financial framework (MFF) and recovery plans, referencing prior parliamentary positions from 2018 to 2020 that called for reforms to ensure adequate funding for EU priorities and citizens’ needs. It endorsed Council Decision (EU, Euratom) 2020/2053, particularly Article 10, which governs the own resources system, and reiterated the need for a sustainable financial framework to address challenges such as economic recovery and climate transition. The Parliament instructed its President to communicate this decision to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, underscoring the urgency of finalizing the MFF and associated recovery instruments to meet EU objectives effectively.

title: The creation of guidelines for the application of the general regime of conditionality for the protection of the Union budget: REPORT on the creation of guidelines for the application of the general regime of conditionality for the protection of the Union budget | A9-0226/2021 | European Parliament
background: The EU adopted Regulation 2020/2092 linking budget access to rule of law compliance, effective January 2021, following negotiations on the 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework and recovery instruments. The Commission delayed implementation, citing non-binding European Council conclusions to develop guidelines. The Parliament will discuss procedural and operational challenges in applying the Regulation’s conditionality mechanism.

SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s urgency in addressing systemic corruption risks, emphasizing that delayed action on rule of law breaches directly undermines the integrity of €1.8 trillion in recovery funds.
